PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan, Kathryn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Procedure, I present the committee's report entitled Bills—Consideration in detail: review of the operation of standing order 226 together with the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Procedure Committee's second report of the 38th parliament. It addresses an issue which is probably not in the forefront of members' thoughts but, nonetheless, is fundamental to their rights and responsibilities as members of the House of Representatives. In July this year, Mr Speaker, you wrote to the Procedure Committee drawing its attention to changes in standard drafting practice which have been adopted by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. You asked the committee to consider and, if appropriate, report on the consideration in detail of bills by the House in the light of the varying format of bills presented to it.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue arises from the fact that in 1995 the OPC altered its standard drafting practice so that proposed amendments to existing acts became items in schedules attached to amending bills. Previously they would have been contained within the clauses of the bills, other than minor or machinery amendments which were usually placed in schedules. Bills for new acts still contain the principle provisions within the clauses.

This means that there are now two basic types of bills, each type having different structures. New bills are structured in the traditional way with all the substantive matters in the clauses, but amending bills contain the substantive provisions in one or more schedules to the bill. The new format of amending bills raises the question as to whether the House's traditional method of considering the provisions of a bill is still the most appropriate.

Standing order 226, which prescribes the order in which the House will consider a bill in detail, provides for clauses to be considered individually, but for each schedule to be taken as a whole. Previously, amendments to laws were drafted as several clauses of an amending bill and each clause could be considered and voted on separately. Under the new format they may comprise many varying items within a schedule which are considered and voted on as one.

The committee was unanimous in its view that the right of the House to examine amending legislation in the detail traditionally enjoyed by the House should be maintained. Thus the standing orders should reflect and protect the right of the House to examine each significant part of an amending bill in the same way as it can for a new bill.

The committee has therefore recommended an amendment to standing order 226 which will have the effect of ensuring that the House has the right to consider individually each item within a schedule attached to an amending bill, unless the House grants leave for certain items—or the entire schedule—to be considered together. This would be consistent with the procedures currently followed in respect of the consideration of clauses of bills and the consideration of schedules attached to appropriation bills. Most importantly, it would ensure that the House enjoys the same rights in respect of amendments contained in the schedules to amending bills as it does in relation to the clauses of new bills—whilst, of course, retaining the right to streamline the process by agreement of all members present.

As I said at the beginning, this is probably not the sort of provision that moves members very much. In fact, the change to presenting amendments in schedules is one that even long-serving members of the House probably had not noticed or at least they may well not have realised the import of the change. I am grateful to you, Mr Speaker, for having written to me to ask the committee to consider this matter. The right of members to consider amendments is very important. I personally have always been rather disturbed by the statute law amendment bills which come into this House from time to time, usually a couple of times a year, listing under one heading amendments to a very wide range of bills. The breaking down of any such bill into individual bills is to be welcomed, although I do recognise there would be an additional cost and an amount of work involved in that.

It is important that members have placed before them individual amendments to bills to draw their attention to the changes proposed. The recommendation that the committee has made will extend members' rights to consider proposed amendments in the sort of detail that those amendments ought to attract. The Leader of the House (Mr Reith) is presently waiting on some further advice from the Procedure Committee in relation to a range of previous recommendations that the committee has made over the years to various governments. I hope that, when he considers all the reports that the committee hopes to bring in by the end of this session, this amendment is one that will be included in any proposed changes next year. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Moncrieff for her very valuable contribution.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Joint Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the committee's report entitled Defence Sub‐Committee: Visit to Queensland and the Northern Territory 5‐8 August 1996 , together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In presenting the report, I would like to make a few observations upon it. It is a report that followed a short tour of inspection—inspections for which on earlier occasions when you were in a happier role you were able to accompany the rest of us, Mr Speaker. It was a visit made to northern facilities—Brisbane, Townsville and Darwin—in August this year. The program placed appropriate emphasis on what all of us accept as the essential briefing of members of parliament through the Defence Subcommittee on learning first-hand about the Australian Defence Force, its members, its priorities and how the defence personnel relate to the events in our strategically important part of the world and, in this instance, in northern Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Although short, the program of visits and meetings provided very useful information for the members of the subcommittee, particularly those who have not previously served in that capacity. I take this opportunity to welcome new members of the parliament to the subcommittee. During the program, we had many opportunities to discuss topical defence issues with commanding officers and service personnel, and we gained valuable insight into modern defence capabilities and requirements in the north.

The report we presented does not pretend to be an exhaustive discussion of all the topics raised with or by the subcommittee during the familiarisation program, but in our conclusions we identified some of the particular aspects that we felt were relevant. I draw the attention of honourable members to those, which are on page 33 of the report in section 5. We were particularly interested in seeing what has been undertaken through the Army Presence in the North concept, which has been developing in the services generally since the opening of the new HMAS Darwin defence base when my predecessor Sir James Killen was Minister for Defence.

PARA.BREAK: As far as APIN is concerned, the new emphasis began with the opening of Robert son Barracks in 1989 and will continue until the final phase of the project in the year 2001. Fully realised, it will mean the relocation of some 2,300 soldiers and 2,600 family members to Darwin. APIN represents a departure from the traditional home location elements of the Australian Defence Force and is predominantly designed to ensure that the members of the Australian Defence Force are climatically adapted and are located where we can best provide a response, if necessary, in the more remote areas of Australia and to any threat that might emerge from outside Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: APIN represents a major commitment to increasing Australia's defence capabilities in the north. It is also a major financial investment. It is a clear example of tailoring modern construction to meet the demands of the terrain and the climate of the tropics. The overall cost of the project is around $500 million, and there are significant flow‐on effects for the Northern Territory economy. We learned that at present Defence is directly spending an average of $2 million per week in the Northern Territory, which with construction would be closer to $4 million per week, not including construction and maintenance expenditure by the Defence Housing Authority. In eight years of operation in Darwin, the authority has injected $27.3 million on average each year into the local economy. The relative effect of direct and indirect Defence expenditure is expected to be maintained at around 10 per cent of the gross territory product from 1995 to 2001.

One of the features of APIN which impressed the subcommittee was the continued partnership with private industry in the design and construction of the facilities and amenities, and the associated tendering processes which are designed to encourage the participation of small as well as large contractors.

The Defence Housing Authority has also participated in successful joint ventures with private sector developers. The committee attended the opening of Fairway Waters, which was opened by my colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas), and the latest collaborative project at Palmerston, south‐east of Darwin, which provides high quality housing for defence personnel as well as for private purchases.

As one who at the time was a little critical of the founding of the Defence Housing Authority and a bit concerned about the role it would take, on each of the many projects I have seen I think the Defence Housing Authority has done a remarkable job in improving the quality of accommodation for the men and women of the Australian Defence Force and their families. Publicly, I would like to endorse them in the task they are pursuing.

Another area of major interest to the subcommittee during the northern visits program was the Army 21 review proposed blueprint for the Army of the 21st century. Members of the committee are critical that within the army there has been too little opportunity for dialogue between members of the services in a public way. We do not see that restructuring the army is something that needs to be confidential. It is something that would have benefited if it had been developed in a way which allowed all those interested to contribute to the debate rather than having it held in such close confine that few knew of its content, although there has been much speculation. This has not just been within the services but also within the media, and a lot of it has been about the directions to be proposed for Australia's army of the future.

As a result of the ministerial defence policy statement in parliament on 15 October 1996, there is now an opportunity to know a little of the directions the government intends to take. The subcommittee would hope that it will shortly receive a briefing from officers of the Department of Defence on the content of this policy statement and would hope that, from that, there might be an opportunity not just for a parliamentary debate but also for a more open debate in the community generally about the directions that it should take. As one who has been involved in the services for many years, I think it is important that we look at it not only from the top down. In other words, it should not be a management exercise; we need to look at the role of the individual soldier.

BREAK.PARA: I, for one, have been impressed by the way in which individual soldiers today are better qualified and more skilled. They make a very important contribution individually beyond that of some of their predecessors because of enhanced capacity—the greater firepower of weapons and technological equipment available to them. It is of concern to me that we do not just accept, for example, a nine‐man section in an infantry company of days gone by as being the necessary way to operate in the future.

If individual soldiers are going to be more sophisticated in their capacity to deliver firepower, then we should be looking at the numbers within sections. We should not just be looking at the role of the individual soldier but at the role of the army itself. I trust all that will be taken into account within the Army 21 review. Aspects that relate to the performance of the soldier are at least as important as they are in the management of the personnel of the forces.

The other aspect I wanted to comment on briefly is the army reserves. I am concerned at the capacity of most individuals in today's work force to provide the 50‐day training that is to be expected of members of the general reserve. That is a big ask. It is going to make it extraordinarily difficult for many of those in the wider community who would like to contribute to the army reserves and participate. It worries me that it is going to be hard, but not because of the security of their employment. It is not a matter of giving them a guarantee of being able to get their jobs; it is a matter of their ability in relation to the work demands of the work force. Problems need to be addressed in that category.

PARA.BREAK: In conclusion, I would like to thank the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan), and the military and civilian personnel of the Australian Defence Force, who assisted in ensuring the success of the subcommittee's familiarisation program, the first of this parliament. I would also like to thank the secretariat of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I thank Joanne Towner, the secretary; Chris Lawson, who accompanied us on this mission; and Jane Vincent, who is on the Defence Subcom mittee. Each of them worked closely with defence personnel to develop a program of visits, briefings and inspections. These provide much valuable information about defence requirements and capabilities in northern Australia to subcommittee members and, through us, hopefully to the parliament. I commend the report to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to endorse the remarks and contribution of the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). I certainly did not disagree with anything he said. It is a feature of the operation of the Defence Subcommittee that members really do try to bring an honest view and adopt a bipartisan approach to the issues presented to them. I compliment all who have been involved in the tradition in the past and those presently serving for continuing it now.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a few things I did want to comment on about this visit. I apologise if I go over some of the ground of the right honourable member for New England. It was really great that we were able to visit the 5th Aviation Regiment, which had been involved in the tragedy at Townsville. I compliment Colonel Tony Fraser, the commanding officer, and all members of the unit. We had a briefing. I was impressed with the honesty and sincerity of the briefing and the way all issues were openly presented without any questioning or probing. I can only commend them for the spirit and approach they are adopting following such a tragedy, which seared the nation as a whole. Not only us but all of Australia wish them well in rebuilding.

We were able to visit the 1st Division, which includes 6 RAR, the Ready Reserve component. I do not want to make any cheap points about the government. The government has made a decision to disband the Ready Reserve. When we went around, we were very impressed with the standard of the ready reservists and their commitment and motivation. I thought it was interesting that the officers were really impressed with the type of individual they are getting into the Ready Reserve.

BREAK.PARA: What makes this perhaps more relevant today is that we are having calls for introducing national service. Following the remarks of the right honourable member for New England, I think the army is requiring a better educated, more adaptable, more flexible soldier—with no disrespect—rather than the cannon fodder that we have traditionally been used to in years gone by.

As you go around the community, you often hear the call, `Let's reintroduce national service.' On this visit, as with every other visit I have had the opportunity to have with the Defence Subcommittee, I have never once had an officer or a member of the services come up to me and say, `We need to reinstitute national service.'

I want to make a public request of the chairmen of our committee and subcommittee: in view of the popularity of this call, perhaps it would be worth while if we did have a short inquiry to look at whether national service is appropriate and whether the army's grave reservations about national service are well founded. The subcommittee could perform a useful task in putting that to bed.

Last but not least, I wanted to talk about Army 21, as this was raised previously. I congratulate the army for such a thoroughgoing review. I do not want to comment on the ministerial statement, but I do want to say thank you to the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan), as I understand he is undertaking to provide us with a copy of the important information available. I agree with the chairman of the committee that it is healthy for us to try to understand the concepts underpinning Army 21 and then have a debate about our respective views on the direction of the army. That ought to be mirrored into the community.

Again, I would like to say how much I appreciate—as I know other subcommittee members do—the opportunity to see serving men and women on their own territory, to speak frankly with them to gauge their concerns on the ground, and then come back to the parliament and report, as we are doing today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand very briefly today to be involved in the tabling of the report entitled Defence Sub‐Committee: Visit to Queensland and the Northern Territory, 5‐8 August 1996 . It is an excellent report and it indicates the extent to which this parliament, particularly its committees, are involved in the area of defence, foreign affairs and trade. I want to particularly thank the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for his comments about bipartisanship. It is very important, in this committee in particular, that we do exercise a very large degree of bipartisanship. As somebody who has been involved in this committee—this is my third parliament—I think that a very large measure of bipartisanship does exist and that the parliamentary processes and, hopefully, the Australian Defence Force is the better for that input.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to reiterate what both the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the member for Chifley have said about 5 Aviation Regiment and, in particular, the commanding officer, Colonel Tony Fraser. None of us could have been anything but impressed by the professionalism and the leadership that that officer exhibited when we were briefed so soon after the Black Hawk tragedy, which is still bouncing around the media and will continue to for some time.

The report itself does raise a number of broader issues in terms of the Ready Reserve. Decisions have been made by our government, and I strongly support the measure that we have taken. But it does have an implication for Army 21 and, as outlined in the ministerial statement delivered a couple of weeks ago, a lot of ground has to be covered in explaining what Army 21 involves. At the local level, I have yet to find out to what extent 49 RQR and 25 RQR are involved in the augmented or revised 6 Brigade with respect to that concept. I think Army 21 has a few potential pitfalls, but until such time as we are briefed in some detail it is very difficult to make a specific comment.

In relation to APIN, the Army Presence in the North, as somebody who was involved—as you have been, Mr Speaker—in the Public Works Committee, I can say that a very large amount of capital expenditure has been outlaid in establishing what is a great strategic asset in the Darwin area. I am sure the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) will have something to say about APIN when he gets on his feet in a moment. Robertson barracks is a facility that is both functional and cosmetically pleasing. It is a facility which all members of the army, in particular, will be pleased with.

Implicit in some of the comments contained in this report is the professionalism of the Australian Defence Force. Yes, the ADF has shortages. Yes, at times they are not able to meet their commitments. However, I am sure the right honourable member for New England and the member for Chifley would join with me in yet again congratulating the Australian Defence Force, including its senior hierarchy, in particular, General Baker who, as the Chief of the Defence Force over recent years, has shown a large measure of leadership under very difficult and trying conditions, particularly when it comes to the budget. It gives me pleasure to be involved—albeit briefly—in the tabling of this report, and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the report entitled Defence Sub-Committee: Visit to Queensland and the Northern Territory, 5‐8 August 1996 tabled by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). It represents a very important development in defence for the Northern Territory. At the outset, Mr Speaker, I must advise you and other members of the House that I was unable to complete the whole tour with members of the Defence Subcommittee. I was able to do only the Northern Territory leg of the tour. Unfortunately, due to other commitments, I missed out on what were probably very interesting parts of the tour.

SPEECH.PARA: The visit to the Northern Territory was very important in view of the fact that there has been a tremendous build‐up by government over the past few years about defence facilities in the Northern Territory. The right honourable member for New England did say that the financial benefits to the Northern Territory are somewhat outstanding. In this 1996-97 budget an additional $2 million will be spent on infrastructure facilities in the Northern Territory, on top of nearly $4 million that is currently being spent. It is estimated that the defence budget for the Northern Territory is in excess of $200 million.

We are aware of other impending programs for the Northern Territory. I understand from the Chairman of the Public Works Committee, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), that the Public Works Committee has just visited Darwin and was able to evaluate some proposals that are being put to it by the department. I am aware of the upgrade of RAAF base Darwin, involving an expenditure in excess of $60 million, which will make that facility much more efficient, as there will be more space available, with infrastructure that will be able to get aircraft in and out much more quickly. There is also an upgrade at the Larrackeyah barracks on behalf of the navy at HMAS Coonawarra where, if the Public Works Committee recommends that the money be spent, $20 million will be expended to increase the facility. I thought it was very important that our members were able to see and hear first-hand from the officers in Darwin who were involved in providing the briefings.

I would like to speak about Norforce in this regard. Norforce is a small military facility. Members were given a very good briefing by the commander of Norforce. We also had a briefing from APIN, the Army Presence in the North project. That gave members a comprehensive feeling for where we are going. We also had briefings from the headquarters of Northern Command, which is called Norcom.

The other exciting project which will need to be evaluated in the near future is the army's decision to take over a property in a remote part of the Northern Territory, between Timber Creek and Kununurra, called Bradshaw Station. Bradshaw Station is being evaluated to see whether it will become a facility for tropical warfare training for the Australian Army. I am also led to believe that other countries which are interested in tropical warfare training will be invited to participate at that new training facility once it has been approved.

BREAK.PARA: I was very fortunate to have my colleagues from the Defence Subcommittee with me when I opened a joint facility at Palmerston, in Darwin, called Fairway Waters. I had invited my colleagues to attend the official opening of the joint housing venture between the Defence Housing Authority and the Delfin Property Group. Members were able to see first‐hand the type of accommodation that is now being built and supplied for our army people in the territory.

I think it is very important to understand that people in the defence system need to have good housing if they are going to stay, especially in what one considers to be a remote area. I do not see Darwin as being a remote area, but somebody coming from Sydney or Melbourne may perceive it to be remote. The important thing is that the accommodation now being provided under this new joint venture is something that we as a government, the army as an organisation and Delfin as the joint venture partner can be very proud of. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a small contribution to the tabling of this report by the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. Although I am in my third term in the parliament, it is the first time that my colleagues have given me the privilege of serving on this committee. I am delighted to be a member of the Defence Subcommittee as part of the overall committee. It is obviously a very good committee. I have enjoyed so far the way in which the committee is run. The committee secretariat is obviously very professional. So I am looking forward to my service on the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The four days or so that the Defence Subcommittee spent on its visit to Queensland and the Northern Territory was extremely valuable from my point of view. Although I am one member of the committee who has actually served in the army—and, indeed, one of two members in the place who have returned from active service—the army has changed a lot since I was in it in the late 1960s and early 1970s. However, as you get back into it, visit some of the bases and talk to some of the personnel, you see that some things have not changed a great deal. Certainly, this was a very important part of my re-education and reintroduction to the operation of the services. I enjoyed the four days very much and found them particularly helpful.

I thank the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) for allowing us the use of the 34 Squadron aircraft. It was a very comfortable way to travel, but perhaps we should not dwell too much on that side of it. It also made the four days very productive because it allowed us to do in four days what we could not possibly have done otherwise. So that was very worth while and useful.

I understand that the committee is to visit other defence establishments. Our particular objective on these four days was to visit the establishments in Queensland and the Northern Territory. Of course, there are many other military establishments in Australia and I am looking forward to having the opportunity to visit those.

Could I also say how impressed I was by the reception we received from defence personnel, from senior officers down, in all of the three services. Each of them was well prepared for our visit, from Major‐General Ford down. In every place we went they were very well prepared for our visit, very cooperative and very pleased that we as members of the committee and members of parliament were actually on the ground to talk to them and to talk to soldiers and other ranks about what was going on in the areas in which they were involved. I mention that because it was very pleasing to be received and to have been so comprehensively briefed at every stop.

The member for Chifley (Mr Price) and others have alluded to the Ready Reserve scheme. The government, in its policy for some time prior to the election, was committed to disbanding the Ready Reserve scheme. I believe that was the right decision, although I ought to say how impressed I was when I talked to ready reservists. They were very committed to the scheme. They had obviously benefited greatly from it. No doubt many people were disappointed by that decision. But I think the point emphasised by the minister in the speech he made the other day which was called `Restructuring the Australian Army and defence efficiency review' was that this would allow us to do what has been long overdue—that is, to put some real resources into the reserve. For a long time the reserve has been very much a second rate organisation. It has been underequipped. The decision to do away with the Ready Reserve will free up funds to enable the reserve to be brought up to strength and to increase the contribution that can be made by reservist soldiers.

I know from my own experience that there is nothing more frustrating than to be in the reserve, committed to it—and most of those who join the reserve are very committed to it—but to find the training is not available to the extent that it should be and that the equipment is not up to scratch. I think that will be a very worthwhile outcome of the decision to disband the Ready Reserve.

I say to the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Dondas) how much I enjoyed the Northern Territory part of the visit. Darwin is a bit remote for most of us. The APIN project, the Army Presence in the North project, is going very well. Robertson barracks were excellent. That was one eye-opener for me, not having been around the army very much for many years—to see the change in the conditions that exist for soldiers these days. Their living conditions and the facilities that are available to them are excellent. Robertson barracks is a very fine asset for the defence services. (Time expired)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Campbell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It has come to my attention that recently quarantine has become very lax in Australia. Indeed, there seems to be a conspiracy to take away protection that has long been enjoyed. Perhaps this is in pursuit of the mythical `level playing field'. I have been very concerned. I know that the government is presently considering introducing New Zealand apples to Australia. New Zealand has a disease, fire blight, which is common throughout the world. It does not exist in Australia, and nowhere in the world where it exists has it ever been able to be eradicated. The reason New Zealand does not have a pear industry is that pears are particularly susceptible to it. If the disease gets into Goulburn Valley there is absolutely no doubt that it will wipe out our pear industry as well. I have been told recently by several people associated with the New South Wales markets that they believe New Zealand apples are coming to Australia illegally in containers packed behind a couple of rows of kiwi fruit.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an indictment of AQIS that they are not in a position to inspect these containers. The reason for my bill is to make the government liable for any damage it does to Australian industry through neglect. Officers of the department who knowingly take action or fail to take action which cause damage to industry should be personally liable. The bill addresses the question of government liability. This should be of some comfort to the industry.

We have seen the government in recent times allowing in chicken meat, with its attendant risks. No-one can tell exactly what the risk is. I realise that there is no such thing as zero risk, but I believe that we should not take chances. In Western Australia, some growers recently imported canola seeds from New Zealand. This canola seed was passed by the quarantine service, but on planting it produced several species of weeds not known in Australia, among them cleavers, redshank and field madder. All these weeds have a significant potential cost to the industry. Keeping them out should have been a priority. They are here now, however, and we now have the job of eradication. The government is beholden to making sure that farmers personally involved in this process are not personally out of pocket.

Similarly, we have Johnes disease of sheep, also introduced from New Zealand. At the moment it seems to be contained fairly well around the Orange district in New South Wales. It tends to be a disease of higher rainfall areas, but there are parts of Australia that we would certainly want to keep this disease out of and efforts should now be made to eradicate it.

Quarantine has been downgraded. Governments of all persuasions are now drawn to what they call `balancing the risk'. This is totally unacceptable. It is totally unacceptable to primary producers and it would damage Australia's `clean, green' image enormously. One of the big advantages we have overseas, and one of the assets we must protect, is our reputation for clean, green produce which is produced without resort to large amounts of herbicides and insecticides. A lot of our markets in Europe are particularly sensitive about this issue—far more so than Asia. I have said for a long time that the potential market for these commodities is much more likely to be in Europe than it is in Asia, if for no other reason than the cost factor and the enormous productivity of the Mekong River delta.

The bill I have introduced is highly reasonable and should be supported by this House. Hopefully, it will restore some semblance of integrity to the actions of AQIS and the government's actions with respect to AQIS. I seek leave to present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Leave granted.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Some two years ago I was visited by a group of people who said they represented the Sudanese ethnic group in Australia. They were educated and sophisticated people. We sat and talked. As many members of parliament would know, when people visit them for the first time one is quickly made aware of one's ignorance of the history and the current political situation of countries remote from Australia. I was quickly acquainted with the dreadful situation in Sudan, and hence I was moved to support my colleague the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) and move the motion the House is to discuss today. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House:
(1) expresses its repugnance with the Government of Sudan's policies of genocide against Sudanese groups;
(2) condemns the sustained and systematic attempt to enforce Sharia law on non-Islamic citizens; and
(3) calls on the Australian Government and the international community, including the UN Security Council, to:
(a) impose an arms embargo on the Government of Sudan;
(b) establish air exclusion zones in Sudan;
(c) support the peace initiatives of the Inter-Governmental Authority for Drought and Desertification;
(d) engage in discussion with all officially banned democratic opposition groups;
(e) ensure the immediate access by the UN operation, Life-Line Sudan and other aid agencies into all areas; and
(f) provide teams to monitor human rights in the north, south and the Nuba Mountains of Sudan.

Some two years ago I had my attention drawn to the efforts of Dr Biro, who was the UN Human Rights Special Rapporteur to Sudan, whose aim was to prepare a report for the United Nations on human rights in Sudan. After many problems and great difficulties associated with gaining access to Sudan, Dr Biro presented his report. I have a copy of his report, dated 1 February 1994, in the House with me today.

Dr Biro in his visit to Sudan reported on many items. After reading them, one is quite moved to realise that there is such inhumane practice anywhere in the world today. He devotes part of his report to the examination of violations by the government of Sudan and analyses those violations in a number of areas, including extra juridical killings and summary executions. He mentions in his report enforced or involuntary disappearances, torture and other cruel, inhumane and degrading treatments. He documents conversations and evidence that he received whilst visiting Sudan of all these practices.

Dr Biro also enunciates the arbitrary arrest and detention provisions and the due process of law in that country. He mentions that the provision of penal legislation is inconsistent with international norms. He mentions and reports to the United Nations on slavery, servitude, slave trade, forced labour and similar institutions and practices. He reports on the lack of freedom of conscience and on some specific cases of violation of human rights of persons belonging to religious minorities. This is a huge report—covering some 40 or 50 pages—to the United Nations by a special investigator who, only after great effort, gained entry to some parts of Sudan but who was not able to gain access to all parts of Sudan.

I am indebted to Baroness Cox, a member of the British House of Lords, who provided further information. Baroness Cox is also a person who is deeply concerned, as are the Sudanese refugees in Australia, with human rights in Sudan. On a number of occasions and in a number of various roles, she has visited Sudan and has had conversations with people there.

In reading the reports from Baroness Cox, one has to be aware that there is a continuation of all of the matters that were identified by Dr Biro for the United Nations. The evidence that Dr Biro established back in 1993 and 1994 continues in train today. The evidence is supported by the neighbouring country of Eritrea. I have in my possession a statement by the Consulate of the State of Eritrea addressed to the House of Lords in the United Kingdom. It outlines the observance by Eritrea—which, goodness me, has an appalling enough background of its own—of the events in Sudan, its effort to establish a reasonable relationship with the government of Sudan and its failure to be assured that human rights are given any strength or given any acknowledgment in Sudan.

Baroness Cox, in her visits to Sudan, has come forward with a number of recommendations which support those made by the United Nations, but these are more recent because the United Nations has not, since 1994, been allowed access to report on the affairs of Sudan. Baroness Cox reports on the continuing practice of the denial of human rights in Sudan. She says that the government of Sudan is continuing to transform by force the ethnically and religiously diverse country into an Arabic Islamic state against the wishes of the vast majority of black Africans. Estimates that she has had of the levels of genocide indicate that there could have been as many as 1.8 million children killed and a possible total death toll of over five million people.

The institution of slavery is rife in Sudan. Slavery continues on a large scale supported, one would have to say, by the government of Sudan. Those sold into slavery are mainly women and young children who are forced into animal‐like conditions and sold as slaves to the highest bidder. Their families are—

TALK.START.PARA: —And forcibly converted to Islam.

—And forcibly converted to Islam of a fundamentalist type, although I would have to say that this is not an entirely Islamic cause because there are moderate Islamic groups in Sudan that have felt the force of the government of Sudan which is fanatical in its interpretation of Islamic rule.

SPEECH.PARA: There are raids taking place by Arabic forces on African towns. People are being locked in their houses and the houses set on fire. There is a story of one church congregation being locked in the church and the church set on fire. Everybody perished in that process. I have seen films of people who have suffered burns from torture and mistreatment in the Nuba Mountains in southern Sudan.

The cause is very significant. The Australian government has, over a period, carried out a worthwhile aid and support program. Our nation needs to go further. We need to be arguing in the United Nations—the Security Council has not yet decided on this issue—for a ban on the provision of arms to Sudan. I join with my colleagues in this House in suggesting that we need to move in that direction. We should also provide continuing support and continuing aid for the people of Sudan. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I speak in endorsement of the broad outline of this motion. With the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), I have had contact with the Sudanese community in Sydney. About 18 months ago they raised this matter with us very clearly. A previous motion which was suggested for debate in this House was never debated. This matter was also mentioned in the British House of Commons.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had contact with the Reverend Dr Richard Rogers who runs a group called Light and Hope for Sudan. In recent months in Britain he has made very clear, by way of hunger strikes and other activities, the concern of the Church of England about the rights of Christians in Sudan. A lot of the international attention on the situation in Sudan has been heightened by the visit of the Archbishop of Canterbury to Sudan and his expose of some of the practices there in the past few years. It is not just the problems of the Christians, it is also the ethnic discrimination within the country, the enslavement of the Dinka and other people, and the attack on animus beliefs. It is not just a Christian‐Muslim issue.

PARA.BREAK: Sudan has obtained a degree of international opprobrium. The United Nations has had to move against Sudan this year, mainly in the context of Sudan's refusal to extradite three terrorists who, it is thought, played a very crucial role in the attempted assassination of President Mubarak of Egypt during a visit to Khartoum. As a result, international diplo matic restrictions have been placed on travel arrangements of Sudanese government officials. There have been restrictions on air travel. From April onwards, they have had a diminished diplomatic status throughout most of the Western world, culminating in the air embargo. At the same time, Sudan is on the United States State Department's list of seven countries that are, as the United States would view it, involved in international terrorism. Another country on that list is Libya.

SPEECH.PARA: On an international front, there is concern about the degree to which they are, as a state, interfering in the internal affairs of a number of other countries not only in the Middle East but also in the Western world. There is a very clear involvement between them and Islamic fundamentalist forces in trying to overthrow the government of Egypt and, as I said, in the attempted assassination.
Only last week the Sydney Morning Herald contained a small piece detailing the latest outrages committed by this regime. The article, headed `Sexes segregated', stated:

Khartoum's State Council has imposed a law segregating the sexes in public places, including transport, political rallies and wedding parties. The law also bans women from going to markets unaccompanied by a "legitimate male companion"—a husband, brother or father—after nightfall.

That is typical of the attempt by the regime of Lieutenant‐General Omar Hassan Ahmad al‐Bashir to implement aspects of Sharia law, most fundamentally in restricting female rights. We are seeing an even more draconian indication of that in Afghanistan at the moment. There have been these aspects of religious restrictions.

Another article reports that the Beja people of north-eastern Sudan, which is basically a schismatic Islamic group, have been declared by the state and by the main ideologue of this regime, Hassan al‐Turabi, not to be Muslims. They have also been discriminated against—just like the mainstream Christian and animus groups.

The people in the country are suffering from gross malnutrition and tuberculosis and there have been constant attempts by the government to restrict and harass aid organisations attempting to provide supplies. In the late 20th century the country has been identified with organised slavery—something that disappeared in most parts of the world a century or two ago.

An article in the Age of 21 June this year, taken from the Baltimore Sun, talks of the efforts of two of that paper's reporters: Gilbert Lewthwaite and Gregory Kane. They wrote about buying two boys for $US500 each—the cash equivalent of five cows—from an Arab trader in a remote village. The article stated:

In their three‐part report, they wrote: "If we were Sudanese slaveholders, we might use such children for herding or for household chores in return for nothing but the crumbs from our table. We might give them Arabic names and convert them to Islam. We might use a girl for sexual pleasure, perhaps as a wife.
"But we are not Sudanese Arabs. We are visitors . . . and our mission is not to perpetrate slavery but to expose it."

The children, aged 10 and 12, who had been purchased had been seized from their father, an impoverished cereal farmer, six years earlier by government‐backed militia. Sudan—in addition to it destabilising Muslim fundamentalist terrorism and its interference in other countries—is internally suppressing religious and ethnic minorities.

As I say, traditionally Sudan has taken a leading role in the enslavement of minority peoples, particularly the Dinkas. This is not just a minor sideline in the backblocks of the country where this might happen to go on because of a lack of central control; there is the involvement of the central government at the highest level. There have been very strong indications of the use of slaves by leading government officials, and it is characteristic of the leadership of the armed forces.

As an indication that things are not getting any better, in the last month or so the Sudanese government has indicated the further centralisation of power in the country. As with many African nations, this country is subject to a degree of schismatic conduct by ethnic minorities and by regions. As part of the process of trying to get everyone on side at various stages, they conceded decentralised power to states. In the last month, however, they announced that they will abolish state assemblies and basically go back to a process of government appointment of all officials at a local level.

Since 1983, the SPLA, a group that has been waging a war against the government, has splintered. Whilst the people opposing the government have received a degree of support from Eritrea, Uganda and other players in the region because of the fears they have about Sudan's external operations, there is no doubt at the moment that the central government is militarily in a strong position. This is having repercussions throughout that region of Africa. Uganda has used the fears it has of Sudan to justify a 20 per cent increase in its defence budget. That is typical of what is happening in the region because of the continuation of this regime.

It has been estimated that one million people have been killed since 1983, and that billions of pounds have been spent in military operations. There have also been threats by President Bashir to invade Uganda. There have been occasions when Uganda's air space has been ignored.

I join with the member for Mitchell in saying that Australia must take a fairly strong position internationally on this regime. It is not just a few members of parliament and the United Nations which can make diplomatic deals; reputable international organisations such as Amnesty International can also assist. Amnesty has published yet another critical report to coincide with the anniversary of the 1989 coup. The report once more accuses Sudan of systematic and comprehensive abuse of human rights, citing incidents of slavery. Amnesty's conclusions have been repeated by other human rights agencies including Human Rights Watch and Christian Solidarity International.

In conclusion, I think this motion is important. Sudan is a country which does not get much coverage in Australia; it is not in a region within our direct influence. A growing presence of Sudanese citizens in Sydney have raised this matter with me and the member for Mitchell at a number of functions. Internationally, as we are seeing, there is concerted action being taken by the United States, in particular, and the United Nations to bring to world attention the concerns about this regime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated by the prior speaker, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), Sudan is not close to Australia, and certainly it is not within Australia's sphere of influence. But the fact that there are such appalling breaches of human rights in that country is reason for this parliament to speak out. Over the last few years attempts have been made in international forums to bring this outlaw government to heel. These attempts have not been as successful as one would have liked; therefore, more is needed.

SPEECH.PARA: Through multilateral and bilateral contacts, this government has done whatever it can to bring about a better future for the people of Sudan. I would like to compliment the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), and indeed the government, on what has been done to date. The government is committed to the universal protection of human rights and it deplores the abuse of human rights in Sudan and elsewhere. Unfortunately, though, these abuses go on day by day and year by year.

In the time that the current Sudanese government has been in power, about seven years, there has been a common thread running through its approach to its people. The common thread is the oppression of human rights. The government tends to polish its image from time to time, but the substance of its abuse remains.

Baroness Cox was referred to by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). This wonderful lady has been to the Sudan on many occasions. She does not hesitate to speak out; she does not hesitate to go and find the facts. On a recent visit to Sudan she represented Christian Solidarity International. The honourable member for Mitchell highlighted a number of the findings of the group from Christian Solidarity International, and I will mention some of them again.

The government of Sudan continues to try to transform by force the ethnically and religiously diverse country into an Arab Islamic state against the wishes of the vast majority of its population, both north and south. The devastating effects of this policy in the south, in the Nuba Mountains, are tantamount to genocide. The report also refers to the mass displacement of the population of the south and the Nuba Mountains by means of aerial and ground attacks on civilians, slavery and the manipulation of humanitarian aid.

The honourable member for Mitchell pointed out that many people have died, possibly about 1.5 million. Raids by the Sudanese army and by militias have taken place and, as a result of those raids, we have seen murder, torture, rape, looting, the destruction of property and the taking of slaves. The institution of chattel slavery is continuing unabated; indeed, it seems to have the support of the government of Sudan. The number of chattel slaves is estimated to be in the tens of thousands. In most cases the slaves are women and children, and they are forced to provide domestic and agricultural labour or to provide sexual services against their will for the provision of nothing but minimum food for survival. Generally they are forced to adopt the Muslim religion. I must say that I find it absolutely unacceptable that, in this day and age, we have a situation where slavery is endemic in Sudan.

Indeed, when Baroness Cox was in Sudan she met some Arab traders and discussed the nature of their transactions. Apparently, the current average price required to redeem a slave is three cows. This is trade in people—totally unacceptable in 1996. The traders claimed that this price was necessary to cover the costs of finding children, abduction and purchase. Also many people have lost their families and have gone all over the country to find them. In some cases they have bought their families back only to have them stolen again.

PARA.BREAK: I strongly support the motion before the House. It is about time the international community took a very firm line on the Sudan. The conduct in that country is woeful, it is totally unacceptable and it is about time that we brought this government to heel. This motion must be implemented. We cannot have slavery, torture, murder, rape and sharia—Islamic law—imposed on non‐Islamic citi zens. It is about time the world stood up and did something positive. It is about time that this outlaw government was rejected by international society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its concern about the high level of concentration of media ownership in Australia and current threats to what limited diversity remains, and urges the Government to resolutely oppose any changes which would narrow the structure of ownership even further.

Freedom of speech is an issue of intense debate in our community at present. The shallowness of this debate, which, I have to say, has been encouraged by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), is exposed when issues about the ownership and control of Australia's media, our vehicles for the expression of ideas, are examined.

For, in a country in which the Prime Minister claims to be one which encourages openness and freedom of expression, we have one of the highest concentrations of media ownership in the world. This concentration of ownership already poses a serious threat to the diversity of opinion and comment in our democracy and so also to our freedom of speech.

In Australia this limited diversity is no more clearly underlined than in the ownership of our capital city and national daily newspapers. In Australia newspapers are a vital part of the national debate in public affairs, politics, religion, sport or almost any other area you care to name. Yet they are controlled by a tiny group of people. The prime example is Rupert Murdoch's News Ltd which owns capital city dailies in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide, Hobart and Darwin, as well as owning the national daily the Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Super League.

—And Super League. That's right. Of these cities, News Ltd has a monopoly in Brisbane, Adelaide, Hobart and Darwin. The combined circulation of News Ltd papers give it an extraordinary 67 per cent of the total daily circulation of capital city newspapers in Australia—a high level of dominance. The fact that this potential for influence is in the hands of an American citizen makes the situation even more disturbing.

SPEECH.PARA: Concentration of ownership is also a major concern in a number of other areas. In the publication of magazines, Kerry Packer's PBL group controls 47 per cent of the total circulation of major magazines in Australia, Rupert Murdoch's News Ltd controls 26 per cent and Mr Murdoch's nephew, Matt Hambry, owns over eight per cent. Together these three individuals control over 80 per cent of the top 30 magazines sold in Australia.

In television the three major networks are controlled by corporations which are also powerful in other parts of the media—News Ltd in the case of the Seven Network; the Canadian group, TNQ, in the case of the Ten group; and by a 100 per cent shareholding by Kerry Packer's PBL in the case of the Nine Network.

While the situation in radio ownership remains slightly more open, new threats to diversity are also emerging in the rapidly expanding technologies of cable television and other multimedia services. Control of Super League is an example of an extension into another area which also involves potential dominance. The reason why this concentration of ownership is of great concern is the constraint it imposes on diversity. Diversity of information and ideas in Australia is already very limited and any arguments that suggest there is choice in news and opinion provided by the privately owned media is clearly confusing diversity with multiplicity. Diversity is crucial for the health of democracy and variety of opinion is the key to maintaining a healthy debate about ideas and about the future of our community.

PARA.BREAK: Prior to the election, the coalition announced that it would hold a public inquiry into the issues of media control and owner ship. This undertaking was welcomed as a positive step in establishing a clearer vision of the future of media ownership in Australia. Unfortunately, after the election the coalition government chose not to pursue this initiative and has instead opted for an in‐house departmental inquiry. This backdown by the government is of great concern for it indicates an unwillingness to comprehensively address the maze of issues surrounding media ownership and control.

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of governments over the past two decades to adequately address this issue is the principal reason behind the narrowing of diversity and the increased concentration of control we face today. A public inquiry would have opened up the debate. It would have allowed a wide variety of submissions and information from across the community and it would have provoked a wider awareness of issues surrounding media ownership in Australian society.

In raising this issue, it is important to remember that in October 1991, 133 members and senators in this place signed a petition to the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, urging him to oppose the sale of the Fairfax group to any individual or consortium which would result in a reduction of diversity and a greater concentration of ownership. I seek leave to table that petition.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This petition was organised in a bipartisan manner by me and the former member for Bradfield, David Connolly. It is interesting to note that amongst the signatories were the present Prime Minister, the present Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), the present Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the now Leader of the House (Mr Reith). These people supported the need for diversity then. They should certainly continue to do so now.

SPEECH.PARA: Questions as to what diversity in our media should mean in practice and how it can be distinguished from multiplicity, which is often mistaken as the same thing, would have been a key point of examination in a public inquiry and, in the current debate about freedom of speech, would have done much to broaden and deepen the discourse. Equally, the issue of foreign ownership and control—an issue of which a great many people in the community feel deeply concerned—could have been addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m, the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The consideration of this notice will be resumed later today and the honourable member will have leave to continue his speech.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Sports CommissionAustralian Institute of Sport

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House today to the farcical situation that has developed with the Australian Sports Commission and the Australian Institute of Sport with respect to the continuing inclusion of netball in the AIS program. Today there is to be a meeting between Netball Australia and the AIS to consider the continuing inclusion of netball in that program. I find it extraordinary that Australia's major women's participation sport is even being considered by the ASC for exclusion.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it equally extraordinary to read an article by Lisa Olsen in the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday, 23 October under the headline `Get a life. Get a sport. And get rid of that silly netball'. To find that a woman would write such an article about such a great participation sport as netball is extraordinary. I call on the ASC to honour the commitment that they have had over several years and keep netball in the AIS, keep it in the program there and not try to blackmail the Netball Association into including a team from the AIS in their national competition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech in the grievance debate in the last sitting fortnight I spoke about the mutuality principle in relation to registered clubs in Queensland and New South Wales in particular. Since that time the Industry Commission has tabled a report on tourism, accommoda tion and training. In a summary on the mutuality principle they were quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The principle of mutuality is soundly based. However, given the changing nature and scope of some large clubs, the Tax Commissioner may need to review their eligibility for access to concessions under the mutuality principle.
That is something with which I concur and was the reason for the debate in the first place.

During my speech I spoke of the Illawarra Catholic Club and quoted the club as having $1.7 million in profit on which they did not pay any tax. This was incorrect. I received a call from Mr Harley who informed me of the correct amount and followed up the call with some hard copy. The actual profit they made without paying tax was in fact $1.2 million. I would like to correct that wrong statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) was about to propose a new tax on cats! This is a government which talks a lot about families but does very little to help them. A number of families in south‐west Sydney are suffering from the government's mishandling of the second Sydney airport issue. The proposed Holsworthy site would not only hurt people in the future; it is hurting them now.

SPEECH.PARA: Take the case of the young couple who were building their first home at Long Point in my electorate. At the time of the government's announcement about Holsworthy earlier this year—when they threw 10 years of planning right out the window—that young couple was living in a garage with their home half finished. Today, sadly enough, they are still living in a garage and their home is still half finished.

They cannot afford to take the risk of building the second half of their home as Long Point, the building site, is just a stone's throw away from the Holsworthy airport site and its proposed runways just on the other side of the Georges River. This government and its madcap decision about Holsworthy have turned that young couple's Australian dream into a nightmare. So much for a government committed to family values. So much for helping battlers.

Again, I plead with the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), for this and many other reasons, to abandon his plans for Holsworthy and give back the certainty, the security and the amenities the people of south‐west Sydney need in their lifestyles and for their families' aspirations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I happily attended a function outside my electorate involving some very prominent members of my electorate. A fundraising event of a few weeks ago resulted in several thousand dollars in cash being donated to the Mater Children's Hospital and also to the Royal Children's Hospital in Brisbane.

SPEECH.PARA: This good work was the result of members of the Queensland Chinese Forum and the Valley Business Association working together at the Mid‐Autumn Festival a few weeks ago. To Bill Qui, Jimmy Mak, Michael Choi—who is the President of the Valley Business Association—Peter Yeoh, Peter Low and so many others I take some moments in this place to offer congratulations on their efforts and also on the fact they have been directing their fundraising to causes which will benefit the broad community.

The money going to those worthwhile causes is yet more money in addition to the amounts which they have extended in the last few years—$40,000 is one estimate and others put it much higher. As Sister Angela Mary from the Mater Hospital said, it is a great pity there are some who are bagging members of the Chinese community in a generalist way and turning their back on the good works which so many people of Asian origin have done in the broad community. I think it is right for us in this place to take a moment also to reflect upon the good work of those people and to say thanks for their charitable works.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to say that I attended the Mount Druitt Festival on Saturday, which was opened by my good friend the Mayor of Blacktown, Charlie Lowles. This is probably the best festival that we have had for some time. I would like to particularly thank Mount Druitt Marketown for their cooperation, which perhaps made the difference on this occasion. I am pleased to report that my office was able to assist in the organisation and I particularly mention Cherie Bugeja from my office who did an outstanding job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are to have a debate in this country on immigration and multiculturalism let us do it with facts and not fiction, let us do it with reason and not bigotry, let us do it with what once would have been called good manners and respect for others. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) did it that way in his excellent article published in last Friday's Sydney Morning Herald and I commend him for it.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been some consequences of the bigotry. I was told by an employee of the University of South Australia last week that the $1.9 billion export earnings of Australia's education and training services industry—and it is estimated to be twice that with living expenses included—was under threat and that New Zealand was being considered instead.

Of course I have had letters and phone calls highlighting the more personal hurt. An Asian family, while shopping, had been told to go home. They have been in this country for 21 years. An elderly gentleman from north Adelaide in my electorate writes:

People of my generation used to ask themselves how the German people with all their education and intelligence could have voted for Herr Hitler. Yes I am prejudiced. I have a daughter-in‐law of Chinese race born in Malaysia, and two wonderful grandchildren aged 14 and 11.
Mr Hieu Van Le, a friend of mine in Adelaide, and others have written to the Adelaide Advertiser stating:
The overtly racist messages contained in a member of Parliament's speech to the Federal Parliament has generated a level of media coverage that, to some, may seem to bestow . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express considerable alarm at the continuing failure by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to unambiguously condemn the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) for her blatantly racist remarks which imply that people from Asia are unworthy migrants to this country. I was initially disillusioned and now I am quite alarmed at the continuing failure by the Prime Minister to unambiguously condemn those remarks. The Prime Minister had the ability by virtue of his office to motivate the entire country into condemning the unnecessary possession of guns. Clearly, if he throws the weight of his office behind a clear and concise denunciation of Ms Hanson's comments, it is likely to significantly influence Australia's opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is nonsense to say that it is not damaging Australia's reputation. Just yesterday a very prominent Thai, Senator Mechai Viravaidya, publicly denounced Ms Hanson's comments and stated that her comments have caused enormous damage to Australia's reputation in the region. We have a $721 million a year trade surplus with Thailand. That means that about $40 million per man, woman and child in this country is being risked as a result of the failure of the Prime Minister to unequivocally and unambiguously condemn Ms Hanson. This is likely to cause very real and ongoing loss. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent, Russell, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —If the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) is going to talk about putting people in garages in this country he should realise that in 1990 when interest rates were 17½ per cent his government threw thousands of people out of their homes and onto the streets or into renting. I know you have nothing to say about this, but that is the fact of the matter. The people have not forgotten that.

SPEECH.PARA: They have not forgotten that in about June last year the then member for McMillan, Mr Barry Cunningham, announced that there would be $10 million worth of funding going into the electorate of McMillan. The truth is that that funding has not been found. It was a myth. I am disappointed that the funding that we lost was out of Brian Howe's better cities program series 2 that was never signed by anybody. The money was never there. To my great disappointment, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) mentioned this in his speech in the debate on the address‐in‐reply to the budget. Other people have mentioned these funds. These funds do not exist. They were a myth of the former member for McMillan, Barry Cunningham. The money was never there, it was never spent and it never went back into consolidated revenue as he argued.

It is very important that all governments be reasonably honest with the people that they serve. The opposition, the former government, was never honest in its regional seats. They never gave people in the regional areas of Australia the opportunities that they deserve. You should all hang your heads in shame for what you have done. They reminded you in the seat of Lindsay that they have not forgotten. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the House a petition signed by 13,605 people protesting the government's proposal to build an airport at Holsworthy. Accompanying that petition are 3,848 letters signed by constituents in and near my electorate. Those letters were written, signed, stamped and mailed to me to personally deliver to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). They say, `We do not want a second airport at Holsworthy.'

SPEECH.PARA: This is an issue that transcends politics. Labor, Liberal and Democrat voters—all members of the community—in my electorate are concerned about this. Holsworthy airport was ruled out as an option in the mid‐1980s. It went from number one to number nine. It has been reintroduced as a proposal by a government which does not have the decency to tell constituents in my electorate and near my electorate that this was the proposal. It was a proposal done under the table.

The member for North Sydney, Jumbo Joe Hockey, is pushing the Holsworthy proposal. The half a million people who would be affected by an airport will not relieve the problems of any of the constituents or residents affected by Mascot. This petition is the people speaking—mainstream Australia. The proposal for a second airport at Holsworthy is a disgrace. It is a stunt by this government. It should be ruled out. There is stress and anxiety among the half a million people in my region. It is not necessary. Rule it out, Prime Minister! (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Within a couple of hundred metres of one another in my electorate are two intersections with an unacceptably high accident history. In August of last year, the former land transport minister, the member for Kingsford‐Smith, Mr Brereton, visited the area where the New England Highway meets Weakleys Drive and Thornton Road, and announced that $11 million would be spent rectifying the problems. The money was to be used to fund a number of measures, including a grade separated interchange and a road directly linking the townships of Beresfield and Thornton in order that the residents of those townships need not access the busy national highway in order to move from one town to another.

SPEECH.PARA: Members can appreciate how surprised I was when in July of this year the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) wandered uninvited into my electorate and announced that some $412,000 would be spent installing two sets of traffic lights at those very dangerous intersections. My first question is: where is the other $10.5 million? Since there already exists one set of traffic lights where Anderson Drive meets the New England Highway, we will have the ridiculous situation where we have three sets of traffic lights within about half a kilometre of one another on one of the busiest stretches of the national highway. This is a crazy situation and I impress upon the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) the need to ensure that the lights should be an interim measure only and that in the near future proper remedial measures be funded entirely. Why is this occurring? This is occurring because the federal government has cut $640 million—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In a couple of minutes we will see one Jackie Kelly come back into this chamber. I am really looking forward to seeing the faces of a number of people opposite. Several weeks ago when Jackie was asking some of the last questions before she went into the by‐election a number of people, such as the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and the member for Banks (Mr Melham), were saying things like, `See you later, Jackie. It was nice having you here.' It is going to be very nice seeing her come back. I am really looking forward to seeing the faces of those on the other side of the House.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A the time for members' statements has concluded.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received the return to the writ which the Acting Speaker issued on 16 September 1996 for the election of a member to serve for the electoral division of Lindsay in the state of New South Wales. By the endorsement on the writ it is certified that Jacqueline Marie Kelly has been elected.

INTERJECT.PARA: Miss Jacqueline Marie Kelly made and subscribed the oath of allegiance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence I would like to congratulate the newly re‐elected member for Lindsay, Jackie Kelly. In doing so on behalf of the Liberal Party I would like to thank her for a vigorous, energetic and highly successful election campaign. Can I also say how grateful I am to the people of Lindsay that they have once again placed their trust in a representative of the coalition. Can I also say how immensely proud I am of the fact that a member of the Liberal Party of Australia, my party, should be representing such a vast area of the western suburbs of Sydney.

PARA.BREAK: I wish the member well. She is a talented, energetic and wholly effective member of the electorate of Lindsay. I promise to the Aus tralian parliament that we will not take her re‐election as any signal for complacency or arrogance towards the people who have once again placed their trust in Jackie and in the Liberal Party. We will do our level best to honour that trust and to deliver high quality government to the people of the western suburbs of Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer confirm that to meet his budget employment growth forecasts for this year an average of 17,000 new jobs will have to be created in each of the next nine months, in contrast with the mere 4,500 new jobs a month that they have averaged in each of the first three months of the budget year? Against this reality how can the Treasurer stand by his budget unemployment forecast, explicitly reaffirmed by the Treasurer last Tuesday, that unemployment will fall to 8¼ per cent by June next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it entirely clear that the government does stand by its budget forecasts. It stands by those forecasts in relation to growth, in relation to employment and in relation to unemployment. Let me say that because of the government's successful budget strategy the economy and the economic prospects are coming together. Mr Speaker, you would be aware that in the last week we have seen the consumer price index fall to 2.1 per cent, right back to the levels of the 1960s and 1970s. You would be aware that in relation to AWOTE we saw very good numbers in the September quarterly figures and you would be aware that the government's budget strategy is having a marked effect on interest rates. There is one thing you could always say about the Labor Party: they could get interest rates up but they could never get them down. The Labor Party was the party that gave Australian home mortgage buyers 17 per cent interest rates when it decided to bring on the recession which—

—I take a point of order which goes to relevance. Surely, Mr Speaker, if it is relevant to talk about that he could talk about the short‐term interest rates of 23 per cent when he was in office and down to the levels they are now, brought by us.
—Order! There is no point of order. Resume your seat.

—Mr Speaker, he could not get on his feet to welcome back the member for Lindsay, could he? But he is up on his feet within seconds once he starts being reminded of his record. We always get amused when we hear the Labor Party talking about unemployment because they have a modern Australian record: 11 per cent unemployment. And who was the minister for employment? It was the present Leader of the Opposition. They bring them all back and they recycle them all back onto their front bench because the truth of the matter is that the Labor Party has no fresh talent. We see a whole group of ex‐Keating ministers sitting here on the front bench, coming back into this House via New York, trying to establish their relevance again by asking questions in relation to employment and economic growth.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say that, in relation to the economy, the prospects in the Australian economy are good prospects.
