The critical issues in ensuring that our prospects for sustainable growth over the next three to four years are maintained are to deal with Australia's problem in relation to savings, to close that deficit which was the legacy of Labor, to make sure that we close the impact that would have in relation to the current account deficit, to make sure that we set Australia up for good prospects for growth for three to four years and to make sure that this country realises the potential that it can have and will have again under good government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Now that the government has reached an historic agreement with the Democrats over ways to improve the workplace relations bill in Australia, what are the benefits to workers and small businesses once the full effects of these practical solutions flow through?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lindsay for her question. I take this opportunity to say that one of the many factors that contributed to her re-election was the persistent and frequent way she represented the interests of her constituents in question time before the by-election.

ANSWER.PARA: The agreement reached between the Australian Democrats and the government regarding the workplace relations bill is an important agreement. It is historic, and I wish to place on record my personal thanks and those of the government for the outstanding job that has been done by the Minister for Industrial Relations not only in devising the legislation and in advocating the need for the legislation but also in the patient, intelligent and persistent way which he negotiated with the Australian Democrats. Over a period of some 50 or 60 hours, these negotiations have produced a piece of legislation which, although it will contain a number of changes from that originally introduced into parliament, will nonetheless honour the five principal criteria that I laid down for acceptability of industrial relations legislation.

It will first and foremost sweep away Laurie Brereton's job destroying unfair dismissal laws. Secondly, it will entrench forever the principle of voluntary association in Australia. No longer will Australian workers have compulsory unionism rammed down their throats. Thirdly, it will provide an effective choice between an industrial award and a workplace contract. Fourthly, it will enable unionists who want to join trade unions to join the trade union of their choice. Not only are we entrenching the principle of voluntary unionism; we are entrenching the principle of choice as to the type of union the individual worker will join. Finally, it restores effective secondary boycott legislation.

So it does honour those five principles. It does contain amendments to take care of the concerns that were expressed by the Australian Democrats. On behalf of the government, I want to acknowledge the constructive contribution of the Australian Democrats towards the negotiating process. I want to acknowledge the constructive, pragmatic, intelligent way in which discussion of this legislation was addressed. The way in which the minister and the Leader of the Australian Democrats were prepared to sit down over a long period of time to negotiate away differences and to reach agreement with each holding to their principles I think reflects considerable credit on both of them. I say on behalf of the government that we certainly acknowledge the contribution that has been made by the Australian Democrats.

I think the most interesting reaction to this legislation is the extraordinarily confused reaction of the Australian Labor Party. I search in vain for a consistent thread. The only thread is the thread of the sour loser. There is no consistent thread, but I suppose the most interesting comment was made by the man from the Carnegie Institute over here, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He had this to say when he was door‐stopped this morning, `There are many ways in which the position of the trade unions has been weakened.' He went on to say, `The capacity to engage in particular kinds of industrial action has been undermined.'

If you throw out the Gareth‐speak, what he is really doing is complaining that it is going to be harder to strike. That is really what he is saying. Is that all you have to say? Don't you look at the enormous advances for individual workers under this legislation? Don't you look at the way in which this legislation will create a greater climate of cooperation at the workplace? Don't you understand that, after 13 years of the dead hand of your industrial relations system, we now have an industrial relations system that does not enshrine the role of one or other side of the industrial bargain but enshrines the objective of a more productive, a more competitive and therefore a more rewarding Australian society?

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Now that the government has been guaranteed passage of its unfair dismissal legislation, can you guarantee that small business will create more jobs in the next three years than the 500,000 it created over the last three years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I can guarantee that this bill is tremendous for small business. We gave a commitment that this government would be pro small business, and with that package we have delivered on that promise. What an incredible cheek for the opposition to be asking us about the implications of our bill when one of the good things in our bill is that we scrapped the Laurie Brereton unfair dismissal law, which has been such a disaster for small business. In short, the fact of the matter is that this bill is benign for jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me amplify upon that, Mr Speaker, to show you the hypocrisy of the opposition when it comes to talking to us about jobs. The shadow minister, through his representative in the Senate, in the next couple of days will be moving an amendment against the package which would see the abolition of junior wage rates next year. Do not talk to us about jobs when your policy holds a sword of Damocles over the jobs of 220,000 young people. That is not just the government talking about the implications of our bill for junior wage rates. Talking about divisions within their ranks, this morning on radio the Labor Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr, said this:
We have got to be alive to the argument that forcing up youth rates can contribute to youth unemployment.

I am very conscious of the fact that any thrust in youth rates will see employers simply opt not to employ young people and again, I think that state and federal governments can work together on that front.

I say to Premier Carr: we are prepared to work with you on that front because youth unemployment is a major problem. It is a problem we have inherited from Labor and we are determined to produce the remedies that will give young people a chance of a job denied them by you when you were in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Kingston.
—Supplementary question, Mr Speaker.
—I have called the honourable member for Kingston.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House of recent action by lenders in relation to variable home interest rates? What factors have led to these positive rate movements and what are the benefits for Australian home buyers and the holders of variable rate home loans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kingston for her question. I know that she, representing the electorate that she does, is concerned about home buyers who had to experience the interest rate increases of late 1994 under the Labor administration.

ANSWER.PARA: When this government came to office, the variable mortgage rate was 10.5 per cent. It is now 9.25 per cent. In an attempt to narrow differential with mortgage managers, the major trading banks first reduced their variable mortgage rate from 10.5 to 9.75 per cent; and in July of this year the Reserve Bank of Australia cut the official cash rate by 0.5 percentage points, with the banks following in August, taking mortgage loans down to 9.25 per cent.

For a person on an average mortgage of $100,000, the 1.25 percentage point reduction in the variable interest rate represents a saving of $104 a month. For someone on adult average weekly earnings, this is equivalent to an increase in before tax income of $160 a month. The variable mortgage rate is paid in after tax income. There is no better benefit that home buyers can be given than a reduction in their mortgage interest rates. That 1.25 percentage point reduction in the variable rate since June and July illustrates for somebody on average weekly earnings $160 a month pre‐tax.

Last week, Aussie Home Loans announced that its variable home loan interest rate would be reduced from 8.65 per cent to 7.99 per cent. FAI announced a reduction in its rates from 8.45 per cent to 7.95 per cent. This illustrates the benefits to the community of competition. This illustrates that new players enter the market aggressively seeking competition. With lower costs, they do have the ability to deliver direct benefits to consumers.

BREAK.PARA: Westpac announced, in response, a reduction in its first option home loan from 8.4 per cent to 7.89 per cent last week. That indicates that competition in the home loan market does have the capacity to lower margins in relation to mortgages and give real benefits to consumers. This is consistent with the government's aim of producing a low inflation economy. This is an aim that is backed up by a responsible fiscal policy. This is an aim that is backed up by movements in relation to wages.

In recent times, we have seen some unions threatening to pursue unsustainable wage increases. Let me make it clear that, in a low inflation environment, wages do not have to chase prices. If prices are under control, wage outcomes can be moderated accordingly. Moderate wage outcomes, low price increases and lower interest rates are all consistent with a sustainable growth economy in which opportunities and certainty for business investment can be created and benefits can be delivered to consumers.

We indicated during the election campaign that we were committed to Australian families. Delivering reductions in mortgage interest rates is part of this government's commitment to Australian families, part of the benefits that will come through to them through a responsible economic program.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard what the Treasurer has had to say on the subject of variable mortgage rates, but what has he got to say on the subject of bank credit card interest rates, which have remained absolutely unchanged since June last year at an average 16.7 per cent? While you have been noisily calling on the banks to do what they were going to do anyway in respect of mortgage rates, why haven't you had anything at all to say about the outrageously high credit card rates that the banks continue to charge? Will you now call on the banks to drop them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are getting used to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition standing up and reading out speeches. But today has been rather a vintage day for him, stung into action by Glenn Milne's story in the Australian today about how not only the warlords of the Victorian ALP are stacking out his electorate but his frontbench is now starting to murmur about the performance of the member for Hotham. You cannot move anywhere in Melbourne without someone walking up to you and telling you about the member for Hotham's campaign for the deputy leadership.
—Is that the briefing?

—No, it isn't the briefing. It is a letter I got from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition complaining about the closure of the tax office in Dandenong Road. It was 11 July 1996. I thought you might be interested in it because it had a very unusual signature down the bottom. It said, `Yours sincerely, Gareth Evans (dictated by Gareth Evans from New York and signed in his absence.)' I said earlier: his body may be in Rockefeller Plaza, but his heart is always in Dandenong Road. I will table the letter. In fact, it had an error, because he sent me one after it, saying—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am not sure what possible relevance this has got to the question, but if it has relevance he might tell us whether or not Greenspan has lost his address.
—Order! There is no point of order. Given the complex nature of the question asked of the Treasurer, he is drawing on all of the resources at his command to address the question.
—You do humour our days, don't you? He wrote on 22 July 1996 saying:

ANSWER.PARA: I have just seen the hard copy of my letter to you of 11 July. You will have noted that it was wrong. It contains a typographical error.
This letter was dictated and signed in Dandenong. I will table that one.

Let me make it entirely clear that the government has a strategy in place to reduce interest rates. That strategy is a low inflation environment. The first thing to make clear about a low inflation environment is that we entered into an agreement with the Reserve Bank which not only secured its independence but made it clear how monetary policy would be conducted in this country. We have already seen, in relation to the differential between the 10‐year US bond and the 10‐year Australian bond, a decline of 130 basis points since we were elected; in fact, last week it was below 100 basis points.

You will recall that, when we entered into that agreement with the Reserve Bank, the Labor Party, stung into action by Paul Keating, threatened to sue us over it. You were going to sue us. Remember? You were going to take us to the High Court over the agreement we entered into with the Reserve Bank. Every day I say to my adviser, `Has the writ arrived yet?' The writ has never been actually issued because there was nothing illegal about that agreement, except to entrench low inflation—something that you were against when this government entered into the monetary agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you go and uphold the act?

—I am still waiting for the writ. Why don't you bring the writ around some time rather than making all these threats? In relation to fiscal policy, it was this government that took your $10 billion deficit and laid out a program to balance the accounts, and you are opposing every single measure—some $18 billion over four years. What do you think that would do to interest rates? Where do you think these policy responses come from? You are an opposition that has opposed every move to take the pressure off interest rates. You have no credibility in relation to that whatsoever. We have put in place a competitive regime. We are getting the benefits through competition. We are getting the benefits through low inflation. We are getting the benefits in relation to fiscal policy. Here is an opposition which is opposing all of those measures. Mr Speaker, as I said before, all of their policy prescriptions add up to one thing: higher interest rates. The Labor Party was the master of high interest rates. They could get them up; they could never get them down.

—I seek leave to table the extract from the Reserve Bank bulletin, which shows no movement on credit card interest rates while every other relevant interest rate has been dropping in recent months. Why won't the Treasurer do something about it?

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Industrial relations policy is important to the wellbeing of my regional seat of McMillan. Have the changes to the coalition's industrial relations package, agreed with the Democrats, met the thrust of the coalition's election commitments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge his interest in workplace relations policy. I am very pleased to be able to say to the House that, on any fair appraisal of what we have done, the government has been able to secure passage of the legislation, which means that we have kept faith with the Australian people on the basis of the undertakings and the commitments that we took to the election on 2 March.

ANSWER.PARA: To echo the remarks of the Prime Minister, we have been able to do so because we have had a very constructive process with the Australian Democrats in looking at the government's proposals. It has been a very extensive process, with something in the order of 60 hours of discussions. From my perspective, one of the good things about the discussions is that, all through the process, Senator Kernot and Senator Murray have been prepared to say, `Give us an explanation of the reasons for what you are proposing.' They have allowed us to explain what we are doing. Furthermore, where they have had concerns, they have responded to us by saying, `If you have got a worry, can you tell us exactly what the worry is so that we can address it?' That has meant that, in the package which we have now come to, there are 171 amendments. All through that process we have attempted to address the concerns and, at the same time, maintain the integrity and the thrust of the proposals that we originally put.

If you look at some of the matters which the Prime Minister has spoken about, he did make a number of commitments in recent times as to what we thought were core elements. In addition to those was our commitment that people would not be worse off as a result and that people would not be disadvantaged by the processes. We have secured a fair no disadvantage test and also a flexible one which I think gives substance to that undertaking. We have, of course, gone further and also met the other matters he raised. It is great that we can scrap Laurie Brereton's unfair dismissal scheme. If employees do have a problem with unfair dismissal, we have a scheme which is fair to employees as well as to employers. With respect to Australian workplace agreements, I think we now genuinely have a user friendly system that is going to be practical, whether you are running a small business or a big business or whether you are an employee. Those agreements can be collective or individual. The good thing is that, if you are not in a union and you do not want a union to be involved in your agreement, you will not have a union foisted upon you telling you what you can and cannot do. Of course, that is provided that that agreement meets a fair set of minimum conditions by way of the no disadvantage test.

We also said that it was a key point of our bill that the freedom of association provisions would be retained. I am very pleased to be able to say to the House that the law as it will now be passed will abolish compulsory unionism. That is important for its practical benefits to people, but it is also important as a basic civil liberty.

The Prime Minister is also on the record as saying it is important that if people want to form an enterprise union they should have the capacity to do so. With the replacement of the `conveniently belong' rule and the changes we have made, we can genuinely say to people, provided there are 50 to form the minimum number for that union, that the way is clear for enterprise unions to really take off in Australia, as employees so decide that it is in their interests to do so.

Another matter which has had a lot of public prominence, not just in Australia but internationally, has been the question of the reinstatement of sections 45D and E. In this area, the public position of the opposition parties is that there should be provisions against secondary boycotts, but when they changed the secondary boycott provisions they made them ineffective. So we have not had in this country a debate on whether or not we should have provisions against secondary boycotts; rather, we have had a more subtle debate as to whether they should be effective.

The existing Labor provisions put in by Mr Brereton are clearly ineffective and that is why it was very important that we reinstate 45D and E into the Trade Practices Act. We have responded to the concerns of the Democrats about consumer and environmental groups. We are therefore proposing to exempt consumer and environmental boycotts from the trade practices provisions but—and this is a very important `but'—not where industrial action is involved.

I think on any fair assessment the policy that we took to the election has been delivered. We have done it in a way which has fairly recognised the concerns raised with us by the Democrats. With regard to some other issues, for example, the member for Kingston raised with me the question of the equal pay provisions. We have made that change to revert to the existing status quo, with some very minor modification. So we have recognised concerns and we have taken and accommodated issues that have been raised with us. For the benefit of this country, we now have a fair bill, a bill which will provide significant change and ultimately meet the title of our policy, which was better pay for better work.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I believe, along with millions of other Australians, that as the leader of Australia your first and main obligation is to the people of Australia. Would you consider reducing our foreign aid, which runs at approximately $1.5 billion a year, to create a civil national service for our youth, to enable them and others to gain employment, as well as personal and social gains, through the building of roads, bridges, railway lines, reafforestation and water conservation systems, to name a few national projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I say in answer to the honourable member for Oxley that I think the current level of foreign aid by Australia is appropriate. I think this is an important question and I think the honourable member is entitled, like any other honourable member, to ask questions in this parliament, and I will endeavour to answer it as comprehensively as I can. I think the present level of foreign aid is right, both in terms of Australia's national interest and in terms of the humanitarian obligations which this country has, as a relatively wealthy country amongst the nations of the world.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to national service, I have always taken the view, and my party has long taken the view, that it would be appropriate to reintroduce national service in this country of a military kind if there were such a military threat or a change in Australia's strategic circumstances as would warrant its introduction. I have never believed that it is appropriate to use the armed forces of Australia for purposes other than the defence of Australia or as an aid to the civilian power. That is a longstanding principle which I think has been followed by both sides of parliament.

I understand why, in times of difficulty—in particular, in areas of economic and social difficulty in Australia—some Australians would look suspiciously upon the provision of foreign aid. The other side of the coin is that there are many countries that receive foreign aid from Australia whose living standards are absolutely appalling by any measure. There are other countries whose relations with Australia are important and therefore the provision of foreign aid to those countries not only carries a humanitarian component but also is in Australia's national interest.

It is equally true that on occasions Australians legitimately feel that foreign aid is sometimes not as effectively used as it might be. I can understand the anger in that. I can understand the anger of Australians who give money voluntarily to great organisations like World Vision and so forth, seeing the political perfidy of regimes in different parts of the world which allows that aid to be literally wasted on the wharves, airports and railway sidings of countries whose citizens are suffering appalling deprivation.

So I would say to the honourable member for Oxley and, through her, to those of her constituents and, indeed, the constituents of any other honourable member who feels that somehow or other foreign aid is being wasted, that I think in the long run that is a short‐sighted, mistaken view. I do think that this country has some moral obligations. There is also a national interest for Australia involved in the provision of foreign aid. Who could argue that the economic, social and strategic stability of Papua New Guinea is other than of immense significance to Australia? Who could argue that the stability of many other countries around the world which may receive assistance from Australia is not important?

I think the honourable member's question does place an obligation on governments and all political parties to make absolutely certain that foreign aid is directed in the most efficient manner, that there is political pressure applied to those countries that have intolerable regimes, who use starvation and the wasting of civilian populations as a method of achieving ends. The shameful record of regimes in Africa on this stands as an absolute blot upon the performance of governments around the world. We should never be reluctant to condemn that sort of behaviour.

I can understand the feelings of Australians who think that their taxes are wasted in relation to aid to those countries. But the answer is not to turn our back on foreign aid; the answer is to try to get a more effective aid delivery system and an aid delivery system that returns optimum benefits to the Australian people while discharging our humanitarian obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Fairfax, I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory, the Chief Minister and Deputy Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and the Head of Government of Norfolk Island. On behalf of the House, I extend to you all a very warm welcome.
— Hear, hear!

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the minister aware of reactions to the announcement yesterday of the agreement between the government and the Australian Democrats on the coalition's IR package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Fairfax for his question and for his interest in the subject matter as well. There has been a very positive reaction to the agreement which was announced yesterday. The principal employer organisation, the ACCI, has issued a statement welcoming the changes. We have had support from the National Farmers Federation welcoming the changes. The Farmers Federation said that it believes that the reforms in the workplace relations bill will make a significant contribution to improved performance in a number of key sectors, including meat processing and the waterfront, and will ultimately generate increased employment.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been a large number of editorials on the subject, by and large favourable—not in every case, but by and large reasonably favourable. The Financial Review says:

Overall, however, Mr Reith is right when he says the Government has retained the integrity, the direction and the thrust of the bill. And the fact that this much has been achieved is to be applauded . . .
We also had in the editorial of the Daily Telegraph the comment that the government:
. . . has secured a major advance in the government's program to reshape the economy.

The coalition pledge to reform the industrial relations landscape and, in particular, the unworkable unfair dismissal laws that have contributed to a paralysis in small business, is a policy the nation has waited too long to see enacted.
We have had semi-supportive comments even from Robert Fitzgerald of ACOSS. We appreciate the support that has been voiced in the last 24 hours on these changes.

What is interesting, I suppose from the point of view of historical curiosity more than anything else, is the reaction that we have had from the labour movement in the last few days. It is a bit hard on some occasions to work out which is the organ grinder and which is the monkey. It seems that the ACTU's stance on the government's package has been an evolving one. Members might remember that before the election on 2 March the prospect was of world war 3—

TALK.START.PARA: —Bill Kelty.

—Bill Kelty declared war, and then we had a minor skirmish of a riotous nature outside Parliament House. Then I was down in the old Parliament House—I suppose we are lucky they did not tear down the doors of that building too—a week ago with Mr Kelty. I heard him say that he had been around for a long time and he had seen these ministers all come and go, each with their little packages. In other words, this was just another package, basically irrelevant to the union movement and therefore something to be put aside. That line was repeated by Jennie George, when she claimed that the amendments agreed with the Democrats had neutered the bill. She basically took the credit for it, which was pretty incredible.

ANSWER.PARA: So the union position is half-smart, semi-sophisticated—forget the system, ignore the law and remember only this: there will always be a union. Doubtless those union delegates in Melbourne today, who would be preening themselves on the 45 per cent group travel discount they got from Ansett to come across from Perth, will take this message back to their headquarters.

What has also been interesting is the other part of the duo. It seems that the position of the political arm of the labour movement has been evolving as well. Nowhere has the evolution of the ALP's position, slowly adapting itself to the position of permanent opposition, been more interesting than in the case of industrial relations. The shadow minister's initial response to the media was to announce that there was a major problem with the agreement but that he would get back to them after he had worked out what it was. I was not surprised at this because the shadow minister announced that it was a tawdry little agreement. The interesting thing is that he declared it at 2.30, before the agreement had even been released. I know we all had trouble with daylight saving yesterday, but to be literally hours off the pace is even more than your usual effort. We wait with bated breath to see what the shadow minister might have to say.

The interesting thing, seriously, is that the evolution of the political wing of the Labor Party since 2 March is not to hang on to the policy position they had on 2 March but to regress back through the 1990s, back through the 1980s, back into the 1970s. I will give the House one example to finish. The Labor Party in government, recognising the problem we might have with junior wage rates, proposed and implemented an extension of the exemption. Yet when they are in opposition the good sense of their earlier move is now beyond them. They are oppositionist for the sake of being in opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to one of the election commitments you did not mention, which is that no worker would be worse off in terms of take home pay. I give the House just one of many examples—a third year apprentice under the textile industry award who currently earns a minimum weekly wage of $361.80. Isn't it the case that even after your deal with the Democrats the approving authority can accept an Australian workplace agreement whereby that apprentice might be paid only 75 per cent of that take home pay, that is, $271.35 per week, and even that is above your miserable top-up rate that Minister Kemp agreed with Senator Kernot? Won't new apprentices under that award, therefore, be up to $90.45 worse off each week in terms of their take home pay? Isn't it a fact that this circumstance is not covered by the amendments or Minister Kemp's letter to Senator Kernot? Why won't you amend the workplace relations bill to ensure that apprentices cannot be worse off?

—This really is a sad and pathetic question from the shadow minister. We have given you briefing after briefing and you still do not understand what is going on. Let me remind the shadow minister that back in May when we introduced our bill we had a discussion on television in which he said that he accepted the principles behind what we were doing because they reflected exactly the same principles that were adopted when he was in government. Instead of attempting to run this shallow, baseless, scaremongering campaign, why don't you just for once take a responsible attitude to the circumstances of young people so that they can enjoy the benefits of the apprenticeship training scheme being introduced by my colleague which will give them the chance of a job denied to them by you for 13 years.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr Speaker.
—I hope it is not as long as the last one.
—Thank you for your help, Mr Speaker. My supplementary question is: will they be $90.45 a week worse off or not?
—The question is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me spell it out again for the shadow minister. It is as simple as this: the principle we have adopted is that where you are employed under an existing award then the award will provide the basis for your remuneration. Surely you don't argue about that. That was the situation you had when you were in government which you supported. You surely are not opposing that basic proposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The change we have made is that, where the parties adopt for their benefit a more flexible arrangement—basically varying the ratio of hours worked and hours in training—and where they have entered into an agreement which does vary that ratio, the principle underpinning the determination of the remuneration is that they will be paid for the hours they work. That is the principle which the ACTU has supported, which the previous government supported and which we have supported and implemented in this package. That is the full and comprehensive answer to your question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the changes to the coalition's industrial relations package still have the effect of overturning the so-called Brereton unfair dismissal laws, which have cost jobs and made employers wary of engaging new employees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Hughes for her question. We are scrapping Laurie Brereton's unfair dismissal law. Goodbye, Laurie! In the small business community, whether you are an employer or employee, people from one end of the country to another will be applauding the end of your system, Laurie. No-one now has the record you have, Laurie. You created a solution for a problem that did not exist and gave us a bigger problem than that which we had to start with.

ANSWER.PARA: The provisions did arouse enormous community hostility and they certainly cost a lot of Australians their jobs and job opportunities. They bogged down a lot of businesses in very costly legal disputes. The provisions, essentially, as history records, were the result of a failed attempt to use constitutional heads of power as a political tool for overriding traditional state unfair dismissal jurisdictions.

The first and most important feature of the new system is that it will be based on the principle of a fair go all round. That principle is a tried and tested principle. It has been in operation, for example, in New South Wales for some time now. We know it is a fair system, that it works reasonably and that it works in the interests of both employers and employees. Again, I must say I find it absolutely amazing that the Labor opposition is still opposed to fixing up the unfair dismissal laws in a reasonable way.

The new system also incorporates a filing fee to be lodged with an application. We are proposing a $50 filing fee. I think that is fair and reasonable. We also have a provision which will allow for the payment of costs where there is found to be by the Industrial Relations Commission a vexatious application. During that process, parties will be properly informed of the position so that they are not in any way ill informed about the processes and the consequences of taking any particular action.

The other change that we made—this certainly came up in the agreement—was to require all of these applications to start in the Industrial Relations Commission. I think that is a sensible change that we made during the process of discussions. The reason that I think it is sensible to have it in the Industrial Relations Commission is that the commission is dealing with the commercial realities of business on a day-to-day basis. It does have a feeling for the way in which workplaces are organised and what is a fair thing within a business when it comes to an unfair dismissal. This is a far better scheme. It is the scheme that should have been introduced originally. It is to the undying shame of the Labor Party that they let Laurie Brereton into unfair dismissals.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. Can he explain why the principals of DDB Needham Adelaide, Mr Toby Ralph and Mr John King, were in his Canberra suite of offices on 29 August at a sensitive point in the tendering process of the gun control advertising campaign? During their visit, were they advised of the findings by Elliott and Shanahan as to how their campaign proposal faired in qualitative research testing? Finally, did the Attorney-General's office subsequently provide officers of his department with the contact phone number for Mr Ralph and Mr King, that number being Canberra 273 2564?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been engaged for some considerable time on a bipartisan venture that will see some safer gun laws applicable across Australia. On a bipartisan basis we agreed that there would be an education campaign conducted. The Labor Party has sought to find something of a political fix in a situation where no such fix exists. The committee that was set up to engage advertising and public relations consultants sought to do the best job it could do. It had on the committee the best people to do the job.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of all the details of contact between my office or my department or the Department of Administrative Services with individual candidates. There were quite a number of them, and there was a lot of contact. I am not in a position to answer that sort of question. But I suspect that what you are trying to point to at the bottom of it just is not there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask the minister as a supplementary question: will he check the records of his office on the basis of the questions that I just asked him to ascertain whether or not that is true?
—That is outside the guidelines for supplementary questions. The question is not in order.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. What benefit will the changes to the government's workplace relations package have for the young people of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to say to the member that the bill is very positive for young people in his electorate as it is for young people all around the country. We have obviously been addressing the question of junior wage rates. Just to put it in the most practical terms, if we had had the abolition of junior wage rates in the middle of next year under Labor's scheme, a 16-year-old would have had their wage doubled. That is Labor's position. That is what they think ought to happen. Our view is that, if you double the wage of a 16-year-old, the chances are they will lose their job—a rather simple point that seems to have escaped the Leader of the Opposition and his party.
—Bob Carr agrees.
—Yes, we agree with Bob Carr.
—On this.
—On this matter only. What we have done is that junior wage rates will be exempted from the anti age discrimination requirements of the act for a further three years from 22 June 1997.

ANSWER.PARA: But we have not just left it there, acknowledging the concerns that the Democrats have had about this issue. We have agreed that the full bench of the Industrial Relations Commission will, within a couple of years, report on the feasibility of the replacement of junior wage rates with non-discriminatory alternatives. The full bench is to be convened by the president of the commission. It is to report not later than one year before the expiry of the exemption; so that is within two years.

The report is to include assessments of whether it is desirable to replace junior rates with non-discriminatory alternatives; the consequences for youth employment of an abolition of junior rates; and the utility of junior rates for different types of employment for different industries and in the school‐to‐work transition. The act will also empower the commission to extend the exemption on an award-by-award basis in accordance with the guidelines that are established by the full bench of the commission convened by the president. That is a fair response to our concerns. So we have the exemption continued on for three years. Beyond the three years, we have a process which would allow that exemption to be granted basically on an award-by-award basis. We will have a much more considered and measured appreciation and analysis of the issue in the meantime. I dare say it is a debate that we will return to.

What I do think, though, is that the Labor Party ought to be reconsidering its position on this. It is not right that, whilst we have youth unemployment at the very high levels it is, a major political party in this country should still be proposing, as they intend to in the Senate in the next few days, that junior wage rates be abolished. If that were successful—fortunately, it will not be—220,000 young people's jobs would otherwise be at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is further to the previous question that I asked, and again it is to the Attorney-General. All of us, by way of preamble since he put it in, have been extraordinarily supportive on a bipartisan basis of the gun control initiatives that he has been involved with. This question does not go to those initiatives; it goes to the way in which the tender process has been conducted. Can the Attorney‐General explain why, on 29 August, staff at DDB Needham Adelaide advised government officials to ring his office if they wanted to speak to the firm's principals, Toby Ralph and John King, to tell them why they had been short‐listed for the gun control advertising contract on the say of the Prime Minister's chief political adviser? During their visit to your office, were they advised of the findings by Elliott and Shanahan as to how their campaign proposal fared in qualitative research testing? Finally, did your office subsequently provide officers of your department with a contact phone number for Mr Ralph and Mr King, that phone number being Canberra 273 2564. Mr Attorney-General, if you do not know the answer to that question, will you find out from your office and give an answer to the parliament?

—Mr Speaker, let me just supplement the previous answer I gave, because it is basically the same question. We have now collected 121,000 firearms. The Commonwealth has provided over $60 million. Firearms owners have received nearly $60 million in compensation. As I explained, I am not privy to every conversation that went on in a lengthy process. But the inference you are seeking to draw that there was a political fix in relation to the letting of those contracts is just wrong.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Have the announced changes to the coalition's industrial relations package secured the government's pre-election undertaking to reinstate sections 45D and 45E into the Trade Practices Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member also for his question. This is a very significant issue. As I said in an earlier answer, it is not really a debate about whether or not we should have provisions against secondary boycotts but whether or not they should be effective. They clearly have not been. We had sections 45D and 45E in the Trade Practices Act at the initiative of the now Prime Minister. In those years leading to Labor's repeal of those provisions, we did actually have one effective remedy; and that was 45D and 45E. For that reason, we are very keen to get those provisions back.

ANSWER.PARA: We were happy to meet the concerns of the Democrats in respect of consumer and environmental protection. It was never our intention to have those groups caught up in an essentially industrial issue. For that reason, they were then happy to ensure that the exemption was qualified so that it was not inclusive of where industrial action is involved.

We also have section 45DB back in the Trade Practices Act. Not many members will remember—some may—that that provision was actually introduced in regard to the live sheep trade back in the 1970s. We were keen to see that measure—which essentially relates to primary boycotts—return because, I suppose, it reflects our belief that some of these boycotts are inimical to the achievement of an internationally competitive economy.

The changes to the enforcement and remedies provisions will, I think, promote the more effective settlement of boycott disputes by recognising the role of conciliation in industrial tribunals and ensuring the court has regard to that role when exercising its jurisdiction, which is in conformity with the practice of the courts, as I understand it.

There is a lot of focus in the public debate about the changes announced yesterday, but the full picture includes a look at the original bill to see those measures which have not been changed and which are retained in the legislation. The bill also retains a range of other measures designed to provide more effective remedies for unlawful industrial action, some of which will be strengthened by the package announced recently. For example, the commission will be required to deal as quickly as practicable with an application for an order to stop or prevent unlawful industrial action.

The more general point I would make is that the level of industrial action in Australia compared with most of our competitors is in fact far too high. For years the Australian community was told by the previous Labor government that the number of disputes was coming down, as if that in itself was a good thing. Obviously the level of industrial disputes falling over some time from the early 1980s to the beginning of the 1990s in itself was positive. But that is not the full story. We really need to look at what happened in the last year or so.

BREAK.PARA: The fact is that the number of industrial disputes in the last period of the previous Labor government increased by 50 per cent. But even more damning is the fact that the level of industrial disputes in Australia compared with our international competitors is very high indeed. The last time I saw the figures in the UK, for example, the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees was about 14, but in Australia today the number is closer to 70, 80, 90 or 100. So honourable members can see that the level of disputation in Australia is very high, and that is why it is important that we have a much clearer definition of the circumstances in which people can take protected action, and a clearer definition, therefore, of the consequences for those who are taking action outside of that clearly defined regime.

The other side of the coin is that, by vastly improving the agreement making processes, we are also giving people an incentive to undertake better bargaining. That is an essential ingredient for more harmonious, cooperative attitudes to work. If we can get more harmonious attitudes to work, not only do we get the number of disputes down but, on the other side of the coin literally, we get better productivity, more jobs and higher living standards through higher wages. And that, Mr Speaker, is our objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney‐General. Is the Attorney aware that well‐known Liberal Party campaigner Mr Jonathon Gaul wrote to a large number of businesses following the 1996 federal election suggesting he could be an invaluable lobbyist for them because of his close relationship with senior members of the Howard government and the federal Liberal Party? Did the Attorney take this into account when he and his office intervened to expand the public relations short list for the gun control education campaign from two firms to three in order to include Burson‐Marsteller, a firm being represented by Mr Gaul? Finally, was the Attorney aware at that time that Mr Mark Textor, a Liberal Party push poller, was doing research for Burson‐Marsteller?
—Order! The Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice will address the first part of the question only. He can ignore the push polling comment. I rule that out of order.

—The simple answer is no. If I am to answer the first question, I was not aware. I have explained before in relation to DDB Needham that I was not aware of any involvement they had with working for the Liberal Party at all. I was not aware.
—This is a different one.

—This is a different one, yes. The circumstances in relation to the finalisation of the public relations short list were entirely different to the way the member for Wills assumes. There was a question as to whether one of the candidates proposed to be short‐listed actually conformed with what was required. On that basis it was decided to add a third firm to the short list.
—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. Could you please advise the House on the basis of which standing order you ruled out the entire second part of the question?
—You have no point of order.
—You have no answer.
—I have the answers. I have ruled, and I now call the honourable member for Macquarie.

—My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. Will the government's decision to end Labor's unfair dismissal laws have a positive impact on Australia's trading circumstances? What will be the benefits of that for regional and rural Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I thank the member for Macquarie for his question. I must say it is not only the exporters in the Macquarie electorate but those right across Australia who will benefit from the excellent outcome achieved by the Minister for Industrial Relations. I congratulate the Minister for Industrial Relations for putting together this agreement with the Commonwealth govern ment and the Australian Democrats which will facilitate the passage of this key legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: I particularly refer to several key points. Sections 45D and 45E on secondary boycotts, which are extremely important, have been covered by the Minister for Industrial Relations. There is also section 45DB—boycotts affecting trade or commerce. I am pleased to say there are provisions involving the movement of goods affecting overseas trade and commerce in that regard, so we can quite properly and accurately continue to promote Australian exporters as reliable exporters, and there are proper arrangements in the industrial relations legislation with regard not only to secondary boycotts under 45D and E but also to 45DB on the matter of primary exports.

I also contend and submit to the House that much greater flexibility will flow from the agreement between the Commonwealth and the Democrats on the workplace relations bill. The authorised workplace agreements will be a whole lot better than the fixed award structure with all its complexity and convolution whereby in Collins Street, Melbourne and various other capital cities the industrial relations club laid down a very formal, ritualistic approach a long way removed from reality, more often than not, on what was actually happening in the workplace in rural and regional Australia.

This legislation is an enormous breakthrough for providing greater flexibility and, as a consequence, generating greater exports. As the Prime Minister says, the abolition of Labor's unfair dismissal law is long overdue for building confidence with employers on a fair basis to go out and create the additional jobs in small business, whether they are in Springwood, Victoria or beyond, Manilla near Tamworth or Carnegie in Melbourne.

I am reminded of the last two places because I notice the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has returned from his latest trip overseas. Glenn Milne was quite correct this day but, in fact, Glenn Milne did not quite go far enough because the quiet fury of your front bench at your trip in the immediate week after the budget was even more so than at your trip to Washington for the Carnegie Institute, when you went off to Manila in the Philippines, which is a long way from Manilla near Tamworth, and vacated your responsibilities as shadow minister and as shadow Treasurer. Your time is up.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney‐General, who might be contemplating his time at the moment. Since his answer on 10 October on the gun control advertising issue, has the Attorney‐General sought to establish once and for all with his staff member, Ms Melanie Granger, whether she did in fact say during the ministerial committee meeting, `Daryl prefers DDB'? Further, has the Attorney‐General taken steps to reconcile the statement of the ACT police minister that there was no dissent about the decision with the action of the New South Wales police minister in walking out of the meeting in disgust and the Prime Minister's assertion that at least two former Liberal Party state directors voted against DDB Needham? Attorney, in order to resolve these issues and inconsistencies, will you now table the minutes of the ministerial committee meeting? While you are about it, will you also table the advice you were sent by your department on the quality of the submissions prior to that meeting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have clarified the arrangements. I explained on 10 October exactly what occurred.
—Did she say it or not?

—There are various versions floating about in the ether as to what was actually said. I can tell you precisely what the arrangement was with her—and she carried it out. I did not express a preference. I expressly explained to her I was not in a position to express a preference for any of the firms that were presenting on that night.

ANSWER.PARA: You mentioned Paul Whelan, the police minister for New South Wales, a member of the Labor government of New South Wales. He was involved in all the presentation. Except he ran out of time. He had had a busy day and he decided to leave before things got finalised. He did not go out in disgust. He left because he ran out of time. He wanted to catch his charter plane back to Sydney. You keep trying to find smoke. You cannot find smoke, much less fire. There is nothing in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you table the advice?
—Did she say it?
—No.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister inform the House of action being taken to ensure that Australian food is clean and safe, particularly given rising community concern on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The incidence of food poisoning is actually rising worldwide. The recent epidemic of haemolytic uraemic syndrome in Japan where 9,000 people were affected is a fairly timely reminder of both the social and economic devastation that can result from food‐borne disease. Australia, of course, is not immune. We had the Garibaldi incident last year and this year the recall of peanut butter due to salmonella poisoning. I think there is cause for concern but there is certainly no cause whatsoever for panic. It should be remembered these represent a very tiny fraction of the total volume of foodstuffs.

ANSWER.PARA: There are three things under way that will help in this area. The first is, surprisingly, Australia has no national data on food‐borne illness. We can extrapolate from US data and, if you do that on a per capita basis, it could be suggested that 630 people die each year as a result of food poisoning. But, clearly, we need our own data. Discussions are under way with the Australia‐New Zealand Food Authority to establish a national database on the incidence of food‐borne disease. The Australia‐New Zealand Food Authority and the Australia‐New Zealand Food Council actually have a scheduled meeting tomorrow and this is one of the items that they hope to progress there.

The second area where there is progress is the Commonwealth‐state‐territory health ministers have asked the Australia‐New Zealand Food Authority to develop national uniform food hygiene regulations. We have a mishmash of regulations around Australia. They take a very proscriptive approach. International evidence has shown this is not the most effective. The most effective is a risk based approach.

The Australia‐New Zealand Food Authority currently has new proposals out for consultation. The first round of consultations finishes on 13 December. They will then be refined, they will go out for consultation again and we hope the final round of consultations will finish very early in 1997.

The third thing that is happening is we are looking at reforming food hygiene regulations in two areas. The first is a new food hygiene standard. What we are trying to do with the food hygiene standard is to integrate what the Commonwealth does with initiatives at a state and territory level. That gives us some prospect of having a paddock to plate approach. The meat industry has already agreed to do this and we will start it from January 1997. Secondly, we are looking at changes to state and territory legislation to provide some cohesive legal framework to back that up.

The food industry is one of Australia's largest manufacturing sectors. There is a great deal of excitement about its potential for export, particularly in Asia. The main emphasis of this push has been a clean and green approach. It is important that we have our own act together as far as food standards go. I can assure the honourable member that state, territory and Commonwealth health ministers take this very seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Attorney‐General. Attorney, why did the Prime Minister's Chief Political Adviser, Mr Grahame Morris, advise OGIA officials that the ministerial committee had `a wider view of the target audience' than that which the government had asked the contending agencies to address and also advise OGIA that losing agencies should be told that the Liberal Party's advertising team were to be awarded the $3 million gun control advertising contract because they offered the `best fit' with Burson‐Marsteller, the firm awarded the PR contract? Why did the government not tell all firms that the selection criteria had been changed before they made their final pitch to the ministerial committee? Didn't the published selection criteria specify the `primary audience' as gun owners, and wasn't the public relations firm meant to be selected after the advertising contract had been decided because it was to be a `complementary activity'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot answer all questions that relate to what other people have done but let me make one thing clear. Those two contracts, the advertising contract and the public relations contract, were meant to be complementary. The two agencies are meant to design and implement one campaign. When the short list was worked out and the presentations were organised they presented before the ministerial committee on the same night. I was not actually there. As you are well aware, I was represented by an adviser. On that committee were people well versed in running campaigns and on that committee were a representative of the New South Wales state government and a representative of the ACT government.

ANSWER.PARA: The assertions you are seeking to make are just unfounded. The ultimate decision was to take the best advertising and the best public relations consultant to do the best complementary campaign, and I believe that was what occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, what were the key achievements of a recent visit to Jakarta by six cabinet ministers? Has the visit further enhanced the reputation of our country among its regional neighbours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Wakefied for his question and recognise the enthusiasm the honourable member has for the government's policy of engagement with Asia, given that Asia is so important to the horticultural markets of Wakefield, including of the Barossa Valley.

ANSWER.PARA: The visit by six Australian ministers to Jakarta last week to participate in the biannual Australia Indonesia Ministerial Forum was a substantial success. It was a substantial success because at that meeting the Australian and Indonesian governments reached an historic agreement: the establishment of the Australia Indonesia Development Area, an initiative which I jointly announced on 25 October with Minister Hartarto, the Indonesian coordinating minister.

AIDA, as it is called, the Australia Indonesia Development Area, offers the prospect of a distinctive Australian role in the development of eastern Indonesia, development which will offer long‐term economic and broader benefits to both countries. Eastern Indonesia has lagged behind Indonesia's general rate of economic growth, but we have a direct interest in ensuring there is a high rate of growth in eastern Indonesia and we are therefore now more easily going to be able to participate in the development of that part of Indonesia.

I also add that this agreement between Australia and Indonesia is an historic breakthrough in Australia's engagement with Asia because this is the first time an Australian government has ever entered into a subregional agreement with an ASEAN country. In other words, this is an utterly practical way in which the government is engaging with Asia. There are several subregional growth areas within ASEAN: there is BIMP‐EAGA, as it is known, the Brunei Indonesia Malaysia and Philippines Growth Area; there is SIJORI, the Singapore Malaysia Indonesia Growth Triangle, and so on.

This time the Australian government has itself been able to ensure that Australia participates in one of these growth areas. That I regard as a very substantial achievement and an historic breakthrough in Australia's engagement with Asia. We were delighted with the outcome of the meeting but, in addition to those results, the individual ministers had most successful bilateral meetings which also advanced very substantially Australian interests within their own specific portfolio areas. The meeting was worth while, it achieved a great deal and there is now an excellent atmosphere in Australia's relationship with Indonesia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Recently, the member for Cunningham asked me a question about the framework of ethical principles for ministers and presiding officers and the framework of ethical principles for members and senators which were tabled in the House on 21 June 1995. Members are advised that the two frameworks were prepared by a working group of members and senators. The working group completed its work on the matter and any action on those frameworks is now a matter for the House itself. Copies of the framework can be obtained from the Bills and Papers Office.

—On 17 October 1996 the honourable member for Moreton directed a question to me in which he alleged that there had been a harassment of a female member of his staff and sought advice about the application of standing orders 75 and 76. Standing orders 75 and 76, concerning the use of offensive words or personal reflections, relate to proceedings within the chamber. Those standing orders do not have a more general application and do not apply outside the chamber or the Main Committee. Having said that, I would be most concerned if the matters alleged to have occurred did occur in this building or anywhere else for that matter. However, on the assumption that the allegations do not involve the possibility of the laying of any charges, this is an issue which needs to be settled between the individuals involved. I would see the two members, as the respective employers of those staff, having a role in resolving the matter.

—I present for the information of honourable members copies of letters received by fax from a firm of solicitors Arthur Robinson & Hedderwicks seeking leave of the House for the production of certain extracts from Hansard in evidence in proceedings before the High Court. I have passed a copy of this request to the Leader of the House, the Manager of Opposition Business and Independent members.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that I have received from the Speaker of the Legislation Assembly of the Northern Territory a remonstrance of the Legislative Assembly praying that the Commonwealth parliament give consideration to the grievances set out in the remonstrance and not proceed further with the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have also received from the Head of Government of Norfolk Island a letter and accompanying resolution adopted by the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly urging that the full democratic rights of the people of Norfolk Island be preserved and that the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 be not passed by the parliament.
The remonstrance and the letter and accompanying resolution will form part of the records of the House. Copies of the text of each are circulated to members in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for you, Mr Speaker, regarding the incident earlier this afternoon. Are we to take it that you will rule all or part of questions out of order without explanation or clarification? In all the time I have been here there has always been an explanation as to why a matter is out of order. Can you check the precedents on matters being ruled out of order without a question being asked and at the Speaker's initiative and without an explanation being given?
—It is nice to see the member for Newcastle back in form. I will take the question on notice and report back to the House later.

—I have a question for you, Mr Speaker. Are you aware whether there have been any restrictions placed on the hours in which the airconditioning system is operated during the sitting days of the House? If there is a restriction on the hours, would it possible for members to unlock the windows in their offices so that they can access some fresh air?

—I thank the honourable member for Moore for his question. I do not think that there are restrictions in force. I think the airconditioning is switched on prior to the evening of the first sitting day and remains on continuously until the House rises. I take note of the honourable member's question and will report back to the House. In so far as opening windows is concerned, my advice hitherto has been that that would degrade the quality of the airconditioning. I think this is a practice generally in force in large buildings like this one throughout the country.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Childcare

Namely that:

PARA.TAB: removal of operational subsidies to community based (not for profit) long day care centres will increase fees, adding a greater financial burden to working parents.

removal of operational subsidy to community based (not for profit) long day care centres in order to place them in competition with privately owned centres (operating for profit) is unfair, iniquitous and may result in a lesocial securityer quality of care for our children.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Baldwin, Peter, MP; Brown, Bob, MP; Lloyd, Jim, MP; Worth, Trish, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Provider Numbers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of NSW draws to the attention of the House that we the undersigned are totally opposed to the restriction of issuing of provider numbers to registered doctors unless they have entered a recognised training program, are vocationally registered or are a qualified specialist. We consider that such an action would cause serious suffering, including a severe disadvantage to women and rural communities and medical research. We believe that it is the essential right of all Australian registered doctors to have access to provider numbers that allow them to provide services which can attract Medicare rebates. We believe that such restrictions are an attack on the most defenceless and vulnerable strata of the medical profession and will not achieve the projected savings which it purports to do. We consider it to be a denial of natural justice, an attack on Medicare and un‐Australian.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

Call upon the Federal Minister for Health the Hon. Michael Wooldridge MP, to enter into meaningful discussions with representatives of those groups most affected by the harsh and unconscionable decisions of his government.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Peter Baldwin (from 94 citizens), Mr Robert Brown (from 60 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 17 citizens)and Ms Worth (from 4,206 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Anthony, Larry, MP; Ruddock, Philip, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Gun Laws
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the need for tighter gun laws.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to support moves by the Prime Minister to tighten gun laws through the following measures;
the banning of fully automatic and semi‐automatic weapons;
the introduction of a nation‐wide shooters licence system; and
the introduction of a nation‐wide gun registration system.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anthony (from 21 citizens)and Mr Ruddock (from 20 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Ellis, Annette, MP; Quick, Harry, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of the certain residents of the State of Tasmania draws to the attention of the House that:

1. The Coalition's decision to means test the Childcare Cash Rebate discriminates against working parents and is a breach of a pre‐election promise, where the Coalition's policy clearly stated `We are committed to maintaining a non means tested Childcare Cash Rebate';

2. The Coalition's decision to abolish operational subsidies for community based long day care centres will result in these centres having to charge higher fees, which will again discriminate against working parents; and

3. The Coalition's changes to the income test for Childcare Assistance will mean that the majority of parents pay far more in increased child care costs than provided through the Family Tax Initiative.
Your Petitioners request that the House:
1. Exert pressure on Members of the Coalition to reverse the outcomes of the 1996 Federal Budget in relation to child care;
2. hold Members of the Coalition to their pre‐election commitments to retain the former system of child care; and
3. vote against legislation given effect to these changes which are to the detriment of Australian families.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Ellis (from 228 citizens)and Mr Quick (from 400 citizens)

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Lindsay, Peter, MP; Sullivan, Kathryn, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of the undersigned electors of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the catastrophic implications to the lives of children and their families that will occur if changes to the current Children's Services Program, proposed in the Federal Audit Commission Report and the EPAC Interim Report, are adopted.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:
Maintain existing levels of Child Care Assistance
Continue payments of Child Care Assistance through services
Retain Operational Subsidies to all community based service types
Retain the benefits of the Cash Rebate for middle income earners
Maintain a National System of Quality Assurance
Extend Quality Assurance to all formal service types
Continue the Federal Government responsibility for Children's Services
Your petitioners therefore ask the House not to pass legislation that will in any way risk the loss of existing quality, affordable child care options for families.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lindsay (from 14 citizens)and Mrs Sullivan (from 33 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Television Reception
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of residents in Derwent Valley in Tasmania draws to the attention of the House to the troubles they have been having with their television reception due to changes from VHF to UHF, aggregation and the subsequent building of the tower on Mt Wellington. Residents had spent large sums of money on new antennae to receive signals on the changeover. When the new tower started to transmit, it required adjustment and different antennae and still no resolution to the problem. Now they have to wait again until another translator is put into restore reception, despite having paid out thousands of dollars.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to have the National Transmission Authority install the last translator as a matter of urgency and that all costs incurred by residents on additional equipment be refunded.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament

The petition of certain residents of the State/Territory of Tasmania draws to the attention of the House their concerns regarding cuts and changes to child care spending by the Federal Coalition Government in its August 1996 Budget.

In particular these include: the withdrawal of the operational subsidy for community based child care centres; the imposition of a 50 hour limit on child care assistance; the abolition of 5,500 new child care places and the introduction of an option for families to have child care assistance paid directly to them rather than to the service.

These cuts will adversely affect families and children by eroding equitable access to quality child care and protection. Reducing this access will also mean that many good quality, community‐based services will become unviable.
Your petitioners request that the House:
Reinstate the Operation Subsidy for all community‐based services
Remove the 50 hour limit on Child Care Assistance
Reinstate the 5,500 community‐based child care places
Ensure that Child Care Assistance payment are made directly to services
Reinstate the $30.00 Disregard for Family Income Assessment for Child Care Assistance.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office, Lithgow
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Calare draws to the attention of the House our opposition to the possible closure of the Lithgow Medicare Office.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to insure the Lithgow Medicare Office remains open.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of the residents of Bathurst and district in the Calare electorate of NSW draws the attention of the House to their wish for the ABC (Australian Broadcasting Commission) not to cut regional services to residents of rural areas, particularly in the field of local news, current affairs, farming news and variety in music.
Your petitioners therefore pray that funding be made available for the continuance of this service to rural residents.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

This petition of Citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House our strong opposition to proposed changes to the Commonwealth States Housing Agreement. These changes will in effect force public tenants out by rising rents, create ghettoes, increase homelessness and will disadvantage those with physical and intellectual disabilities, Aborigines, migrants and the aged. These people will have less access to public housing and are discriminated against in the private market.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to intercede on our behalf to strongly oppose these changes and to defend "safety‐net" public housing policy which has had 50 years of bipartisan support.

PETITION.TITLE: Bears
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House that approximately 8,000 bears are being kept in cages in China for the purpose of extracting bile for medical purposes and that the cages are so small the bears cannot move, which results in some of them going mad. It is further brought to the attention of the House that the Chinese plan to increase the number of bears, for these purposes, to 40,000.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to object most strongly to this horrendous and tragic practice and ask that steps be taken to stop it immediately.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House the procedures of D&X (partial birth—skull decompression) abortions. We further point out to the House that such procedures cause death by dislocation of the vertebrae or by removal by suction of the brain.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House opposes any appropriation to Medicare to fund D&X abortions, and calls on the National Health and Medical Research Council to oppose D&X abortions.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the decision by the Federal Government to abolish operation subsidies for community long‐day Child Care Centres will result in huge fee increases for parents making it difficult for many Australian families to continue to use long‐day care.
