Your petitioners therefore request the House to overturn this decision and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumer Price Index
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, Canberra:
We the undersigned petitioners do show that:
1. The Consumer Price Index (CPI), of necessity, covers all prices including luxuries and;

2. Pensioners spend their income on the necessities of life, which rise by greater amounts and more frequently than other items, and the pension, adjusted twice yearly according to the CPI, is losing its value and has become inadequate to our needs.
We therefore call on Parliament to grant an immediate $10 (Ten Dollar) increase in the weekly pension over and above the CPI, and this we humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Dental Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Electorate of Batman draws to the attention of the House the issue of the cessation of the Commonwealth Dental Program.

The Program has successfully provided accessible quality dental care resulting in decreasing numbers of tooth extractions, increasing simple tooth restoration work and decreasing waiting list times for people on pensions, the unemployed and people on health care cards.

The effect of the program in Northcote has been that waiting times have reduced from 2 years to six months for general dental work and to 16 months for denture provision. People are able to access the public dental service locally for general and emergency care. The dental team reports that they are seeing an improvement in dental health among the people accessing the service. This trend will be completely reversed as the result of the cessation of the Commonwealth program because the Northcote service would be cut by at least 68 per cent, decreasing the service from 2.6 dental teams to less than one.

The loss of this service would condemn many people to long waiting lists and substantially increase the probability of pensioners and unemployed people having their teeth extracted rather than having simple cost effective fillings.
Your petitioners request the House to reinstate the funding of the Commonwealth Dental Program and ensure there is no decrease in funding in real terms of public dental service.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Dental Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The following citizens of Australia request that the House of Representatives note with concern that the withdrawal of Commonwealth funding for dental clinics will place undue hardship on the disadvantaged population of Australia and create unacceptably long waiting lists. Your petitioners therefore request the House to call on the government to reconsider its decision to cut Commonwealth dental funding.
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are opposed to the release for public screening of the Columbia Pictures film entitled "The Craft" .
2. We believe that the film encourages young people to become involved in witchcraft which could have serious adverse moral and spiritual effects.
We therefore pray that the House call on the Film Censorship Board to disallow public screening of this film and for the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, to indicate his disapproval of this film.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia expresses our grave concerns about the conflict in Sri Lanka as arguably the most significant crisis in the Commonwealth of Nations of which Australia is a member.

We understand that both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs have expressed their concerns about the conflict and have advocated sending a fact‐finding parliamentary delegation to Sri Lanka. They have also emphasised the need for an internationally mediated peaceful resolution to the conflict that would bring greater autonomy for the Tamils in Sri Lanka.
We therefore pray that the House of Representatives call on the government:
to persuade the United nations to authorise a delegation to carry out a fact finding mission to Sri Lanka.
to appeal to the Sri Lankan government to lift the economic embargo and allow non‐government organisations to carry out emergency relief works without any government interference in the Tamil areas.
to appeal to the parties to the conflict to stop the war and negotiate a political solution that recognises the right of self‐determination of Tamils.
to persuade the parties to the conflict to accept the role of an independent "Envoy" to facilitate a negotiated peaceful resolution to the conflict under international observation.

PETITION.TITLE: Euthanasia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
This Petition of the undersigned in the State of Queensland respectfully draws to the attention of the House that
Kevin Andrew has introduced a Private Member's Bill to the House of Representatives which would, if passed, invalidate the Northern Territory's Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. (R.O.T.T.I. Act).
We believe the R.O.T.T.I. Act breaches all legal, moral and ethical Australian traditions and urge the Government to support and vote for Kevin Andrew's Private Member's Bill.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives will vote in favour of the Kevin Andrew's Private Member's Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office: The Entrance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the House the importance of preserving Medicare services for Central Coast residents.
Your petitioners therefore request—
That the House call on the Federal Government not to close The Entrance Medicare office.

PETITION.TITLE: Gun Laws
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned requests—
That the Federal and State Governments act swiftly to enact all the proposed new gun laws recommended by the Police Ministers' meeting of 10 May 1996, including:
a complete ban on automatic and semi‐automatic weapons, and
national registration for all firearms.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia being;
Parents/Guardians
Children
Staff
Management
Service Providers
and members of the general community concerned for children.
Draws to the attention of the House:
the threat to childcare places;
the risk to children from unmonitored care;
the increased cost to parents;
the abolition of operational subsidy and its impact on community based service providers;
the impacts on female participation in the workforce.
Your petitioners therefore urge that the House:
Will not endorse the proposed removal of Operational Assistance from children's services;
Will recommend that consultation take place with interested parties on any changes to childcare funding;
Will make any decision on changes to child care funding based on the best interests of the child not on economic rationalism.

PETITION.TITLE: Kingsford Smith Airport
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

This petition from residents of Canterbury City Council draws to the attention of the House the increase in aircraft noise over Canterbury City since the reopening of the East-West runway at Kingsford Smith Airport. This decision has occurred without a proper assessment of the environmental and health impact of this action on the people of Canterbury City and neighbouring areas.

The increase has been exacerbated by aircraft moving away from former flight paths and continuing breaches of curfew requirements. Airservices Australia seek to increase air traffic, particularly from the East-West runway, which will only create additional stress and problems for residents of Canterbury City.

We appeal to the House to stop all aircraft from flying over Canterbury City. We petition the House to remove aircraft noise and associated environmental and health pollution from previous unaffected areas.

We ask that any changes to flight paths be accompanied by a comprehensive environmental and public health impact study on the effects of changed flight paths and that any such study include proper and open community consultation, including guaranteed local representation. We further request that the Federal Government urgently proceed with the construction of a second airport to provide a long term solution to this problem.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office: Belmont
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of certain electors of the Division of Shortland draws to the attention of the House that residents of the East Lake Macquarie area would suffer serious difficulty and inconvenience if the Belmont Medicare office is closed.
Your petitioners request the House to require the government to ensure that Belmont Medicare office remains open.

PETITION.TITLE: Ausmusic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of Tasmania draws to the attention of the House that:
the Federal Coalition Government has completely withdrawn funding from Australia's contemporary music organisation—Ausmusic;
has ignored the findings of a 1994 Coopers and Lybrand report, which recommended Ausmusic be federally funded for a period of five years, in order that it become commercially viable;

and has placed in jeopardy the future of Ausmusic programs, including the annual Australian Music Day, Australian Music Education Week and industry courses which are offered at more than 1,200 schools, youth training centres, technical and further education colleges and universities.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to reverse the decision made by the Minister for Communications, the Hon Richard Alston, and reinstate full funding to Ausmusic as it provides valuable employment and export opportunities for young Australians.

PETITION.TITLE: Communications Superhighway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition from the undersigned citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the grave concerns we hold regarding the dangers inherent in the communications Superhighway, with its potential to corrupt and deprave our present and future society if material containing depictions of indecent or obscene material is not proscribed.
Your petitioners therefore request that in regard to Computer Bulletin Boards the House will frame legislation to ensure that the system cannot be used to:
(1) (a) transmit or
(b) advertise as available for transmission or
(c) possess objectionable material regardless of intended use.
(2) the definition of `to transmit' includes `to obtain' or `to acquire'.
We further request that the legislation ensure that `objectionable material' means material which in any way:
(3)(a) depicts indecent or obscene material

(b) describes, depicts, expresses or otherwise deals with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in a manner likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person
(c) depict in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, a child who is, or who appears to be, under 16 (whether or not engaged in sexual activity)
(d) depicts child abuse
(e) promotes, incites or instructs in matters of crime or violence, or which depicts denigration of religious beliefs
(f) depicts material which is unsuitable for a minor to see or play (definition of `minor' is the same as in the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1994)
and that the legislation ensure
(4) that requests for classification by investigating or prosecuting Authorities shall be completed by the Censorship Board within 60 days, and
(5) provide that proceedings for an offence under section 1.(a), (b) and (c) may be commenced at any time after the material has been refused classification.

Your petitioners also request that all of the above be included in section 85ZE of the Crimes Act 1914. Your petitioners therefore request the House to enshrine legislation containing the above to ensure that the information superhighway be used to contribute beneficial knowledge which will enrich the lives of all Australians.

BREAK.PARA: Petitions received.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking earlier about the value of a public inquiry into the issue of concentration of ownership and other media policy issues, and was suggesting that questions such as what diversity in our media should mean in practice and how it can be distinguished from multiplicity, which is often mistakenly thought to be the same thing, would have been key points of examination in a public inquiry. In the current debate about freedom of speech it would have done much to broaden and deepen that discourse.

SPEECH.PARA: Equally, the issue of foreign ownership and control, an issue about which a great many people in the community feel deeply concerned, could have been addressed. Foreign ownership and control of our media, even more than foreign ownership and control of other elements of the economy, is a matter that deserves greater attention than it has received in recent years.

In the area of cultural discussion and debate in Australia it is a particularly important and relevant question. A public inquiry would have advanced the issue of restraining foreign ownership. It would have been able to at least start to consider in a public forum whether constricting foreign ownership and control was a sensible and important element in maintaining national sovereignty or whether it was simply not appropriate in an increasingly globalised marketplace.

From this question a third issue arises: whether or not restricting foreign ownership would only concentrate control in the hands of a limited number of wealthy and powerful Australian citizens. All these issues deserve a thorough examination, an examination which it appears will not now be as comprehensive as it could or should have been.

The possibility of a further concentration in the ownership of Australia's media should be resolutely opposed by this House. Of greatest concern is any move which would see either Kerry Packer or Rupert Murdoch acquire control of the Fairfax group should Conrad Black sell his 25 per cent controlling shareholding, a move which continues to be rumoured in the markets as a distinct possibility. His Fairfax group dominates classified advertising in Australia's two largest single markets, Sydney and Melbourne, and it is this domination which provides it with the income stream it needs to keep its cover price low and maintain market pre‐eminence. Should either Kerry Packer's PBL or Rupert Murdoch's News Ltd seek to gain control of Fairfax, the consequences for the diversity of ownership and opinion would be quite appalling.

Control of this prestige organisation by either of these media players would also enhance their capability in the further development of online multimedia services into which both are expanding. Such moves would only further narrow the diversity of available information. Greater diversity and broadening of ownership should be achieved through media policy which encourages a greater number of Australian owners and operators and which promotes conditions which would foster such an environment.

Concentration of ownership and reduction of diversity are fundamental threats to the expression of ideas and freedom of speech in our democracy. If this House truly believes in the importance of this ideal then it should firmly oppose any further narrowing of our media ownership and urge a more constructive, open and public debate on issues of ownership and control.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say at the outset I have a great deal of empathy for the motion by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). I suspect his final words sum up very well the position which many in this place would take. We are very well aware the diversity needed in public debate in this country through the media is sadly lacking. I also know the honourable member has a track record in proposing just these particular measures within his own party forums—and each time has been rolled.

SPEECH.PARA: Very simply, when we look back over recent history we can see it is the course of the previous government which, quite simply, created the quite horrendous positions we have now. Labor's legacy, which this government has inherited, has meant media ownership has become heavily concentrated. Diversity has all but disappeared; the prospects through pay television operations of additional players coming into the market are very limited. It is a great loss, not only to the Australian people but also to a viable media industry in this country.

The previous government's role in doling out political favours, in doling out political paybacks and the famous `get Packer' amendments which occurred prior to the last election in the dying days of the 37th parliament are all part and parcel of the case I would like to put before this House today. Even the Senate print media inquiry found the processes under the Foreign Investment Review Board were `secretive, superficial and open to political influence'.

Rupert Murdoch packed up, moved offshore and became an American citizen so he could satisfy their domestic rules as far as media ownership was concerned, but it did not stop him from maintaining a solid stake here in Australia. Hand in hand with Labor's legacy as far as these cosy deals are concerned is the reality there has been a great deal of lost jobs in the media industry over the years. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I was one of those who had a career in the media for a number of years.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very distinguished career.

—I thank the honourable member for Fisher. I think I interviewed him once about 10 years ago in his earlier incarnation in this place. I must say it always pains me to believe both commercial and ABC media in this country have declined greatly over the course of the previous government. It is interesting to see average Australians turning off their commercial television and ABC television. Even radio is declining and newspaper sales are down. I think what we are seeing is people voting with their feet, saying they are hearing and seeing the same old rubbish day in day out and they are not all that interested.

SPEECH.PARA: Another factor is media operators in this country are greatly disconnected with the community they should ideally be serving. I will deal primarily with the television industry through this particular speech. If you look back on the television act of 1953, inherent from those sorts of moves put forward by the Menzies government was the essential two‐station rule. Regardless of whether you owned stations in Tamworth and Taree, or Rockhampton and Mackay, or Sydney and Melbourne, two stations was all you could own. This meant a great diversity of ownership, and it was a very good thing. It also meant local boards. It meant local business people or local community people plugging in with media operators to ensure the local community was well served. A lot of it has disappeared now.

What is even worse, when you look at the so‐called independent ABC voice, it is now the independent ABC Sydney voice being seen and heard right throughout rural and regional Australia and interstate. The stupidity of `icing' the Queensland edition of the 7.30 Report as they did last year proves to me the ABC are just as out of touch.

It is a basic argument to put that media operations are different. Those on both sides of the chamber who practice the doctrine of market forces only dictating what should occur have to remember one thing: the media, by its very design, by the type of industry it is, has a built‐in market failure feature. It costs a great deal of money to enter the media and to maintain business in the media, so it naturally rules out free entry into the particular market. Therefore, it needs government intervention to prevent monopolies developing.

The previous Labor government over the last 13 years forgot all about community interest, forgot all about providing average Australians with a diversity of view, forgot all about trying to prevent monopolies and happily went for the ride and drove the car on too many occasions as far as concentration of media ownership is concerned. There are so many examples.

I turn to aggregation. I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, in your own electorate you would know how rural and regional Australia were promised great diversity of views. They were going to get two and three stations where there was once one. Coffs Harbour was well served for many years by the local station, and now there are a couple of other stations. What did people get? Not a diversity of views; they got Sydney and Melbourne plugged into them nightly. It is not what local people want.

I think we need to return to the core, decent elements of community service obligations, of being plugged into local communities to offer a range of views; views which were inherent 40 years ago in this country. This is not going to happen overnight because there is certainly a lot of money at stake, and a lot of very big businesses would probably reel in horror at any government which decided to make those changes. I suspect the motion of the honourable member for Fraser is all about saying, `Please, no more. We do not need it to go any further.' On such a basis, I think his motion has great validity and is very timely.

It is interesting to note the difference between the previous government and this government. Quite openly, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) said up‐front we want to make sure the national interest is put first. We cannot allow media ownership policy as a means of putting political allegiances and paybacks into the system ahead of looking after local, community and, through it, national interest. There are going to be absolute criteria to open up to public exposure any of the media ownership decisions which will take place before this current government. Relevant decision making processes will be conducted in the public arena. Reasons for decisions will be publicised as well.

I think this is a tremendous commitment from this government. It is a coherent approach to media ownership and cross‐media regulation which will ensure plurality, diversity, competition, advances in technology, national and community broadcasting and local content as we try to evolve back to the basic decent tenets which we had in media policy prior to the advent of the Labor government of 1983-96.

It is quite important to have these diverse views and to have competition back into the provision of public information. It always pained me when I was a journalist for commercial operators and even for the ABC to watch former colleagues in the press gallery in the Queensland parliament caucus as they attempted to work out who was going to put what particular slant on what particular story each night. Here we have for all intents and purposes competitors at the 6 o'clock news level who get together to decide what the particular angle to the story is going to be and which particular five‐second or 10‐second grab may occur.
The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) is quite correct: it probably happens here in the press gallery.

It really is quite a shame and quite disgraceful and quite unethical this occurs. Let me tell members why it occurs. I have witnessed myself first‐hand where journalists would return to their newsroom and compile a story quite independently, based on the facts before them and the debate. They would present the story in a straightforward and direct way. Then their news producer would say to them, `Why didn't you have the particular angle the chap over on Channel 9 has?' So journalists found it difficult to explain why they did not have the same angle when they saw the story in a different way, which was their job and their professional right.

Now they caucus to ensure each other's hides are protected from each other's producers, to make sure everyone has the same line. I think that is very, very bad for Australia. I think it is very, very bad for the dissemination of information in the Australian community. I hope the members of the press gallery in this place and other places will repair their approach.

It is very important we do look closely at this motion before us today. It is quite timely we discuss the need to have public and open and accountable debate about cross-media and media ownership in this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) for raising this very important question. It is easy but regrettable to understand how it happened that Australia has the highest concentration of media ownership in any country of the Western world—even Ireland. Two major groupings dominate metropolitan daily newspapers and many provincial and suburban ones: News Corp, with 66.6 per cent of circulation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, now a naturalised US citizen and resident, and John Fairfax Ltd, with 22 per cent, controlled by Canada's Conrad Black. Tony O'Reilly, an Irish‐American, owns a large share of suburban give‐away newspapers.

SPEECH.PARA: The same players, under different guises and different hats, also exercise a dominant share of some parts of the television empire. Since 1987, major proprietors have been forced to choose between newspaper or television ownership in specific metropolitan markets. In Paul Keating's telling phrase, proprietors could be `princes of the print' or `queens of the screen' but not both.

PARA.BREAK: With sharply increased program costs in the 1980s, the viability of some networks came under threat. Commercial television was no longer seen, as Roy Thomson once put it, as `a licence to print money'. With competition from the Sky television satellite services, another Rupert Murdoch possession, essen tially piped into hotels and clubs, pay television providing specialised services—mostly sport—and the prospect of picking up additional signals by satellite and subscribing to cable (optical fibre) services, the economic threat for the three existing commercial networks was acute.

SPEECH.PARA: By 1994, new model television sets provided for up to 110 channels. The amount of worldwide quality programming was finite and would be diluted with an exponential increase in channels. This put most local production at hazard, with five networks in Sydney and Melbourne—commercial plus ABC plus SBS. With the potential for 30 channels, let alone 110, all of Australia's feature films since the 1930s could be absorbed in three days transmission.

Foxtel, a partnership between News Corp—which owned Fox in the US—and Telstra announced in March 1995, had the potential for more than 200 channels on cable, some of them interactive. This made the challenge to local content even more pressing. Even interminable replays of sports events, panel games, low‐cost home improvement shows and crude assemblances such as the `World's Funniest Videos' would hardly suffice.

The issue of protecting local content will become increasingly sensitive. In 1994, France fought GATT negotiators to make concessions to protect local film and television culture which could be swamped by Hollywood. Despite the significance of the information revolution and the information superhighway's potential as a transforming technology, governments generally have failed to sit down and assess the social, legal, political and economic implications to imagined policy responses.

The previous government, I regret to say, was no exception to that. Australia has been obtuse in that area, with an extraordinary degree of fragmentation of policy responsibility, compounded by a federal system where states can make laws about newspapers but the Commonwealth makes the laws for electronic media systems.

In its report Australia as an information society: grasping new paradigms, the late lamented House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies complained that policy had generally evolved in an uncoordinated fashion, reacting to real or perceived crises. This has generally followed the adoption of a new technological or commercial form—for example, satellites, pay television, optical fibre and the privacy implications of data matching techniques.

Other policy crises have risen unexpectedly: for example, Rupert Murdoch becoming a US citizen, the collapse of John Fairfax Ltd and two television networks going into receivership. Electronic funds transfers globalised Australia's economy and made it harder to control foreign debt. Other information related issues have included intellectual property rights, industrial espionage—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next member, I remind members on both sides of the table of the necessity to observe standing order 57.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to recognise the genuine concern of the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) on this matter of media ownership and congratulate him for raising the issue. It is somewhat late, however, given that the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) has released a review of the cross‐media rules and released an issues paper on 1 October 1996. But I recognise that the timing of this motion is not in the hands of the member for Fraser.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of issues that have created the current circumstances which I think the House generally recognises have led to a review of cross‐media ownership rules. The first one which we need to contend with is the fact that in 1996 we have a new economy. Australian companies generally are having trouble coming to grips with the fact that low inflation means that they will no longer be able to bury ever increasing profits in inflationary increases in the prices of their products. Therefore, they have gone through a period of productivity increases through downsizing and through investments in technology and so on.

It is coming to a crunch point where they can no longer downsize. They are realising that they cannot jack up their prices in order to meet the profitability expectations of their shareholders. Therefore, they are looking to merge or take over their competitors in the industry in order to improve the economies of scale and therefore deliver increased profits. These challenges are going to be faced by companies such as the West Australian newspaper, PBL, the Seven Network, Fairfax, the Ten Network and a whole range of other Australian media companies.

The second area of change is in the area of convergence. The first part of that is the convergence of technology. Once we get a new stream of technology on board, such as the provision of satellites and satellite TV, we get a more improved form of delivering the service coming along such as cable. I well remember walking around the streets of Harare in Zimbabwe a few years ago looking at the enormous satellite dishes in the back of some of the more affluent homes and thinking, `This is the technology of the future.' Yet today we have better access to the same diversity of information through other means and certainly smaller satellite dishes.

The second part of that change relates to services. For example, telephone lines now deliver faxes and video signals and so on. That is a way of penetrating the market through the same means of communication. That is creating problems for those communications carriers that have been providing services in a way that we are accustomed to: for example, AM radio suddenly changing to FM radio, and so on.

The third part of that change relates to the convergence of enterprises. During the 1980s we saw a period of great greed and also great change. The change was actually the catalyst for the greed in relation to communications where we saw, for example, News Ltd purchase the Fox television studios and the Seven Network, more recently, make a substantial investment in MGM studios.

The third area of significant change is globalisation, where you see honoured companies such as Time Warner, News Ltd and Sony becoming global players as opposed to specific regional players. News Ltd, a company which many of us are obviously familiar with, is a very good example of that; it is penetrating every part of every continent. Satellite communications in particular have opened that up.

I believe that the government has taken the right approach. Our focus is on three main areas. The first one is plurality, which relates to the number and kind of media outlets an individual should be able to control. The second area of our focus is diversity, particularly the diversity of programming, and we need to look at the various points of view that are promoted. The third area of our focus is competition. With the advent of the ACCC, competition has a new face to it in 1996 as opposed to previous years.

Around the world media ownership rules are changing. In the United States last year, the US Congress passed legislation substantially modifying cross‐media ownership laws and the UK parliament is looking at a way of delivering cross‐media ownership. So the change is happening. It is a case of how we should manage that change, particularly in the light of the advent of new technologies, such as the Internet. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams, Dick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) recognise that veterans with psychiatric disabilities have problems in accessing public transport;

(2) vary the medical criteria that are set out in section 104 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 regarding the recreational transport allowance to include a category that would extend the allowance to veterans with psychiatric disabilities; and
(3) develop specifically identified other categories where service related disability inhibits travel on public transport that will allow a lower rate to veterans.

The reason for this motion is that I have been approached by a number of Vietnam veterans who have been having difficulties travelling on public transport. Some of them still have a great fear of crowds, or they cannot cope with strangers or loud noises. Some of them also have violent bouts of head pain, necessitating them to stop travelling or to return home very quickly.

In Tasmania, we have very limited public transport anyway, and I am finding that a lot of these veterans with this sort of disability are staying within the confines of their homes without venturing out. Of course, being restricted to their homes leads to all sorts of other disorders and severely limits the quality of life that these people can have. They do not have the freedom that a lot of people have, especially in pursuing recreational or other activities.

During the life of the last government a review was undertaken into the psychiatric services of New South Wales. The review team was told of many instances in which veterans' conditions deteriorated due to delays in having their psychiatric condition accepted as a war related disability. Recommendation 11 stemming from that report states:
That psychiatric problems be given similar recognition to those malignancy and treatment approval (i.e. treatment card) be issued without involvement in the adversarial process.

Those veterans with post traumatic stress disorder, or PTSD, have very varied needs, and so do their families. PTSD sufferers need advice, assistance and access to counselling and therapy. But in the country, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, services of this nature are often non‐existent. How do these people manage to get into town or to access those sorts of facilities? If they cannot use public transport, then they cannot go. Originally, the recreation transport allowance was introduced in 1927 to:

. . . arrange for suitable transport . . . for recreation under Departmental medical advice for those soldiers totally and permanently incapacitated as the result of spinal, head, pelvic or hip injury, organic cerebral or spinal disease, and to double amputation cases above or at the knee whose means of locomotion, because of war disablement, is permanently restricted to wheeled chairs or cots.

The introduction of this benefit would make it possible for an eligible member, whether he was resident in a metropolitan or country district or at a home or institution, to lead a brighter life and to be closer to the normal activities of life than would otherwise be possible.

It was expanded again in 1930, in 1944 and in 1950, but it has not been changed much since then and there have been many quite different war situations with quite different traumas to contend with. It has been recognised that those in the Vietnam War, for instance, faced abnormal difficulties on their return from that war.

However, these difficulties were not recognised in the old legislation, which I believe needs amending to recognise the problems which veterans have in accessing transport. In the Independent Inquiry into the Repatriation System, the report of which came out in June 1975, it was suggested that wider eligibility should be allowed for members who, while suffering little or no restrictions on their powers of locomotion, have limited mobility for other service related reasons. The sorts of things mentioned were allergic respiratory conditions that were made worse by conditions encountered on public transport, certain mental conditions such as intermittent amnesia, and severe physical disfigurement or abnormality where an unsatisfactory psychological adjustment exists.

That was considered under this review in 1975, the recommendation being that the recreation transport allowance at the lower level should be made available to such additional categories as can be specifically identified who, while suffering little or no restriction to the powers of locomotion, are nonetheless inhibited by their service‐related disabilities from travelling on public transport.

PARA.BREAK: A further report was done in May 1994 on improving psychiatric care for veterans. The then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Con Sciacca, accepted these recommendations. He looked at means by which he could address serious problems such as PTSD and developed a package for Vietnam veterans. He did put in place a number of things, but what he missed was the ability of some veterans to access some of the programs which were put in place. So, although recommended, it appears that legislation has not been changed and the department's interpretation still precludes veterans with the disabilities de scribed from accessing some means of private transport.

SPEECH.PARA: My motion is merely to help some of our struggling Vietnam veterans to access programs which they cannot currently access because of their mobility problems. I do not believe it would be costly. In fact, it would apply to very few. But the improvement in the quality of life for those few would be worth an awful lot.

I am disappointed that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Bruce Scott, is not in the chamber at the moment to take on board what I am saying about this very important issue. I hope he will give consideration to what I am saying and to this motion. The motion could apply to any service personnel, whether they served in the Vietnam War, the Second World War, the Korean War or any of the other conflicts in which our service personnel have been involved in recent times. I hope the minister will accept what I am saying. I am sure that the research is available in his department. It is only a matter of getting it out and looking it up. If he needs to be furnished with any further details, I can certainly find those for him. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gambaro, Teresa, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as I rise to speak to the motion moved by the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams), allow me to take a moment, as I commence my response, to recognise the veterans of Australia, with particular reference to those in the veteran community in the Petrie electorate. In many ways it is quite timely to speak on issues concerning veterans, their needs and this government's commitment to this community group, with Remembrance Day only a few short weeks away.

SPEECH.PARA: Remembrance Day, like Anzac Day, is a time to think about sacrifices, a day to commemorate friendships and, most importantly, a day to remember. At any time when we speak about our veteran community we speak about them with great pride. The Petrie electorate has a strong and recognisable veteran community. It focuses on ideals and binds together to provide friendship and support. With this in mind, I wish to take this opportunity to recognise in the House the fine work and the efforts of the veteran community and Returned and Services League sub‐branches in the Petrie electorate. The changing needs of veterans is something that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), I know, is fully aware of and takes a particular interest in. It is also of great concern to this government.

The coalition came to government with a policy of support and commemoration for our veteran community and will continue to work closely with them and the associated representative bodies and associations now and well into the future. Demographics show that by the turn of the century some 60 per cent of the Australian veteran community will be over the age of 75 years. This strongly indicates that the pressure on social, emotional and support services will also increase. The government has made a very positive step for the veteran community, particularly in the areas of assistance, restructuring and simplifying areas which in the past have had logistical problems.

In the recent federal budget a number of key initiatives were directed specifically at veterans. These included: the streamlining of aged pension payments to veterans receiving disability pensions, improved entitlements to veterans for footwear and spectacles, innovative training programs and improvements to the health services of veterans through more efficient and effective use of medication.

It is an unfortunate but recognisable fact that many veterans suffer from a type of disability, whether it be a physical disability, intellectual or psychological. Our community has come a long way in accepting and including those with disabilities in a range of recreational and social activities. Veterans who suffer from psychiatric illnesses, in particular, have their own special needs which have to be addressed. This is an important point to make—that those with psychiatric disabilities do have differing needs to those who suffer intellectual or physical disabilities.

In many cases those who have psychiatric illnesses can be extremely intelligent but, however, can suffer major mood swings and panic attacks which could be triggered by a whole range of everyday social interactions. I am of the understanding that people who suffer from this illness can be prone to a whole range of phobias. Whether it be crowds or confined spaces or loud noises, the resulting impact can bring terrible anxiety. This is a serious illness, where withdrawing from society can lead to post traumatic stress disorder or clinical depression. For example, the depression which some Vietnam veterans have suffered can result in chilling detachment from modern day life. I acknowledge the mention that the member for Lyons has made in this area.

The government is concerned with the needs of all disabled veterans, particularly in relation to ensuring that they lead healthy and very fulfilling lives. Socialising and being part of the community are important factors and the government is striving to provide support for veterans through a number of programs. The Department of Veterans' Affairs plays an important role in the managing of services and support for veterans and their families. The department works closely with disabled veterans providing opportunities for social and cultural interactions. Often the assistance the Department of Veterans' Affairs provides includes organising or hiring transport, whether it be buses or taxis, so that disabled veterans can attend social functions.

As the community gets older it is acknowledged that their needs will change, and this is true for veterans who suffer from psychiatric disability. It places a great deal of added pressure on the support and care structures which already are in place.

I wish to acknowledge the success of the Veterans' Health Week which was held recently. This week provided an opportunity to highlight the needs and issues surrounding the health of veterans. The week also provided a tremendous opportunity to give veterans with disabilities a chance to participate in activities which they may not have been able to do previously.

In the honourable member's motion he has raised the issue of widening the eligibility criteria for veterans with psychiatric disabilities in relation to the recreation transport allowance. He quoted a number of reports, including the 1974 and 1994 reviews. The recreation transport allowance is a benefit paid by the department to assist certain disabled veterans with the cost of transport for the purposes of recreation. The allowance was introduced in 1927. Its intention was for the allowance to benefit those veterans with physical disabilities and to enable them to participate in the normal activities of life that would otherwise be impossible for them to enjoy.

Over the years the eligibility criteria were widened to include veterans with physical disabilities, including war caused amputations and blindness. The criteria, though, were already restricted to physical incapacity which hindered a veteran's movement. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has indicated to me that he is most happy to re-examine any benefit provided to veterans. This government has given a commitment that veterans are provided with benefits and services which best meet their needs.

The honourable member also moved that the House develops specifically identified other categories where service related disability inhibits travel on public transport that allows a lower rate to veterans. With this in mind, it is worth making the point and drawing to the attention of the House that section 104(1) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 contains a table which indicates a description of incapacity in respect of which recreation transport allowance will be paid and per fortnight payments in respect of each of these.

Under the current legislation the lower rate of recreation transport allowance, which is currently $26.40 per fortnight, is paid to veterans who have both arms amputated at or above the wrist; have both legs amputated below the knees; have one leg amputated above the knee and the other below the knee; have one leg amputated above or below the knee and one arm amputated below the elbow; are blind in both eyes; are incapacitated to an extent that, in the opinion of the Repatriation Commission, is similar or severe to the extent of incapacity associated with the amputations which I have described or are handicapped in relation to locomotion to a degree that, in the opinion of the Repatriation Commission, is similar in degree to the handicap in relation to locomotion associated with the amputations which I have described or blindness. I should also mention that the act specifies that the loss of function suffered by the veteran must be permanent.

Let me finish by saying that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is well aware of the issues which have been raised by the honourable member for Lyons in terms of those who suffer from psychiatric disabilities. I am sure that the minister will review the situation. I have indicated to the House today that those who suffer from psychiatric illness do have special needs which have to be met. The government has already shown in many cases that it is open to consultation and will review with an aim to providing the support which is necessary to ensure the quality of life for our veterans community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion. I do so on the basis that there are many veterans across my electorate of Isaacs—indeed, throughout Australia—who suffer from what can only be described as debilitating psychiatric illnesses and who are, as the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) has so succinctly and lucidly indicated before the House today, prisoners of these war‐induced psychiatric illnesses. They are not only a prisoner of the illness from the perspective of health but also a prisoner, in many cases, in their own homes—a symptom of these war related psychiatric disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: These veterans are too timid, too afraid, too sick to leave their own homes. As the member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro) has indicated, they suffer from phobias, mood swings depression and panic attacks which see them too afraid to venture too far beyond the confines of an environment that they know well. For the many veterans who have fought so bravely for our country in so many theatres of war around the world, this motion provides the opportunity to free themselves of the shackles of this condition by affording them the chance to get out and about, having benefited from the application of this particular recreational travelling allowance for those who suffer from psychiatric illness.

An expansion of the recreational transport allowance to veterans with such designated war‐induced psychiatric conditions would, as I say, facilitate greater mobility and access to the range of medical, counselling and other services which are available to eligible veterans. As the member for Lyons has alluded to, a former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Con Sciacca, commissioned a report on the provision of benefits to impaired veterans. The most recent of such reports was released in May 1994. This went to the question of improving care for psychiatrically impaired veterans.

Subsequently, the minister placed before the House a package containing a number of measures to address post-traumatic stress disorders and other similar conditions. Notwithstanding the gains that were made in this area by the former minister, these problems prevail and remain a problem for veterans in Australia. To that end, there have been no recent legislative changes to expand the application of this allowance to other veterans.

This is compounded by the problem that the Department of Veterans' Affairs still precludes veterans with conditions related to post-traumatic stress disorder from accessing appropriate transport for recreational purposes, be it public transport, taxis or the like. The member for Petrie has also drawn our attention to fact that the current Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), is happy to canvass any issue which may result in a review of this iniquitous situation and, indeed, has stated that he is well aware of its existence. I implore the minister to act on behalf of affected veterans and to extend this allowance to those who are so psychiatrically impaired.

I conclude by saying that, from its inception, the intent of this allowance has been to assist veterans who have physical mobility problems to obtain transport for recreational purposes. I think this should be extended to those who have designated psychiatric problems. As I said, there have been no recent demands to expand the eligibility criteria to these long-serving veterans. To that end, I implore the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the member for Maranoa, to act and rectify this iniquitous situation. Given that we are approaching Remembrance Day, I think that affords him a fine opportunity to remember the fine deeds and brave acts that have resulted in our country being free today. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the opportunity to speak on this subject as it is one which affects some people in my electorate of Bowman. I have listened to the needs of certain individuals who have brought their concerns to me in my electorate office. Most Australians take public transport for granted. It may be inconvenient and crowded but it is always there when the need arises. You may not feel comfortable with the person you are sitting next to, but you know that this trip will soon be over and you will be able to get on with your day.

SPEECH.PARA: Just for a moment imagine, if you can, that you suffer from a psychiatric disability—one which leads to panic attacks whenever you are in a crowded place—then imagine yourself on a crowded bus or train. Unfortunately, for many people in our society this situation is a daily occurrence. For these people, having to travel on public transport is one of the hardest things in the world to do. This leads to social isolation, which in turn can have a detrimental effect on the future wellbeing of the sufferer.

It is also unfortunate that a large number of our returned service men and women suffer from some form of psychiatric illness. Veterans can also demonstrate extreme social withdrawal as part of conditions such as post‐traumatic stress disorder or clinical depression, as has been previously mentioned. A large number of our veterans have simply withdrawn from society rather than confront the problem.

This government recognises the need to ensure these veterans lead a healthy and fulfilling life, which includes getting out into the community and socialising. As previously mentioned by the member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro), the government already has in place a number of programs to help veterans. There is a joint ventures program run by the Department of Veterans' Affairs which helps other organisations run social functions for disabled veterans. Through this program, funding has been provided to purchase vehicles to transport veterans to these functions. It is encouraging to note that a substantial amount of this funding has gone to functions organised by veterans who are long-term sufferers from psychiatric illnesses and who fully understand the problems of social isolation.

There is the highly successful Veterans' Health Week, which encourages veterans and their families to get involved in a variety of activities. Many of the activities offered during the week would usually never be accessible to people with psychiatric disabilities. Not only does this program give veterans the chance to socialise, but it also gives them a sense of achievement.

The community care seeding grants program, through which the department provides funds to assist veterans and war widows live independently in the community, has also proven successful and is contributing to the quality of life of a great number of people. So you can see that the government does consider social isolation as a serious problem and is taking steps to ensure the impact is lessened.

However, while the government is already actively involved in a number of programs which give assistance, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) has indicated he is always willing to consider improvements to those programs which will further enhance the quality of life for veterans. The minister has given an assurance that he will have his department review the recreational transport allowance, taking into account the suggestions made by the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) in his motion moved in this House. I conclude on that note: that the minister will take up any suggestions and look at them for approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 9 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews, Kevin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

I recall the painful years during my adolescence when my father was bedridden, slowly dying of the illnesses that sapped him of life. The shadow of death hovered over my studies as I lived with the knowledge that the next phone call could be to tell me of his death. Later, I experienced the losses that many of us have felt—family members to cancer, the tragedy of a young cousin disconnected from a respirator after a car accident. Like all of us, I have seen people die: some quickly, some slowly, some peacefully, and some in circumstances we wish were different.

We cannot ignore our emotional experiences, any more than we should ignore the consequences of our decisions for all Australians. This debate is about passing a bill that protects the vulnerable—or about leaving them exposed to pressure, abuse and a loss of autonomy. It is about having the courage to address an issue of national importance or running away from it:
. It is not a debate about territory rights;
. It is not about the separation of church and state;
. It is not about regulating current practice; and
. It is not a simple issue of personal autonomy.

Territories do not have rights—they have responsibilities, particularly to protect the ill and the vulnerable. This parliament has been prepared to override states, most recently Tasmania, in the national interest.

In this case with this bill, the parliament has express constitutional power. Yet we hear urgings that we should ignore our responsibilities on the spurious grounds that one small territory, with the population of a suburban municipality in Melbourne or Sydney, by one vote, without any house of review, without attempting to state why a law rejected by every major inquiry in the world was proper, and in the face of universal opposition from its Aboriginal population—whose remonstrance in the form of this letter stick I bring before this parliament and the text of which I will seek to incorporate in Hansard—can pass a law that affects many Australians and then claim, nay, demand, that we wash our hands of our responsibilities.
If the parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia cannot resolve a matter that goes to the life and death of its citizens, then what is the purpose of this parliament?

Secondly, it would be strange if only those without religious belief could express an opinion on such a profound matter as this. The fact that no other parliament has been prepared to pass such a law is evidence of the breadth of the opposition—something which Hippocrates expressed thousands of years ago when he said: `I will neither give a deadly drug to anybody if asked for it, nor will I make a suggestion to this effect.'

People like Colleen McCullough, with no religious beliefs, and Professor Malcolm Fisher, who describes himself as a `born again heathen', strenuously oppose lethal injections. There are religious and non‐religious people on both sides of this debate. Let us deal with the arguments.

One of the arguments is that it is happening already, so we should regulate it. This is like saying that some people will obtain high powered automatic guns, so we should regulate, not ban them. If a person is willing to disregard a law which says lethal injections are never allowed, why would they be constrained by a law which says lethal injections are sometimes allowed? If some doctors are prepared to take the law into their own hands and reject the clear requirements for knowledge and consent, why would they change their attitude, especially when dealing with an incompetent patient?

BREAK.PARA: An independent South Australian study found that 49 per cent of doctors and nurses who said that they had assisted a person to die did so without the knowledge or the consent of the person concerned. As the Dutch Attorney‐General, Professor Remmelink, found: many cases of euthanasia are certified simply as death by natural causes.

The law will have no impact at all on these circumstances. Indeed, the Northern Territory law is so poorly drafted that not only are the definitions of terminal illness and depression wide open, a coroner has no basis on which to investigate any death once a certificate is signed by the doctors involved in giving the lethal injection. Despite its procedures, the Northern Territory law has major flaws. If the safeguards are disregarded, the only witness is dead.

Just as the law against automatic weapons will not stop possession of all automatic weapons, laws against homicide will not stop a minority of doctors from practising euthanasia. But the law does send a message, and in the case of many people, it will protect them from abuse and save lives in circumstances where people have changed their minds. Euthanasia legislation sends a powerful message to the Australian community that the vulnerable are expendable and not valued. What we in this parliament legislate to allow, we approve and encourage.

Nor is this is a debate about personal autonomy. A lethal injection is not an autonomous action, even with the use of a machine. If only one person is involved, we are not talking about euthanasia. But can anyone recall the death of a family member or friend that affected no‐one else? As the House of Lords committee stated:
The issue of euthanasia is one in which the interest of the individual cannot be separated from the interest of society as a whole.

With euthanasia, the patient gives up all control to the doctor. John Stuart Mill insisted that no‐one could, in the name of freedom, sell oneself into `unfreedom'. This is why we maintain that people cannot freely sell themselves into slavery. This is why our laws reject consent to bodily harm as a defence in a court.

Euthanasia involves quality of life judgments by the doctor about the patient. If a physically well person is suicidal, we provide them with counselling and care. Witness our response to the tragedy of youth suicide. But, under the euthanasia laws, if an ill person is suicidal, the doctor decides that care is no longer required. In the doctor's mind, death becomes an option.

This is not to mention the pressures, subtle and otherwise, on the elderly and infirm, many of whom already feel a great burden to others. This is why groups representing the disabled and the elderly generally have rejected pro‐euthanasia positions. But consider also the objectives of euthanasia proponents, such as Peter Singer:

We should treat human beings in accordance with their ethically relevant characteristics . . . They include consciousness, the capacity for physical, social and mental interaction with other beings, having conscious preferences for continued life, and having enjoyable experiences. Other relevant aspects depend on the relationship of the being to others, having relatives for example who will grieve over your death, or being so situated in a group that if you are killed, others will fear for their lives.

In other words, the unconscious, the incompetent and the incapable have lost some or all of the characteristics which demand the protection of the law. Even being alone, having no‐one, in Professor Singer's words, to `grieve over your death' may be sufficient to justify and to allow intentional killing. As the authors of the Netherlands Remmelink report state:

But is it not true that once one accepts [voluntary] euthanasia and assisted suicide the principle of universality forces one to accept the termination of life without explicit request, at least in some circumstances, as well? In our view, the answer to this question must be affirmative.
Indeed, Professor Singer has extended his principle to the conscious but handicapped infant.

The Coalition of Organisations for Voluntary Euthanasia has, as one of its commitments, that legalised euthanasia should apply to people with disabilities even if they do not have a terminal illness—something which one of its sponsors, Professor Baume, confirmed again just yesterday. A logical consequence of this policy is the finding of the Dutch Supreme Court that a doctor could give a lethal injection to a 50‐year‐old woman whose husband had left her and whose two sons had died, but who was without any physical illness and who refused bereavement counselling.

Proponents of euthanasia already argue that a lethal injection can be given to a person incapable of consenting. The events of the past century reveal that once voluntary euthanasia is accepted, the language of rights will be employed to argue that those who are incapable of giving consent also have a `right', as determined by another person, to a lethal injection. Far from enhancing autonomy, euthanasia will lead to more control over the lives of many people. This is revealed in the Dutch finding that 27 per cent of people given a lethal injection had neither expressed consent nor had knowledge of their impending death by that injection.

These are the consequences of a choice in favour of euthanasia. The discouragement of suicide is removed for certain categories of people on the judgement of others that their lives are unworthy of living because of sickness or disability. How can we establish categories of people who, if they are suicidal, are to be given a lethal injection, without devaluing all the people in these categories? What is so compassionate about telling people who feel worthless that they are better off dead? The steps in the Northern Territory act do not address these issues. Euthanasia makes a mockery of autonomy.

PARA.BREAK: Three‐quarters of the population believe euthanasia is about turning off machines. This bill does not prevent either the discontinuation of treatment or the provision to patients of the most effective forms of pain relief, even if that treatment coincidentally hastens death. The purpose of this bill is to restate the clear principle that the legislative assemblies have no power to make laws which permit or have the effect of permitting the form of intentional killing of another, whether conscious or unconscious, called euthanasia—which in cludes mercy killing—or the assisting of a person to terminate his or her life. It restates the existing law in the states and territories of Australia, with the notable exception of the Northern Territory.

BREAK.PARA: Some say that there is no difference between turning off a machine or refusing treatment and a lethal injection. Many of us know of someone who has decided against another course of chemotherapy. We do not say that is the same as a lethal injection.

If a person is given a lethal injection, it is the injection that kills them. Presumably, another injection would be given if the first did not work. If we turn off a machine, it is the illness which leads to death. If, as has occurred in many cases, the person continues to live, we care for them. We have no intention to bring about their death.

There is a simple test for euthanasia—that is to ask: what would you do if the person lived? If you discontinue treatment and the person lives, you continue to care for them. If you provide pain relief which risks hastening death, you only provide more doses when required to relieve pain.

Intention is the cornerstone of our ethical and legal systems. A person may shoot another, but not be guilty of homicide, if the shooting was in self‐defence, was provoked, or was an unforeseen accident. It is the intention to kill that makes the action an offence.

At a time when health costs are escalating, the population is ageing, there is a contraction of hospital beds and people are lying on trolleys in hospital corridors in just about every state and territory of this nation, the community is reluctant to raise taxes, and the Economic Planning Advisory Council and others such as the former Governor‐General Bill Hayden have discussed euthanasia in the context of the cost and economics of health care, it is naive to think that economic judgments are not being made and that pressures will not intensify on the elderly. Consider also the costs of palliative care—some $5,000 to $6,000 on average for a person in the terminal stages of their life in a palliative care hospice compared to just $25 for a lethal injection.

We have a conscience vote about how we respond to a person who says, `I want you to end my life.' A wise and prudent judgment must take account of human nature as it is. To believe that with the stroke of the Administrator's pen all people will act altruistically is to condemn people to unconsented deaths. In the analogous situation of capital punishment, we maintain that if one innocent person is going to be killed, even after the very public and due process of the law with all its reviews and appeals, then that is too high a price.

What we should do is to provide high quality palliative care and enact modern refusal of treatment legislation, neither of which has been done in the Northern Territory. And we should take note that every major committee of inquiry in the world, every parliament bar one, the Aboriginal people, the various religious groups, the world medical profession and those representing people with disabilities have all rejected euthanasia. They have rejected it on one unifying principle: the people who are most at risk are the most vulnerable, and a law which fails to protect vulnerable people will always be a bad law.

This debate is now properly before the parliament. To run away from it—as I hear noises—now would be to deny our responsibilities to the people to exercise our judgment for their wellbeing. I commend the bill to the House. I hope that we have the courage to deal with such an issue of profound importance to this nation and to the people of Australia. I commend its contents to all honourable members and I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the contents of the letter stick presented to me for this parliament by the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The letter stick read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: A Letter Stick For the Federal Parliament

This letter stick (darpa dhwumirri) is sent because it follows the ancient practice of our people (Yolu) when communicating with trading partners, in diplomatic alliances, or between parliaments. This message is a special form of communication between the Parliaments of the Yolu Nation/States within East Arnhem Land, and the Commonwealth Parliament of Australia.

It contains, within the markings, a reference to Mgaya, which is the responsibility of the Parliament to the citizens. Mgaya is the peace, order and good government afforded the people constitutionally under Customary Law in a manner similar to the Australian Constitution as stated in section 51.

The Rights of the Terminally Ill Act of the Northern Territory is seen as breaking these fundamental constitutional responsibilities placed upon the parliament. Further, Yolu Customary Law—`Common Law'—defines the enactment of the NT Act as an illegal action of sorcery punishable at law. For this reason this message endorses the action of Kevin Andrews MP to bring a private member's Bill which will overturn the NT Act. Indeed it is the sacred responsibility of this parliament to do this.
This message urges the members of both houses to support the Bill's passage into legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus, Christine, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in opposition to the private member's bill currently before this parliament. My opposition to the bill is on philosophical, practical and technical grounds.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is philosophically wrong in that it overturns the legitimately enacted law of another democratically elected parliament. It is philosophically wrong because it imposes a set of beliefs on people who do not share those beliefs. It is philosophically wrong because it denies choice.

It is dangerous in that it gives the parliamentarians in this place a position of moral superiority we do not and should not have. It is legally wrong in that it perpetuates the system whereby doctors kill their patients outside the law and without supervision or regulation.

It is morally wrong in that it prevents doctors from legally responding to a dying patient's plea to end their suffering. It is technically wrong in that it does not define its terms and is likely to have consequences in the Northern Territory and the ACT that were not intended.

BREAK.PARA: What right have we as a democratically elected parliament to overturn the properly enacted legislation of another legitimate and democratically elected parliament? This is not simply a matter of states rights. The overturning of the Northern Territory legislation is more fundamental.

If we pass this bill, this parliament is saying to the parliamentarians of the Northern Territory, `Our decision making capabilities are better than yours. We know better than you do.' I cannot believe that our arrogance would be so great that we could be seduced into such a dictatorial point of view.

How dare we, as parliamentarians in a democracy, presume to treat the Northern Territory parliament with such disdain. We may currently have a constitutional right, but we do not have a moral or a democratic right.

My second objection to this bill is that it imposes the belief system of one group of people onto another. In our society, many people believe extremely strongly that, if they are dying, it is their right to choose to end their suffering when it becomes unbearable.

There is another group who hold an equally strong belief that there is something inherently wrong in a person choosing to shorten their life by a week, a day or even an hour. Each group starts from a fundamentally different premise. Because these are value judgments no‐one can say that one group is right and the other wrong. Both groups have an equally valid right to voice their own point of view, yet those promoting this bill intend to impose their particular beliefs on everyone else.

I am a Liberal, and as a Liberal I support choice. I do not believe that any one section of the community or any group of parliamentarians has the right to enforce their view on the people on such a very personal subject as this. The Northern Territory act is about allowing that choice. It provides those who cannot bear to suffer any longer with the option of choosing to end that suffering. It does not deny the legitimacy of another belief system and it does not impose one particular point of view on the entire population.

Surveys have shown that the majority of people in Australia support the right of the dying to choose whether or not to end unbearable suffering by hastening their death. Australians are asking to be given a choice. If the parliament passes this bill, it denies them their fundamental democratic right to that choice.

This leads me to the third and fourth objections, which are the practical consequences of this bill. This bill perpetuates a law which prevents doctors from legally helping someone to end their life. This bill imposes on doctors a legal obligation to watch someone die, to see their agony, to listen to their pleas for a quick end and to do nothing. Under the law the only compassionate act the doctor will be able to perform is to alleviate some of the physical pain by administering increasingly large doses of morphine, the effect of which is to remove dignity, self‐control and the ability to think and to communicate. Let us be very clear: this bill is not about prolonging life but about prolonging suffering.

A further consequence of this bill is that it asks parliamentarians in this place and all Australians to turn a blind eye to the deliberate hastening of death that we know goes on without supervision and outside the law. An opponent of this bill, a member of this House, has said that he has been involved in euthanasia as a doctor on two occasions. Seven doctors in Victoria have named themselves publicly as regularly taking part in euthanasia. Fourteen per cent of doctors in New South Wales have responded to the Australian Medical Journal declaring that they have assisted their patients in euthanasia. Eighty‐one per cent of these said they had done it on more than one occasion. Doctors are killing their patients today. They are doing it without supervision, without regulation, and they are doing it outside the law.

The Northern Territory says to doctors, `You do not have the right to end the life of a patient simply because you believe it is the right thing to do.' It gives a strict set of guidelines that must be adhered to before euthanasia can be carried out. The prime requirement is that patients must ask. In the present situation, we do not know how many doctors are acting because it is the patient's will and how many because they assume it is the patient's will. But we do know, because they have told us, that doctors are killing their patients and this is done without supervision, without regulation and without due process.

Under the Northern Territory act one medical opinion is not enough. As well as the request of the dying patient, the act requires the endorsement of a specialist in the condition the patient is dying from, of a psychiatrist and of a palliative care expert. The situation in the states, the ACT and the Northern Territory, if this bill is passed, is that doctors are making the decision to terminate life but without the safeguards inherent in the Northern Territory act. Passing this bill means that decisions will continue to be made by doctors without consultation, decisions will continue to be made by doctors in secret and decisions to terminate life will be made without knowing what the patient wants.

This is a key problem. Under the present system in Australia outside the Northern Territory, doctors are too scared to discuss this issue with their patients and so they make end of life decisions without consulting them. The Northern Territory act has brought this covert process into the open. It empowers the patient, disempowers those doctors who believe that theirs is the only opinion that matters and empowers those doctors who wish to act within the law and according to the wishes of their patients.

An argument for the bill is that it is supported by the Australian Medical Association.
