—I listened very carefully to the comments of the Deputy Prime Minister and I have read very carefully the proposed amendment. Apart from all of the emotional issues, we are dealing here with procedural matters. On the basis of the procedural matter under consideration, the amendment is in order. I call the honourable member for Werriwa.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the member for Bonython seconded the motion of the member for Perth and reserved his right to speak. The call should be to this side of the House now—and I wish to speak.
—That is fine, but the honourable member for Werriwa has the call.
—It's not a matter that goes from one side of the House to the other.
—Order! Let the adjudicator adjudicate. The honourable member for Werriwa has the call.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order—
—I listened very carefully to what the honourable member said. You will have your opportunity to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At this time of free voting I am in the position where I can support the propositions moved by both the member for Longman (Mr Brough) and the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith). I am an opponent of the private member's bill in principle, primarily on the principles of democracy and liberty. I do not claim, however, to be an expert on the detail of the Northern Territory euthanasia laws.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in this matter the onus of proof and argument is with the mover of the bill. He is the one who wants to take rights from others; he is the one who wants to take democratic rights from 500,000 Territorians in this country; he is the one who wants to take rights from terminally ill people in the Northern Territory. I believe that, until the bill and the mover make that case in principle and detail without any doubt, the parliament is entitled to want more scrutiny.

I was very disappointed to hear in the media yesterday the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) saying that he thought a select committee would be a waste of time, because that is exactly the charge that Northern Territorians level at him. I think there is a great irony and sadness in the fact that the member for Menzies, having given so much scrutiny to the laws of the Northern Territory, now seems afraid himself to have the legislation he has brought before this House of Representatives subjected to scrutiny.

I believe that a select committee can play a very productive role. It would not be a waste of time. It would, most importantly, bring scrutiny and detail to the sort of legal arguments that would not otherwise be canvassed in this chamber or in the Main Committee. The legal questions that flow from the issue of the definition of euthanasia and of intention to kill—and I understand they are currently before the courts in Australia without comprehensive conclusion—have been put from so many sources.

The questions have come from lawyers at the Australian National University, from lawyers we have in our Parliamentary Library who have brought to the attention of members in the Bills Digest their concern that this legislation does not have a definition of euthanasia, does not have a definition of intention to kill and does not deal with the complex legal issues currently being bounced around Australian courts and common law on the meaning of `intent'.

I think it was very disappointing that the member for Menzies in his second reading speech just moments ago did not deal with any of those questions. They are criticisms of his bill in its detail that have been brought to bear by lawyers throughout Australia. They have also been raised, I understand, in correspondence with all members in this place by the Attorney‐General of the Northern Territory. I would have thought that a select committee would be useful—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. We are really not debating the merits of the legislation in this motion. The member for Werriwa is continuing to stray from the motion and get on to the merits of the legislation in responding to the member for Menzies. In my submission, he should be called to order.
—There is no point of order.

—I am not speaking right and wrong on the bill. I am raising the questions that have been raised by many lawyers within this parliamentary precinct and within the Northern Territory—including the correspondence of the Attorney‐General to all members—and by lawyers from universities and other places around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I am arguing the case for scrutiny on the detail of this private member's bill. I am also arguing for scrutiny through a select committee because essentially euthanasia is new law. Changes in medical technology this century have done two things: they have extended life beyond the normal course of nature, and they have also brought potential to hasten death. It is not unusual that parliaments across the world have used select committees to deal with these new aspects of law responding to new medical technology.

I also think that a select committee would be very useful in dealing with the contradiction between the attempt to strike down the Northern Territory euthanasia laws and the support that this parliament and the government in other places have brought to bear on the question of Northern Territory statehood. For the benefit of the House, I will read the communique of the recent COAG meeting dealing with Northern Territory statehood:

In this context the Prime Minister indicated the Commonwealth's willingness to facilitate statehood for the Northern Territory according to a negotiated timetable through a truly cooperative federal partnership.

There will be a stark contradiction between in‐principle support for Northern Territory statehood by 2001 and saying in 1996 that they do not have the right to make law with regard to euthanasia. That is a contradiction the parliament could usefully consider through a select committee. (Time expired)

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this aptly named grievance debate on a matter of real grievance for the people and businesses of my electorate of Blaxland. I am supported in this by the member for Banks (Mr Melham), because the people in the Banks electorate are equally affected by the proposed closure of the Bankstown Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of this very real grievance is the decision announced in the ATO Business 2000 statement that the Bankstown Taxation Office would close in the period after 30 June 1998. The `Regional summaries of major impacts' in that document stated:
To 30 June 1998
During this period we will be actively marketing the Bankstown site for sub-leasing. Staff will not generally be required to move from Bankstown until sub-leasing is achieved.
The document continued:
Post 30 June 1998

It is likely that it will be during this period we will move out of our existing Bankstown site. A new presence for field and public contact will be established to maintain and enhance our service to the local community.
The general rationale for the Bankstown office to June 1998 states:

With moves to increase staff density and business line plans to reduce number of sites in each region, the result is a need for less space and branch offices overall. Bankstown has been identified as a site that is unlikely to be required in the medium to longer term, having regard to Bankstown's location between Hurstville and Parramatta for ease of staff movement and the cheaper leasing costs of other sites.
Community expectations for client service will continue to be met. We will be piloting new approaches to the `client services' function in the northern Sydney site(s).

Most staff will not need to move until tenant(s) are found and alternative space has been made available in other existing sites. The earliest this is likely to be possible is around January 1998. Some staff . . . will move earlier as a result of line consolidation.

This is in stark contrast to the draft report some months ago, which recommended not only that the Bankstown Taxation Office should stay but that its staffing should be increased from 644 to 800. The individual taxpayers and small business people of Banks town had the expectation that the significant presence of the ATO in Bankstown would not only remain but be increased.

During the past 10 years, the ATO in Bankstown has grown and served its local clients on the basis of the ATO's decentralisation program. Bankstown is now faced with the closure of a major federal government department in what can only be described as a policy of centralisation and contraction from the local point of view.

Bankstown's individual taxpayers will be faced with long journeys to the ATO offices at Parramatta or Hurstville to deal directly with ATO staff on matters relating to their tax affairs. Small business people in Bankstown will no longer have ready access to a full regional taxation office where their businesses are. The removal of 644 staff from Bankstown to Parramatta and Hurstville will have a very direct detrimental effect on the local economy and small businesses in Bankstown. The Bankstown Taxation Office provided an employment ballast in the Bankstown area, and it attracted further private accounting business to Bankstown because it was a full regional office capable of resolving tax matters at the local level.

I know the difference the loss of the Taxation Office will make to Bankstown because I know what taxation services were like prior to the former Labor government introducing its decentralisation program. The purpose of decentralisation was to move ATO offices closer to where clients are and closer to where clients live. A further advantage of decentralisation was that ATO staff could live close to where they work instead of being stuck in the Sydney central business district. I well remember the Sydney South Office in Hunter Street, Sydney, which housed 5,000 taxation officers. The cost to the ATO of these CBD offices was high, the travel cost in both money and time for staff was high and the environmental demands on Sydney's public transport systems were significant.

PARA.BREAK: The ATO's decentralisation campaign made real sense. It moved its taxation officers out into the suburbs of Sydney close to where the staff lived, which meant that transport costs for staff were minimised as was their travel ling time. It also meant the taxation officers who were involved in field work were much closer to the industries and businesses they had to investigate. This involved great savings in travel time and greater efficiency for the operations of the ATO. This was especially significant for Bankstown's Taxation Office because Bankstown is such a major industrial and commercial centre. The city of Bankstown has a population close to that of Hobart, and it rightly deserves to have a full taxation office to serve the needs of individual taxpayers, small and large businesses and the efficiencies embodied in the ATO's decentralisation program.

SPEECH.PARA: In the early 1980s Bankstown had a taxation office. It had a staff of seven, closeted in rabbit hutch conditions with the Customs Service in an office in Stanley Street, Bankstown. The office was difficult to find, inadequate in terms of staffing and accommodation and incapable of addressing the needs of the people and businesses of Bankstown. The ATO's recognition of the inherent inadequacy of these arrangements led to the establishment of a staged development of a full taxation office in Bankstown. The first stage of that development was an office of 150 ATO staff situated in Rickard Road, Bankstown. This was followed by the opening of the full Australian Taxation Office in Meredith Street, Bankstown, in a leased building which was built to ATO security standards.

The people of Bankstown were pleased that the ATO's decentralisation program had led to the establishment of a fully empowered and fully operating taxation office in Bankstown. The people of Bankstown understood the local economic benefits of this office and they appreciated the convenience of accessing ATO services locally. The people of Bankstown had the quite reasonable expectation that the office would continue to operate efficiently and effectively as it had from its inception. This expectation was buttressed by the ATO's draft plan which was released a few months ago and which stated:

The current staffing level in Bankstown is 664. The ATO‐Business 2000 plan proposes 800. The increase will be accommodated by increased density of workpoints at the Bankstown site and changed work practices.

Between the draft report and the final statement the decision to close the Bankstown office was taken. The draft report was clear and unambiguous that Bankstown rightfully had a place, that it would continue and that it should be increased in staffing level by 156 people. Its future seemed to be assured and soundly based. It cannot have been decided on the basis of reductions in staff numbers due to technological changes as this was already the basis of the draft report.

The rationale underlying the final report was that the ATO `would not use technology to retreat into the back room. Rather we will use the resources freed up by these developments to put more people into jobs dealing directly with the community on their individual issues—giving a more human face to the ATO'. Closing the Bankstown Taxation Office after June 1998 will, for Bankstown, mean that the backroom is bulldozed and the human face of the ATO will be removed from the city of Bankstown almost entirely. The only concession made by the ATO in a letter to the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) on 16 October 1996 was as follows:

. . . in the medium term we are looking to move out of our current offices in Bankstown and Cheltenham (Melbourne), while making sure that we maintain client service delivery for Individuals Non‐Business and the Child Support Agency in those areas through alternative methods.
In that same letter, Mr Peter Simpson, the Second Commissioner of Taxation, stated:

The original proposal has been changed significantly, taking into account extensive feedback received from ATO staff, Members of Parliament and community representatives and ATO business needs now and into the future.

I can only wonder whether the present Treasurer, the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), was one of those members of parliament making an input into the decision making process on ATO Business 2000. I can think of no other ready explanation for a significant taxation office such as Bankstown being retained at the draft stage and then peremptorily axed in the final decision than that it was a mean‐spirited, vindictive intervention by the Treasurer against the maintenance of the Bankstown office, because it was established in Bankstown during the time of the former Treasurer, the Hon. Paul Keating.

Perhaps I am wrong but it is entirely in concert with the drive of this coalition government to abandon direct service provision by the Commonwealth Public Service and to drive towards those service functions being provided by the private sector through outsourcing. The tremors of this drive are already evident in the ATO Business 2000 document. The overview of accommodation argues:
The difference between current best practice of around 15 square metres and our existing holdings is the equivalent of 1,200 staff.
Put another way, if we were to accommodate their existing staff—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey, Fran, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House the growing problem of the ownership of intellectual property in our country. As we move further and further into an age of high technology and global computer networks it is becoming increasingly important to protect the literary, artistic, scientific and industrial creations that we develop as a nation. These creations are known as intellectual property and their ownership is determined by intellectual property rights.

SPEECH.PARA: We all come face to face every day with intellectual property rights. The music that plays over the radio is subject to copyright, the food we eat is covered by brand name trademarks, the newspapers we read are subject to copyright, the clothes we wear may be covered by design rights, the cars we drive are registered designs, much of the equipment and gadgets we use are subject to patents and the formula in some of these products may be subject to a trade secret.

But the laws we have in Australia to protect intellectual property rights are no longer adequate. We go to great lengths to protect people's rights to own land and goods but we do not invest the same amount of resources in protecting people's ideas, inventions and creative work. In recent years, there has been a growing awareness about the need to improve laws governing the ownership of intellectual property. Inadequate intellectual property rights can have widespread ramifications for our standard of living and national exports.

Increasingly, Australian creative and research efforts are becoming an important part of our national exports and if given adequate protection will play a vital role in the level of exports in the future. Literature such as the Power of One by Bryce Courtenay; films such as The Piano and Babe; music by Tina Arena, INXS and Dame Joan Sutherland; highly technical and lifesaving research currently being achieved by Positron Emission Tomography at the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre; the bionic ear; and indigenous artworks and distinctive designer clothing by Jenny Kee and Ken Done are just a few of the examples we have successfully developed in Australia and exported to the world.

However, without sound intellectual property rights there is no incentive for our artists, inventors and scientists to continue to create, and no incentive for investors to back their projects financially. Australia is already a net importer of intellectual property. The Australian Copyright Council estimates that in 1985‐ 86 exports of copyright based items totalled $220 million, while imports totalled $1,285 million. This $1 billion imbalance reflects the substantial premiums Australian industries pay for the use of copyright material, trademarks and inventions protected by intellectual property rights. These 10‐year‐old figures are the latest available.

The true imbalance today would be even greater. The greater tragedy of this, however, is that many of these royalties are paid to overseas holders of Australian registered patents. We are basically importing our own inventions because there is not the incentive or the savings base for these goods to be manufactured and developed in Australia.

The laws governing intellectual property rights should provide the incentive for private individuals and organisations to invest in research and development. New products and processes are part of the competitive market to help keep firms one step ahead of their opposition and provide the prospect of healthier returns. But firms are not going to invest their time and money in a product that is not protected from duplication, counterfeiting, piracy or plagiarism, either in Australia or on the world market.

Piracy is a major problem for the film, video, music, book publishing and computer software industries in Australia and is causing a number of export related problems. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade backgrounder stated in May 1990:
The risk of piracy in the computer software industry was cited as a major factor inhibiting export growth, especially in the micro computer sector.

A wide range of industries—including agricultural and veterinary chemicals, pharmaceuticals, automotive parts, apparel and others—also reported that they were being affected adversely by counterfeiting in overseas markets.

However, the recognition of financial rights is only one aspect of copyright. The other is moral rights, which is the right of the author, artist or scientist to prevent any distortion or mutilation which affects the integrity of their work. These rights are not recognised under Australian law. The Australian Copyright Act 1968 is primarily concerned with protecting economic interests. Examples of infringement of moral rights may include, for example, a sculpture being altered so that it fits a selected site, exhibiting a three‐piece work of art separately or changing the title of published works.
Moral rights are recognised in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which states:
Everyone has the right to the protection of the moral and material interests resulting from any scientific, literary or artistic production of which he is the author.
This principle is also included in the 1886 Berne Convention to which Australia is a signatory.

In June 1994, the Commonwealth Attorney‐General's Department issued a discussion paper entitled `Proposed moral rights legislation for copyright creators' which examined the need for specific legislative protection for moral rights. However, the previous government simply sat on the submissions for two years and did nothing. It failed to implement modern workable copyright laws.

It must be recognised that our current copyright laws, drafted 27 years ago, are fast becoming obsolete due to modern technology. I welcome the coalition's commitment to overhaul our copyright laws and to protect both the economic and moral rights of our artists, authors and scientists.

Designs also need to be better protected not only to compensate designers for their creation but to encourage designers to be even more creative. Australian designs are covered by the Designs Act 1906 and are protected for a maximum of 16 years from the filing of the application. The question is whether this act, established 90 years ago, adequately protects designers of today. I do not believe it does.

In 1961, there were just under 1,500 applications for registered designs in Australia. Thirty years later, in 1991, this figure had risen to just over 3,900 applications—hardly a reflection of the huge technological, engineering and industrial advances we had made over the same period. I believe one of the main reasons for this lack of confidence by manufacturers in the registered design system is the widespread failure of the act to protect design proprietors. Less than 10 per cent of alleged design infringement cases are successful—hardly an incentive for manufacturers to seek design protection and points to a major flaw in the registered design system.

There is little incentive for manufacturers to design new products, if a competitor can copy the design with just subtle changes, market the product and reap the resulting profits without paying a cent to the original designer. Our designers and manufacturers have been badly let down. The act needs to cover not only designs for new or original products but also designs which are slightly changed or improve the product.

As the global village becomes a reality, I believe there is a need for a world patent. This would mean that, once a patent application was successful in Australia, it would be automatically recognised by all other countries. This does not exist now, but there are already enough international intellectual property agreements in place to suggest the feasibility of a world patent. For example, under the community patent treaty a single application filed at the European Patent Office will, if successful, lead to automatic patent recognition in every country in the European Community. A worldwide patent would reduce the huge cost burden the current world patenting process places on Australian businesses.

Australia is currently a party to 14 international conventions affecting international property rights, including the trade related aspects of intellectual property rights agreement. The TRIPS agreement requires World Trade Organisation members to provide a base level of protection to various forms of intellectual property and a minimum level of enforcement of these rights.

PARA.BREAK: In today's society, we can literally access the world at a touch of a button, which is why it is so important that we adequately protect our intellectual property. The first step towards achieving this is to undertake these long overdue reforms. What our industry, our scientists and our creators really need is a complete overhaul of the laws governing ownership of intellectual property to ensure that Australia reaps the rewards of the ideas, inventions, designs and research which origi nate here. Now is the time for this review. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to put forward some thoughts on the current debate occurring in Australia regarding migration and the way that has been misused and abused in some quarters in what would be quite a racist manner. I note the presence of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), who I am proud to call a friend, even if he would not call me that—I am sure he might. I hope he will find nothing of great complaint regarding what I have to say tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I would link up the question of racism and the debate on Asian migration with the term `multiculturalism'. One of the problems I see with the current debate is with the definition of the terms; that is, people are using some of these words as it suits them in their own circumstances as they see it, often not only in a situation where they do not understand the meaning of the word or what the word was meant to mean or what some people think the word was meant to mean but also in a situation which is largely based on ignorance.

That is one of the real concerns in this debate—that so much of it does appear to be on the basis of ignorance. I do not blame anyone in particular for that. I would not say it is just a matter of it being an individual member of this parliament. I think it comes across clearly in talkback radio, in letters columns in the various papers and also in calls that I have got at my electorate office. That ignorance is also based on an element of fear—fear and concern about the future of this country, fear and concern about the future of our children, fear and concern about what in fact is Asia, fear and concern about what in fact is our place in the modern world.

PARA.BREAK: I have been doing a bit of reading today to try to catch up on some of the current debate on this issue. I was concerned that there was some difficulty in accessing documentation which really laid it all out in regard to this issue. That is part of the public debate that is missing. When comments are made by indi viduals stating facts as they see them, which are in fact not facts at all, if they are not refuted they become a truth and that truth grows and grows and grows. I think so much of what we have seen in recent times is along those lines.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to relate some personal experiences as a member for an electorate with a high level of residents of a non-English speaking background, as a former councillor for the old city of Springvale in the south‐eastern suburbs of Melbourne, and also as a resident for some six years in the suburb of Noble Park in that city of Springvale. Springvale has sometimes been called `Chingvale' by those who probably have never been there, because of a high level of Asian migrants who have made the area their home. It is a very unfortunate and unfair term.

As one who has doorknocked the streets of Springvale in order to convince the good burghers of that area to put their trust in me—they have on occasions done so; why I will never know—the situation is that there are many other migrants in that area, not just Asians. In fact, if you pick a country in the world, the chances are there would be people from that country living in the Springvale area.

When walking around Springvale or going to the Springvale shops, the comment was often made, `There are thousands of Vietnamese people who live here.' As a councillor I had a bit of experience with the Springvale shopping centre. The fact is that that shopping centre is about the best area in all of metropolitan Melbourne to shop for Asian food, Asian cuisine. The council once did a survey of people who were using the shopping centre and found that it was used by people from as far away as Werribee and Lalor—people from the other side of town. The reason for that location being heavily Asianised, if you like, was the fact that there was good, cheap food available. That shopping centre was a major source of economic development for that area.

When I first moved into Noble Park an elderly family of Anglo-Saxon extraction lived in the house on my left. They were very nice people. I bear them no ill. They were reasonable neighbours; I have no complaint about that. They moved out after several years and were replaced for the last two or three years of our presence in that street with three generations of a Vietnamese family—grandparents, mum and dad, and a couple of kids. With no disrespect to my other neighbours, I can honestly say that they were the best neighbours I ever had. They were courteous, polite and quiet. The grandfather even used to come to our place and work in our garden free of charge, because he believed our garden was a bit messy for the area. I think he was right and I make no apology, because I am no gardener. They were good and, I think in many respects, typical.

At that time my kids went to a local primary school called Heather Hill Primary School. If you heard an audio recording of my eldest daughter's class when she was in grade 1, you would think that there were about 30 screaming six‐year‐olds running around, jumping, playing and doing what kids that age do. If you saw a video of that class you would think that what was taking place was a junior version of the United Nations. There were people of all different backgrounds, but they were generally recently arrived migrants or first generation Australians, and the fact is that they were becoming part of Australian society. Frankly, what we see with Asian migration in general terms is a development of what has occurred with previous patterns of migration.

Back in the 1960s when I was a kid, I remember going to my grandparents' place in Brunswick and dealing with Greek, Italian and Turkish kids who had come there to make it their home. They are now doing things like playing for Aussie rules football teams, working as accountants or lawyers, and they are part of our society. Essentially, that is what is happening too with Asian migrants today. The fact is that they look a bit more different, therefore they are a bit more noticeable, therefore they are a bit easier to use as an excuse, and that is what is happening in some respects.

PARA.BREAK: I do not believe that all Australians hold these views. I do believe that most Australians—I would include myself in some re spects—have a lot more to learn regarding this debate before they can comment with any significance and with any clarity and by using the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was in Noble Park there were often complaints about gangs and issues of that nature. In my six years of residency there I got accosted once by a gang. It was just after former Prime Minister Bob Hawke visited during the election campaign in 1990, and that gang sure as hell was not Asian. They were just local kids causing a bit of trouble; essentially, that was the nature of the area.

I spent my teenage years in Frankston, which largely consists of English migrants and second and third generation Australian stock. The one time in my life I have been belted good and proper was by a gang of largely English kids—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Right.

—It was not the Labor Right—it could have been. They were Anglo‐Saxon. Often, rather than looking at a situation in society and saying, `Here is a problem; why is there this problem?' we say, `Here is the problem; what is different about these people that makes this the problem?' When we look at areas of lower socioeconomic development, we find that lower paid people are living in those areas and they are often migrants. We look at them and say that that is the problem. That is not the problem at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I will finish by reading a letter from a local constituent which illustrates some of the problems that are occurring in the community in terms of the perception of this debate. I think it is an informative letter. It is from Dr Ming Zhao. He writes:
Dear Mr Griffin,

I am a professional Australian with Chinese origin working with Telstra as a Principal Scientist. I also know a group of a few hundred Australian Chinese professionals. We not only work for universities, government institutions and industrial companies across different sectors but also run professional services. Most of us are highly qualified and experienced and started to contribute to the Australian society just as other Australians since our arrival on this soil. We accept the mainstream culture of Australia, and embrace the fundamental social values of democracy, human right and freedom of speech. We have made Australia home because this is a multicultural society which enjoys harmonious relationships between people from different nations.

I am deeply concerned of, and so do my friends, the recent attack on multiculturalism in the Parliament by a tiny group of Members and extremely concerned by the increase of racial based crimes in the society. I strongly believe that only mutual respect, understanding and tolerance among all Australians will lead to a stable and prosperous society which will in turn benefit all Australians coming from such a diversified area and cultural backgrounds. Racial based bias, hatred and division only result in instability, violence and crime. They also seriously damage the international stand of the country.

I appeal to you, a Member of Parliament and a leader of this country, to act on the interests and benefits of all Australians. I appeal to you to condemn racism and racial based violence. I appeal to you to promote understanding instead of hatred between people of different origins. I appeal to you to promote multiculturalism.
I believe this letter really makes a point regarding the significance of this debate and the concerns it is raising in the community. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nairn, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I, unfortunately, continue to grieve over the wellbeing of those communities in the south‐east of my electorate which have relied heavily on the hardwood timber industry for many generations. I do not need to remind this House of the extent of the impact that previous federal and state government decisions have had on towns like Eden and Bombala—decisions that were based on pure politics, not on science, decisions designed to win so‐called green votes in large urban electorates.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know what the people of rural and regional Australia thought of the Labor Party over such disgraceful decisions which threatened to decimate their economies and throw people out of work who had worked hard, honestly and responsibly in the timber industry for many, many years. Yes, they got rid of virtually every single Labor member who represented those areas. That is what they thought of those decisions.

We promised to take the politics out of the timber industry decisions, put the emotions to one side, bring the science back in and give some consideration to those rural communities at long last. We started that process when we brought in new regulations covering the export of woodchips. That was sensible, logical and scientifically based. Contrary to the misinformation put out by so‐called conservation groups, the decision was also good for the environment. It will stop the burning of waste, it will clear the forest floor of rubbish, thus allowing new trees to grow more vigorously, and it will allow foresters to get back to good forest management, with thinning being done, also promoting strong forestry growth.

The decision will also allow some degraded forests to be cleared so that new native hardwood plantations can be established. We all recognise that hardwood plantations are the key to the long‐term future of the industry, but there has been a disincentive to establish them to date. Unfortunately, there still is a problem in this regard in New South Wales due to the draconian, totally over the top regulation called SEPP46. This regulation is a good old Labor Party method of using socialist regulation as a way of changing attitudes. It does not work and only catches all sorts of other things in the process.

Meanwhile, the reaction from overseas clients to our government's change in the export woodchip regulations has been very good, particularly the aspect that allows companies to negotiate longer term contracts. In Australia, we too often forget just how young we are. Other countries want to do deals for the long term. They are used to that. We cannot be a world force if we only let our exporters sign up contracts for short periods. So foreign clients were very pleased that they would now be dealing with a country whose government is encouraging longer term contracts.

Unfortunately, the new regulations came too late to help a company in my electorate, Harris Daishowa, to negotiate additional contracts for this year. Their clients went elsewhere only weeks before we were able to make the changes. But it does help them for the future and their clients are pleased to be now negotiating along those lines. That is, if the New South Wales Labor government allows them.

One might ask: what have the New South Wales Labor government got to do with woodchip exports? Nothing legally, but they do control the resource, and they are not playing the fair scientific game in this process. It is about what you would expect, others might say.

The Commonwealth, in good faith, has participated in the process that is designed to achieve a regional forest agreement for the south‐east. That process is partially completed. There is still an enormous amount of scientific work to be done on the forest and national park areas. It would be premature and scientifically irresponsible to make decisions at this stage as to what should be locked away forever.

But what has the New South Wales Labor government done? It has pre‐empted all of the scientific work and announced that 90,000 hectares will go to national park and another 30,000 hectares will be further assessed. When this announcement was made I had the temerity to suggest that `further assessment' was Labor Party code for, `It's okay, extreme green groups, we're really going to lock it away, so just let us play the politics a little bit longer.'

My cynicism was proved right the very next day, when the Labor Minister for the Environment, Pam Allan, referred to the 120,000 hectares going to national park. She had it locked away already without any further assessment. To support that, I was subsequently reliably informed that some key high conservation areas were deliberately put into the 30,000 hectares rather than the 90,000 hectares to ensure that it all would be included in national park.

The end result of all of this will be further decimation of the industry and subsequently the communities that rely upon it. But I am very pleased to see that our Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is awake to these tactics. In a press release last Friday he reminded the New South Wales Labor government of its responsibilities and of the process it should be following. He reiterated that the application of forest reserve criteria must be flexible and must take account of the social and economic importance of the forest industries and the effect on communities. He expressed his great disappointment that the New South Wales Labor government continued to pre-empt the comprehensive regional assessment which must be concluded for the Eden region.

If the New South Wales Labor government do not return to the proper processes and allow the full scientific research to be done prior to final decisions, the communities of Eden and Bombala and many other smaller communities will be facing a very bleak future—and this is because the New South Wales Labor government will not be able to keep their commitments on resource supply if they proceed with the magnitude of forest lock-up that they are currently proposing. It will mean that they will not be able to supply the 26,000 cubic metres of milling grade timber needed to sustain a viable industry. They will not be able to supply the necessary pulpwood resource to Harris Daishowa, which would mean a supply of at least 25 per cent below the contract levels that the state government are contracted to supply through to the end of the year 2009.

I warn the New South Wales Labor government that if they pursue a course which results in a breach of contract, a breach that may then lead to a point where the aggrieved company seeks damages, the New South Wales Labor government should not look toward the funds available through the forestry industry structural adjustment package, FISAP, to pay those damages. That would be an absolute abuse of the use of those funds. I will be seeking assurances from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that he would not allow Commonwealth money, which comprises 50 per cent of the FISAP funds, to be used in this way.

I am justifiably concerned as to just where the New South Wales Labor government are going on regional forest agreements. One has to wonder if they really want to see the continuation of a viable, sustainable hardwood timber industry. I also wonder where they stand on value adding in this industry. Just today I received a phone call from someone in the Eden area who was made redundant from the timber industry nine months ago. He has invested in a mobile mill that can be taken into the forest and be used in such a way that a lot of waste timber could be processed through it. Many logs that have fallen naturally are lying rotting on the forest floors. They could be processed. These are logs that are uneconomical to take to sawmills and at best may be taken to the chipper.

Many of the trees that are currently only suitable as pulpwood could be part processed by this mobile mill with the balance going to the chipper. I would have thought this makes a lot of sense—it creates work and utilises poor quality logs and waste. But the New South Wales Labor government seem to think otherwise and continue to refuse a licence to this enterprising man to scavenge this sort of timber from the forest areas. I will be calling on them to reassess this and look realistically at what is actually happening in these communities.

The regional forest agreements can work for everyone. They should be based on science, and not on politics. I call on the New South Wales Labor government to rescind their decision to lock up 120,000 hectares of forests and allow the correct processes to be completed before final decisions are taken. Those decisions must be taken with an assessment of the impact on the communities on top of the priority list, not down the bottom, where they currently are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity tonight to make very clear the position of the opposition on public housing and, in particular, the areas where we are at variance with the government. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) has constantly implied that she has bipartisan support from the opposition for the government's proposed reforms to public housing. I would like to put it on the record in this parliament, as I did in a letter to the Melbourne Age last week, that the Labor Party rejects this claim. There are areas of housing policy where Labor does have a degree of commonality with the government, but there are significant and crucial differences.

SPEECH.PARA: In my letter to the Age I made the point that Senator Newman's recent pronouncements on public housing reform in that newspaper had been long on rhetoric of a rosy future for all renters, both public and private, but very short on the critical detail. What we do know is that this Liberal government has reduced the current Commonwealth-state housing agreement from three years to one, thus ruling out any long-term capital investment in new public housing stock by the states. This has caused the New South Wales government to greatly reduce its planned construction of public housing units from around 3,500 per year to just 680 this year. No doubt it is the same in all the other states. This will also mean the loss of more than 4,000 jobs in the building and construction industry in New South Wales alone.

Less quantifiable, but possibly even more long term, has been the damage caused by the general uncertainty resulting from the restriction of the CSHA to one year and the failure to clearly define and act upon whatever it is that is to replace the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. In my own electorate of Jagajaga, tenants in public housing and public housing workers are becoming increasingly frustrated by the uncertainty and delays to necessary work that this government's half-baked attempts at housing reform have produced. One direct outcome that I know has disadvantaged the public housing residents of West Heidelberg has been the cutting of funds from minor capital upgrades. This has meant that there can be no work carried out to modify housing for tenants with disabilities or for tenants whose increasing age or frailty necessitates modifications to bathrooms and toilets.

PARA.BREAK: Of equal concern is the fact that, where housing has become so run down that replacement rather than repair is the recommendation, there are no funds available and so the unit is usually sold. Thus this government's policy is leading to a net reduction of public housing stock. Government workers in public housing are becoming increasingly frustrated as they try to find answers to tenants' ques tions about their likely future. This uncertainty is breeding suspicion and distrust—all because the government still has not provided the community with any detail about its reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to another state and look at the Brisbane Courier‐Mail of last Friday which carried a report about this issue. The Courier‐Mail referred to the Queensland Minister for Public Works and Housing, Ray Connor, being heckled and called a `galah' by angry public housing tenants at a Brisbane forum called to consider the implications of the `controversial federal government housing reforms'. The newspaper reported:
Public housing tenants told the forum, organised by Queensland Shelter, that they were "scared" about the rental subsidy scheme.
They predicted the reforms would result in evictions, poverty and longer waiting lists.
Speakers at the hearing then went on to detail one of Labor's main concerns with the proposed changes. I quote again from the newspaper report:
. . . the rental subsidy scheme would make the poor poorer and put money straight into the pockets of private developers.
The newspaper reports that at the meeting:
Mr Connor predicted the Federal Government's final resolution on the housing reform statement—scheduled for January—would not be achieved for "quite some time".
He used the forum to reiterate his growing concerns about the housing blueprint.
"I'm becoming decidedly reluctant about the proposed changes, because so far there has been no assurances Queenslanders won't be financially disadvantaged," he said.
"It has to be signed by me and I will not sign it."

It is therefore apparent that the government has failed to convince even one of its more conservative state governments of the benefits of its proposed changes to public housing. It seems likely they will be forced to roll over another Commonwealth-state housing agreement into another year of uncertainty, confusion and unnecessary worry for tenants. That the government has failed to carry the states along with its ideas is not surprising. The states can see that the policies the Commonwealth is proposing will leave them—the states—with increased responsibilities and less resources to meet these responsibilities.

It is important to make the point that Labor is not opposed to reform of public housing. Indeed, changes and reforms were already happening under the previous Labor government. It is simply the case that we feel the Howard government looks like they will throw the baby out with the bathwater. In their rush to implement policies in accordance with their ideological agenda, they place undue confidence in the ability of the marketplace to achieve outcomes that the opposition feels should remain the responsibility of government.

This is best seen in this government's desire to move from a system involving a balance between the provision of public housing units by governments and the provision of a level of rent assistance to low income renters in the private rental market to one where the federal government no longer requires any commitment by the states on the provision of public housing stock.

Many arguments are advanced by the government to support this policy change. The opposition accepts some of these, such as the desire to see public housing tenants located as closely as possible to services and employment opportunities. However, the notion that housing for low income Australians can be entirely left to the mercies of the private rental market is one that we emphatically reject.

I just want to outline some of the things that Labor believes any bipartisan approach to public housing must contain. First, overall levels of public housing stock should be maintained. We would not agree to any reduction in the Commonwealth-state housing agreement of overall levels of public housing. Secondly, there should be an increase in public housing in areas of need. It is not the case that all parts of Australia have adequate access to public housing. In fact, to go back to the Queensland example once again, we have serious evidence of considerable underprovision of public housing in that state. The Commonwealth-state housing agreement needs to recognise this fact and provide the capital to the Queensland government to ensure that public housing is built.

Thirdly, public housing in well‐located areas, especially the inner parts of cities and those close to jobs and services, should be maintained. This government has yet to say categorically that it will not stand for the states selling off well‐located stock. Fourthly, the redevelopment of old public housing estates is another very important part of any new agreement. Fifthly, there should be a guarantee that no public housing tenant will pay more than 25 per cent of their income in rent and that no existing tenant be disadvantaged.

Sixthly, the new CSHA should contain national tenancy legislation and, finally, all public housing should be maintained at acceptable community standards. This requires a clear role for capital within the new Commonwealth-state housing agreement so that we do not see older public housing estates just deteriorate and left to be pulled down at some future date.

Location of public housing is a key concern of Labor's housing policy. It was the primary motivation behind the increase in funding for private rent assistance as a partial means of breaking the deadly nexus between poorly located public housing and employment opportunities. But it was never ever intended as a replacement or substitute for public housing. Until the government shows its agreement and commitment to these public housing priorities that I have outlined, we will not be able to have a bipartisan approach. I hope that change will happen very shortly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the historic circumstances of today's debate, I wish to use my grievance debate this evening to make some comments about the issue of euthanasia. I preface my remarks by saying that I have practised medicine for 13 years. I chaired the ethics committee of the Australian Medical Association for three years and in that role, apart from other things, was involved in the investigation into the improper behaviour of some medical practitioners. I have also been involved in development of policy on behalf of the medical profession and, in my former life, was the leader of what remains the largest medical organisation in the country, and that is the Australian Medical Association.

SPEECH.PARA: In March last year, my own brother, who was a member of the Society for Voluntary Euthanasia, died from a disease which he had had for some time. Obviously, at a personal level, I have also had some experience with these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just interrupt the member briefly. I am sure he is aware of standing order 71 which will allow him in a grievance debate to traverse this area so long as he makes no reference to the legislation before the House and the specifics of that legislation, particularly as it refers to the Northern Territory act.

—Yes, thank you, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, I am aware of that. When speaking at a conference three years ago, an elderly man from the back of the audience interjected, `This is all very well, but what are you doing about euthanasia? The old people of Australia don't know how they are going to survive without it.' That comment reflects some of the uncertainty that exists in the community in relation to terminology.

SPEECH.PARA: Equally, on 28 April last year I was at a function on the Gold Coast for the Royal Australasian College of Physicians when the then Governor-General, Mr Bill Hayden, a proponent of euthanasia, said that, having lived a good life—and I do not doubt that from what I read in the newspapers at the time—and visited many nursing homes, he would not like to be like that when he got to the age of many nursing home residents. He felt that he had a right as an individual and as a human being to request the timing and the manner of his own death.

I was recently told by one of my political colleagues that I should be aware of the polls and that I should not be left behind, because 70 to 80 per cent of people responding to polls were in favour of euthanasia. There are a number of points that need to be made in relation to polls. The first is that the reality of the polls is that people are just walking down a supermarket aisle on Saturday morning with two or three children looking for cornflakes when somebody says, `I am from Newspoll. Do you think the law ought to be changed to allow a doctor to give a lethal injection to a person that is suffering from a terminal illness?' Like some other surveys, I say, `What is wrong with the other 20 per cent who don't reply yes?'

What most Australians—in fact, I think all of us—fear is not death so much as the process by which we will arrive at our death. We fear dying an unnecessarily painful and undignified death. For those who understandably are not frequently having to think about the issues in relation to dying, it is an easier thing to answer yes to such a question.

The second point that ought to be made is that just because something is popular does not always make it right. For example, at the moment it would seem that some of the comments attributed to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) are popular, but I would suggest to the House and to the community that they are not necessarily right.

The issue is like dusk. Those people who are in favour of euthanasia and those who are against it are neither fully right nor wrong. It is very difficult to tell whether it is day or night. But not all things in life can or should be regulated by laws. There are some who say that this matter should be out in the open and not behind closed doors, as they perceive it to be. But the law is a blunt instrument. It does not have the finesse to deal with all of those circumstances in which we inevitably find ourselves as human beings, whether it be as doctors, nurses, patients or families.

The law is about winners and losers. It not about dignity. It does not deal with the issues of fear, uncertainty, respect and expectation at all well. In my experience, the concepts of trust and respect are much more likely to flourish in a relationship which is governed by ethics, morality and common sense than it is by the laws which govern the day-to-day transactions of life. When we put the law in a situation where it has to be involved in some of the most difficult and intimate decisions that people have to make, then the doctor and the patient find themselves as potential adversaries. From experience, I have found that that is not in the interests of a patient.

People request euthanasia usually when they are diagnosed as having a disease from which they will not recover. Understandably, they are depressed. Many people who are dying feel guilty about the grief they see their loved ones going through. For example, Mr Dent from the Northern Territory was concerned that his wife had to provide certain levels of personal care to him. Equally, relatives feel that they are unable to cope with the process themselves.

The former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory was reported at one stage as saying, in favour of euthanasia legislation, that he had watched his mother die and that no-one should have to go through that. It begs the question: for whom is such legislation intended—those who are dying or those who, for whatever reason, have difficulty coping with the process?

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the member for Bradfield that he is now skating on thinner ice than he began with.

—I will get back onto thick ice, Mr Deputy Speaker. The other experience I have had is that people particularly request euthanasia because they are in pain. But, in fact, it is usually because they are not being treated properly. They are being treated by doctors and medical people who do not have access to good palliative care and who are not up to date. Frequently, I have also found that doctors fail much more as human beings than they do as scientists.

SPEECH.PARA: Not all pain and suffering is of a physical nature. Unfortunately, many doctors fail in the interpersonal relationships which they have—or perhaps do not have—with their patients and the families. I think that people also need to be reminded of this fact. I certainly have met people who were told three years ago that they only had three months to live and they were told that by five or six doctors who are proficient experts in a particular field.

PARA.BREAK: When Mr Hayden said that he had an individual right to request euthanasia—in his own words `to no longer be a burden to his own family and to society'—it is very appeal ing to all of us to say, `Yes, that appeals to me. I want that right. Nobody is going to tell me what to do.' But when one human being exercising their rights diminishes those of others then I think we have a responsibility to say, `No, we don't think this ought to happen.' If Mr Hayden and someone in bed 10 says, `I no longer wish to be a burden to my family and to society,' and has euthanasia, then that places others around them in a position where they feel guilty about continuing to live.

SPEECH.PARA: The Economic Advisory Council, in its report of January last year into the cost of ageing, actually canvassed euthanasia as a prospective solution to this problem. Professor Peter Singer from Victoria said that babies up to 30 days of age could have their lives ended. One has to wonder where legislation to give effect to such things might end up. Equally, it is of concern that as a society, in a nation which has a youth suicide rate that is amongst the highest in the industrialised world, we are sending a message to young people who similarly suffer despair that we think death is a legitimate solution to what are thought of as insurmountable problems.

I have also found over the years, in caring for people who have later died, that it is quite possible for people and their families, when they face the battle of death, to emerge from the whole process having had what you might call a spiritual victory. I suggest to those who, understandably, are concerned with quality of life that life is a struggle—no more so than when you are dying—but the value of life lies in how you deal with it.

There is a crisis in this country, there is a crisis in society, and it is deeply rooted in the higher moral priority given to people's rights than their responsibilities, and on value rather than values. There is a preoccupation with the here and now, a preoccupation with `me' and `What am I going to get out of life?' on `What is going to happen to me?' rather than concern for other human beings.

I have had 10 minutes in the chamber to address the Andrews bill. I will take 10 minutes in the Main Committee to make some further comments. I thank the House for giving me the opportunity to make the remarks I have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the mid‐1980s I was the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. It does not exist now; its job was taken over by the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration. The expenditure committee mirrored a lot of the work that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts did in those days.

SPEECH.PARA: One of its inquiries, when I was chair, was into the activities of the Aboriginal Development Commission, the predecessor of the current Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. That inquiry took between 18 months and two years. In that time, the committee travelled widely around Australia, looking at Aboriginal communities, talking to Aboriginal groups, talking to many people who were critical of the ADC, and generally trying to find some answer to what in those days were some of the ongoing problems in that Commonwealth government instrumentality.

All members of that committee—or all except one, I think—tended to change most of their views towards the end of that inquiry. When we went out to regional Australia and saw the circumstances in which Aboriginal people lived—the difficulties people had in getting things like education and clean water for their children, getting housing over their heads and getting medical attention—it became evident that the Aboriginal people had not been served well by the European community that came here just over 200 years ago.

It struck me at that time that government had to find some other way of resolving our position with the Aboriginal people or else, it seemed to me, it would be difficult for us, as Australians, to look ourselves in the eyes. If we are not able to say that we have made a form of peace with the people who were in this country before us, it says something bad about us as a community.

PARA.BREAK: From time to time over the years in Australia, the issue of race bubbles up, then fortu nately goes away. Then, in uncertain times, it tends to come back again. Unfortunately, at present we are seeing a resurgence of criticism—uninformed criticism—by people about how we should deal in our relations with the Aboriginal community. One of the things that brought me to the view of the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating—that reconciliation and land rights were an answer to this question—was that we have failed in everything else. With the great affinity that Aboriginal people have with the land, that might be the way for us European Australians to come to some reconciliation with the people who cared for this land for 40,000‐odd years.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that, when we get into a position of nearly agreeing on these things, we find ourselves unable to do it. But there is one thing we all should be able to agree on, and that is that what happened with Aboriginal children in Australia up to 1969 was pretty awful. Entire communities of people of indigenous background have been scarred deeply by this country's past draconian policy of assimilation. The separation of thousands of children from their families for no other reason than that they were Aboriginal has left a scar on the people involved and a scar on Australia as a nation.

Evidence has been given to the national inquiry into the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families. It is estimated that in New South Wales one in three Aboriginals now over the age of 25 were removed from their families as children. Nationally, the figure is one in four. These people are still suffering and many of the social issues affecting indigenous Australians today result from their having been treated differently and insensitively in the past. Historian Professor Peter Read estimates that, nationally, 100,000 Aboriginal children were removed from their families under the laws which existed until 1969. Only 30 years ago we were taking Aboriginal children away from their families for no reason other than that they were Aboriginal.

Generations of people had their family life destroyed. Aboriginal children were taken away not because they were neglected by their parents or because their removal offered them some hope of a better life but just because they were Aboriginal. Today many of the widespread problems in Aboriginal communities stem from this policy. Family breakup, violence, chronic ill‐health, alcoholism, substance abuse and lack of parenting skills stem often from the grief, loss and unresolved trauma of many of these people who were taken away from their parents.

Today there is a crisis of parenting in the Aboriginal community as the majority of these children did not receive adequate consistent parenting themselves, especially during the earlier and most formative years of their life. Apart from the thousands of children who were directly affected at the time, there was a more serious effect on the capacity of the removed children to become parents themselves. Removal of the children, therefore, had become a generation cycle. There is a strong link between institutionalisation of parents when they were young and criminalisation of their children.

The problem, as numerous submissions to the inquiry have noted, is that children when institutionalised do not learn parenting skills themselves. The consequences of these policies are flowing on. In Queensland and Western Australia, the inquiry found that in the juvenile justice institutions almost all the kids involved were the children of the stolen generation. In the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, 43 of the 99 deaths investigated were of people who had been taken away from their families as children. That shows the pain that these people still suffer.

It is sad that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) seems to have no understanding of the pain and suffering caused by the forced separation of Aboriginal children from their parents. This shows through in a letter that he wrote to the Northern Territory's Chief Minister, Mr Shane Stone, where he expressed reservations about the benefits of a national inquiry.

The government, irrespective of which party it is, has an obligation to come to grips with these problems of the past. We all have a responsibility to Australia to acquit the past actions on behalf of our predecessors. Part of that acquittal involves allocating resources to heal the damage caused by the removal laws.

I remember the previous shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the member for Hindmarsh (Ms Gallus), sending out a press release saying Aboriginal groups had approached her office saying that in the 1990s Aboriginal women who have their children placed by welfare agencies lack support to rebuild their lives and regain their children. As a result, the situation does not improve with the burden and grief of losing their children and their lifestyle becomes worse. She went on to say that an inquiry was urgently needed to assist both the Aboriginal people who were suffering from the pre‐1970s policies and those who were still losing their children because of the poverty and breakdown of Aboriginal families. The government, unfortunately, showed a lot of concern while in opposition but do not seem to now.

There are many experiences that people have had that show that it was a horrible past for many people. But Senator Herron says a lot of the people benefited. `Benefit' is a pretty subjective thing. I do not see how anyone can think that any parent could benefit from losing their child. How would any honourable member feel if someone came along and took their kids away from them just because they were part of that reviled group called politicians and said, `You are unfit to parent your children,' and took them away?

If someone took one of my three boys away from me when they were young, it would have killed them and killed me. But the government goes on and says that they do not see the need for this inquiry. I hope that, when the government considers the motion the Prime Minister will hopefully agree on with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) shortly on the issue of race, we will confront this issue because we are all successors of the past—and unless we understand what happened then we will be forced to relive it again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance tonight is with the New South Wales Labor government and its interim forest assessment process announced last month. On 23 September—after many anxious months for those involved in the forestry debate in New South Wales—the Carr government announced what it described as `historic reforms which will create new, better paid and safer jobs in a revitalised NSW timber industry'.

SPEECH.PARA: The New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation, Kim Yeadon, even claimed the package `gives industry the certainty it needs to invest in the future and to create jobs'. In reality, the package announced has simply added to the uncertainty for many in the state's timber industry and left an even bigger cloud over the future of many communities in regional NSW, in particular on the mid north coast.

This was supposed to be an `interim' process only. The Carr government were simply required to identify forests for the national reserve system to be created through regional forest agreements as negotiated under the Commonwealth‐state agreement. Instead, the Carr government made a number of `concrete' decisions, including locking up an extra 200,000 hectares of forests in national parks and wilderness areas, further reductions in crown sawlog quotas, plus a 30 per cent increase in timber royalties.

Clearly, the Carr government has pre‐empted the outcomes of the RFA process in a vain effort to make good its election commitments to the Green movement. Bob Carr's political expediency has served only to damage the New South Wales forest industries yet again and undermine the whole RFA process. As the federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) stated in a press release on 3 October:

The result of the NSW Government's actions has been to undermine the scientifically rigorous processes that both the Commonwealth and NSW had agreed would form the basis for signing Regional Forest Agreements.
It is a bit rich for NSW to claim this is an interim decision pending the completion of further detailed assessments, and then lock in a range of long term outcomes.

The NSW package had a number of key elements including, from 1 July 1997, sawlog supplies to fall a further five per cent to 10 per cent—after a 30 per cent cut this year—to between 60 per cent and 65 per cent of 1995‐96 quota levels.

The package has committed to five‐year resource security agreements set at 50 per cent of the 1995‐96 quota levels. There has been the creation of a 90,000‐hectare national park in Eden, with logging deferred from a further 30,000 hectares pending completion of an RFA. The New South Wales package adds 45,000 hectares to national parks, 153,000 hectares to wilderness areas and 671,000 hectares are deferred from logging, pending the completion of RFAs.

There have been plans to use Commonwealth‐state restructuring moneys to purchase private forest land to supplement timber supplies. The price of quota sawlogs is to increase by an average of 20 per cent from 1 January 1997. The plan also proposes to establish regional harvest advisory boards.

The impact of this package on the industry in New South Wales will be a reduction in the viability of the timber industry. First, it will reduce the quantity and quality of timber supplies by cutting sawlog quotas again and by restricting logging from more and more forests. Second, it will increase the cost of timber by increasing royalties by 20 per cent next January. Together, these two elements of reduced timber supplies and higher timber costs will see a gradual squeezing of many small and medium sized timber operations, some of which are in my electorate. As one timber industry person put it to me recently, it is death by strangulation for small business in this industry.

The Carr government's decision undermines the RFA process. Locking up an extra 200,000 hectares in national parks and wilderness areas before the more detailed and comprehensive environmental and socioeconomic studies have been completed in the RFA process is unfair. Bob Carr is playing god with the future of New South Wales forests. He has prematurely sealed the fate of yet more vast tracts of forest land. He has ignored the proper scientific and consultative process his government jointly agreed to follow with the Commonwealth in setting up RFAs.

The Carr government's decision will create further industry uncertainty. There are real concerns as to whether the levels of supply to which New South Wales has committed itself can be achieved, given the additional forest reservations and deferrals that have been made. The New South Wales government has admitted that there will be difficulties in matching its sawlog commitments to the timber industry.

Firstly, it wants to set up regional harvest advisory boards. These boards will be faced with the problem of deciding which deferred forest areas will need to be logged in order to meet commitments. While the proposal appears admirable, the make-up of these regional committees with pro-green and pro‐logging interests could ensure no decisions are reached. In other words, Bob Carr has become Pontius Pilate and washed his hands of any responsibility on meeting sawlog commitments by handing such decisions to these local boards—guaranteeing further chaos in the timber industry.

Secondly, the New South Wales government wants to purchase private forest land to replace existing state forest log supplies. Not only is this a waste of taxpayers' money, it sends the wrong signals to the timber industry, causing yet more uncertainty and problems. The Carr government's decision also excludes other forest users. Forest users, including other sections of the New South Wales timber industry, beekeepers and graziers, have been excluded from the process so far. They have all been affected by the Carr decision, yet were never consulted.

We might ask: what is next? In the wake of last month's announcement, the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments will have to sit down and renegotiate the DFA agreements before proceeding further towards establishing regional forest agreements. While the New South Wales Labor government has sought to play politics with our forests, the Commonwealth remains committed to a balanced future for our forests.

This process will include fast‐tracking the RFA process.The conduct of comprehensive regional assessments leading to negotiation of RFAs is to be accelerated following an additional $48 million in this year's budget. This will ensure finalisation of all RFAs for export woodchip producing areas by mid‐1998 and all remaining RFAs by mid‐1999. The RFAs will provide a world‐class reserve system and the basis for an internationally competitive, value adding and sustainable forest industry.

The Commonwealth has implemented a new woodchip export licensing regime, which sees the retention of the present woodchip export licence ceiling of 5.25 million tonnes plus an extra one million tonnes from sawmill residues and silvicultural thinnings. The Commonwealth requires a three-year licence, which replaces the annual licence regime, and it has banned woodchip exports from areas not covered by RFAs by the year 2000.

The wood and paper industry strategy will be implemented. This strategy aims to promote the development of the wood and paper industry by expanding the plantation resource base, accelerating research and development of value added products, increasing international competitiveness, and developing an internationally recognised certification scheme for sustainably produced forest products. The Commonwealth will continue the forest industry structural adjustment package, which aims to ameliorate the impacts on native forest industry business and workers adversely affected by DFA and RFA outcomes.

In conclusion, the Commonwealth has taken a sensible approach to the management of what should be a sustainable industry in Australia—unlike the New South Wales government, where speculation remains rife as to the extent of damage and job losses that will arise out of the New South Wales government's interim forest assessment announcement last month. The real impact remains to be seen. The next stage of the comprehensive regional assessment process towards establishing RFAs in New South Wales will hopefully be less political and more transparent than that which has been achieved thus far by the Carr government alone.

PARA.BREAK: Our forests and the people that rely on them—conservationists and the timber indus try—deserve better, sounder decision making from government than that which has been provided by the New South Wales Labor government, which evidently in this process and through the decision that has been undertaken are just playing populist politics, particularly with the Green movement. We all saw the election campaign that was run by Labor in the seat of Clarence where the elected member, Mr Harry Woods, was going to be the guardian of the forest industries. I am afraid Harry Woods did not do too much for the forest industry when the Carr Labor government made these decisions, which are going to have a profound and detrimental impact on the forest industries in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As the time for the grievance debate has expired, the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message from the Governor‐General reported informing the House of assent to the following bills:
