DEBATE.TITLE: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Dr Lawrence moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"the House is of the opinion that the bill should be withdrawn and redrafted to provide, in the interest of certainty, for $1 billion from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to be credited upon enactment to the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Reserve".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Heritage Trust of Australia Bill establishes a Natural Heritage Trust reserve, with some of the proceeds of the partial privatisation of Telstra. The fund will be essential for certain environmental projects. It will integrate the joint interests of environmental protection and sustainable development to protect and rehabilitate Australia's natural environment.

SPEECH.PARA: My electorate of Murray is in the heart of the Murray‐Darling Basin. Many years ago it was fashionable to look at the environmental problems in that area and to blame individual farmers. Back in the 1930s, 1940s and 1950s people used to look at the high watertables, the dead and dying trees and the less than sustainable natural flora and fauna and say that the problem was that farmers were irrigating badly. In the 1980s, the Victorian government took a long hard look at the problem and after an all party inquiry decided to dedicate something like $23 million per annum to address the problems of sustainable development in areas like the Murray electorate.

Sustainable development does not come cheaply. Individuals cannot by themselves turn around problems which have as much to do with the geology of ancient parts of Australia as they have to do with the fact that we cleared a lot of trees and irrigated the land without giving much consideration to drainage.

BREAK.PARA: In the 1980s we started to understand catchment planning. If a farmer down basin, say in Echuca or Cobram, wants to do something about the high watertable that is killing his apricot or orange trees he has to look at what is happening often many hundreds of kilometres away in the rocky intake areas—the areas where the water in the first instance intercepts the ground water system.

Why should a farmer or other public interests start planting trees in the central highlands of Victoria when the benefit will be achieved down basin many hundreds of kilometres away? I am trying to illustrate that cross‐basin management requires an integrated effort. It requires public stakeholders—such as recreational users, the people who live in towns and those who benefit from the food and fibre grown in those areas—to stand back and say, `All of us need to raise funds so that we can have proper environmental planning.' In that sense, all must participate in a better and more sustainable future for all Australians.

In the electorate of Murray many millions of dollars is expended by individuals on whole farm plans, water reuse systems, replanting tree plans, looking after the rocky intake areas, planting trees on the roadside and reafforesting the sides of streams. That work is often done on a voluntary basis. The research effort has to be made. Without the many millions of dollars dedicated by the state government and supplemented, through the Murray‐Darling Basin Commission, by federal funds we would have gone nowhere.

I would like to give an example from one part of my electorate which is proof of the work that can be done over many decades leading to a sustainable agricultural system—that is, Barr Creek. Members who learnt geography in the early 1960s and 1970s will remember the reference to Barr Creek as the single biggest source of salt to the Murray. As recently as last Sunday there was a reference to Barr Creek in the Sun‐Herald which continued to suggest that Barr Creek is one of the single biggest sources of salt to the Murray.

The point about Barr Creek is that underlying it are high watertables fed from many hundreds of kilometres away. It is a very flat area. At the turn of the century irrigation was introduced in this area. Within a decade or so the high watertables resulted in the land not being as highly productivity as it was with the first irrigation application.

In the 1930s, men on sustenance pay were sent to dig Barr Creek deeper. The idea was that if there was better drainage in this dairy farming area perhaps the productivity could be improved. The men dug into the creek bed in Barr Creek and quickly intercepted the ground water system, which is more saline than the sea. Barr Creek turned from a stream flowing with basically fresh water into a salt drain—a drain which intercepted the watertable and resulted in the highly saline ground water heading for the Murray. It was not long before part of Barr Creek was diverted to an evaporative basin—Lake Tutchewop—in an attempt to keep the salt flows back from the Murray. Too much fresh water was still entering Barr Creek, however, as run‐off from farms, so Lake Tutchewop was not an efficient evaporative basin.

In the 1980s, it was evident that the Barr Creek farmers were benefiting from the salt drain flowing through to the Murray. But that was a substantial disadvantage to the Murray River basin and the people downstream. With the support of government, with two full‐time project officers and with funds to help them put in whole farm plans, reuse water systems and to plant trees on channel banks they set about doing the major works which were of minimum local advantage but of major downstream benefit.

Barr Creek today continues to lead the way in dairy production. There are major dairy exports from that region. The food is processed at the Kraft factory in nearby Leitchville, which has just invested, with its other factory, some $90 million in the area. I use this example to illustrate how a community of some 300 dairy farmers worked hard and invested substantial sums of private capital to improve an area when the largest benefit was downstream. They could not do that alone. They did it with government funds and government support. I am suggesting that the Natural Heritage Trust will supply the level of funds which can translate into on‐ground works which have a major benefit.

In the Barr Creek today you will see native trees growing, which has brought back bird life. You will see native reptiles and snakes flourishing. The ecosystems are back to being as diverse as they ever were. I suggest that in my area it is not a case of whether or not we need the National Heritage Trust and its billion dollars to help our environment. It is instead a question of how soon it can happen; the whole issue is how we can manage to survive until those funds start to flow.

We have too much damage now with our blue‐green algae blooms, indicators of the results of urban water supplies contaminating our systems. We have too much evidence that we are using our waters beyond the capacity of the Murray River to deliver. There are too many demands on our water supply systems. I am arguing that we should support this bill to the fullest extent. The public of Australia understands that our natural heritage is precious. Without sustainable agriculture and sustainable ecological systems we cannot hold our head up amongst other nations. We cannot continue to be the sustainable food and fibre producers that are important for our economy now and in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey, Fran, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight on behalf of the people of McEwen and in support of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill. This bill delivers to the people of Australia—and to residents in my electorate of McEwen—the strongest commitment to environmental action that this country has ever seen. The primary aim of the Natural Heritage Trust is to protect and rehabilitate Australia's natural environment by establishing the trust, with an initial injection of $1 billion to be funded from the proceeds of the partial sale of Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: Some $700 million of this money will be used to fund five key programs over five years. These initiatives have been strategically developed around five interdependent environmental packages: vegetation, rivers, biodiversity, landcare, and coasts and clean seas. Each of these packages contains measures which will benefit every single Australian. Some people might be surprised by that statement but it is true: literally each and every Australian depends upon the environment in some way, either for food, water, work or recreation.

About six per cent of Australian workers directly rely on the environment for their livelihoods. This includes the agriculture, forestry, logging, commercial fishing and mining industries. The figures rise dramatically for those who rely for work indirectly on the environment. The number of people employed indirectly as a result of agriculture alone is estimated to be about 27 per cent.

The important agriculture and food processing industries which depend upon the environment for survival produce about one‐quarter of our export income. Our flourishing tourism industry has our unique environment to thank for the rapid increases in the number of tourists to Australia in recent years. The environment also affects us on a much more personal level through air pollution, poor water quality and rising soil acidity.

We have a unique environment here in Australia which is the envy of almost every other country in the world, yet we really have taken it for granted and let it fall into disrepair. During the past 200 years of European settlement we have cleared an estimated 20 billion trees. Thousands of plant and animal species have become extinct; waterways have become polluted with sewage, nutrients and silt; and our soil has become more infertile through salinity, acidity and loss of ground cover. Weed and vermin problems have escalated.

Over 50 per cent of Australia's land is now in need of some form of repair. The Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation estimates that losses from wind and water erosion, rising salinity, lower soil fertility, the decline of native vegetation and invasion by weeds and water pollution stand at a crippling $1.41 billion a year. These figures can no longer be ignored. Almost 70 per cent of Australian adults are concerned about at least one environmental problem. But being concerned is no longer enough; we must start to take action now or run the serious risk of our unique environment becoming little more than a wasteland. That is why the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill is so important. It represents a real commitment by this government to environmental action. Australians recognise and share that commitment, including the residents of McEwen.

I have more than 50 landcare, land management and environmental conservation groups in my electorate. Many of them have written to me welcoming the government's commitment to the environment. Their response to the initiative has been both positive and supportive. `At last,' they say, `the environment is getting the recognition it deserves. Finally, here is a government which has a clear plan for addressing our complex environmental problems.' For example, the Creightons Creek, Ruffy and Terip Landcare Group in my electorate says:
Our Landcare group was pleased to learn that the Federal Government will be focussing on remedial and preventative works for land degradation.

While research will be needed on some aspects of some land problems, there is enough information and know‐how available in most areas to tackle problems now. Lack of funds is the major limiting factor.

We look forward to the promised increased support for landcare groups and the refocussing of the National Landcare Program. Would you please keep working on this as we believe that such changes will not happen easily.

For the past 13 years too many vital environmental dollars have been tied up in administration, bureaucracy and bus tours; and too little on positive action and on‐ground works. Fortunately, this government recognises that it takes more than mere words and a few cheap headlines to address our environmental problems; it takes the sound strategies and substantial funding which this bill delivers.

This view is shared by Ingrid Martin, secretary of the Home Creek/Spring Creek Landcare Group in my electorate, who says that the great dilemma that so many landcare and conservation groups are experiencing across McEwen and around Australia is lack of funds. They have the management plans in place, but in order for their grassroots work to provide widespread and lasting results they desperately need the funding and strategies which the Natural Heritage Trust will deliver.

BREAK.PARA: One group in McEwen which has taken the initiative to develop an effective, long-term strategy is the Upper Goulburn Catchment Group, which encompasses 50,000 hectares from Mount Buller to Mansfield, Alexandra, Molesworth and Yea. The Upper Goulburn catchment project area produces half the certified grass seed grown in Victoria, stone fruits for export to Asia, wine grapes, herbs, farm forestry, prime beef and lamb, fine wool, deer, milk and 75 per cent of fish in the state. It is also the second largest potato growing area in Victoria. The unique landscape of the area and its diverse native animal and bird life also make it popular for ecotourism. Water is the lifeblood of the area. The area contains Lake Eildon, Victoria's most important water storage area and a complex system of waterways.

The group's strategy aims to improve and maintain water quality in the catchment by combating the extensive flash flooding, salinity, erosion and pest, weed and land degradation problems currently being experienced. It aims to achieve these objectives by priority works, which include pasture re-establishment, erosion control, extensive revegetation, creek stabilisation and vermin and weed control. However, to do so, the group needs more than $5 million in funding. It may seem like a lot of money but, if we sit back and do nothing, these problems will simply escalate and all the natural advantage the area holds will be lost.

Another local group, the Goulburn Broken Catchment and Land Protection Board, has just released its draft catchment strategy. This region comprises 2.4 million hectares of land, which supports a population of 200,000 and major agriculture, food processing, forestry and tourism industries. The processes of land clearing and irrigation have resulted in significant degradation of the catchment's land, water and biodiversity. Salinity is such a major problem in the area that a special dry land salinity management plan has been developed to try to control the problem.

If current practices are not altered, salt affected land will increase from 3,500 hectares to 38,000 hectares in the next 30 to 50 years. Already, more than $500,000 a year is lost in agricultural production. As a nation so reliant on our environment for employment and export income, we cannot allow the situation to worsen.

Community groups like those I have mentioned in McEwen have already prepared themselves for action. It is now time that we, as their elected representatives, work with them to improve the environment. By establishing the Natural Heritage Trust through this bill, this government is going to provide funds to these groups to undertake on‐ground works. These groups do not need more awareness raising or studies. They need money and well‐developed strategies, all of which this bill will provide.

Any attempts by the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens to frustrate this legislation will lead only to further environmental damage—more land degradation, greater weed and vermin problems, worsening water quality and increased salinity problems. Is this the legacy that we want to leave our children and grandchildren? I think not. This decline can be stopped right here and now. We have the opportunity with this legislation to provide the level of funding needed to arrest and repair environmental damage. I urge all members to support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill is all about government responsibility, focusing on the long-term environmental future of this country rather than short-term political gain. I congratulate my National Party colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), who is in the House tonight, along with the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, and his predecessor, Senator Rod Kemp, for putting together this legislative package which will bring new meaning to the words `responsible environmental policy'. I am particularly pleased that this bill was introduced by a National Party minister.

SPEECH.PARA: There are few people who are more in touch with the environment than our farmers. They are the principal custodians of the land. The vast majority of these people consider themselves active environmentalists, not environmental activists. There is a big difference.

On this note, I would like to mention some of the initiatives which the previous coalition government implemented. The Antarctic treaties of 1960 and 1980 were coalition initiatives, as was the Whale Protection Act. We proclaimed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, the Kakadu and Uluru parks and the Christmas Island National Park. We played a major role in the prevention of sandmining on Fraser Island, as well as many other major achievements. These speak for themselves.

The environment, and the protection of it, should not be the exclusive domain of the Greens, the Democrats or the ALP. What the Australian environment needs is a government which will implement policies which are based on hard‐core scientific fact, not on short-term gains. One classic case in point is the woodchip issue.

The Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill looks at the environment as a set of integrated and mutually influential issues. It targets five broad environmental issues: vegetation, rivers, biodiversity, landcare, and the coasts and oceans. None of these areas are more important than the other, but we must recognise that they are all interrelated and interdependent.

The Howard‐Fischer government will inject $700 million through a number of major initiatives, concentrating on the following: the national vegetation initiative, the Murray-Darling 2001 project, the national reserve system, the national land and water resources audit, the coast and clean seas initiative, the endangered species program and the national river care initiative. But the beauty of this trust is that, apart from the unprecedented $700 million going into it, another $300 million will remain in perpetuity for future generations.

On this note, I would like to highlight a few of the environmental problems we have on the far north coast of New South Wales. The electorate that I represent encompasses three major water catchment areas—the Richmond, the Brunswick and the Tweed. These catchments, and many coastal catchments in Australia, have a high incidence of acid sulphate soils. Acid sulphate soils, by definition, means the presence of a mineral in the soil called iron pyrite, which releases sulphuric acid when exposed to oxygen. A very hardworking group in my electorate, the Richmond Tweed Acid Sulphate Soils Local Action Committee, is doing some outstanding work to combat the effects of acid sulphate run‐off, particularly into the Tweed River.

Past experience highlights the importance of this issue. In 1992, over 2,600 tonnes, it was estimated, of pure sulphuric acid were discharged into the Tweed River. In 1994, over 950,000 tonnes were discharged into the Richmond River. The environmental consequences of such a discharge are enormous, particularly when 60 to 70 per cent of commercial fish species spend part of their life cycle in these estuaries.

Don Buckley, a director of Tweed Shire Council, along with Mike Melville, from the University of New South Wales, and Ian White, of the CSIRO, have been advocating and testing water and soil pH and monitoring water tables and acid sulphate run‐off for the past four years. With the cooperation of local cane farmers, such as Robert Quirk and Robert Hawken, these scientists have found that applying lime to cane field drains can change the pH level from 2.7, which is highly acidic, to 7, which is neutral.

I would like to see a slice of the Natural Heritage Trust spent directly on liming acidic drains. Given that the whole Tweed community benefits from a cleaner, safer and more diverse river, the cost of such work should be borne by the taxpayer, not just the cane farmers.

Another area that this legislation addresses is farm forestry. Apart from direct environmental benefits, farm forestry can offer a much needed source of additional income for landowners. In Richmond, there is a great potential to use relatively poor country to reap the environmental and economic rewards of revegetation. On this front, I am very pleased to see that over $20 million has been allocated to farm forestry.

Farm forestry is definitely the way of the future. While we are importing over $2 billion worth of timber products, adding to our trade deficit, we would be foolish not to develop aspects of this industry. But we also need legislation which will give the security of harvest for those land‐holders who choose to do it and choose to make that 20‐year investment.

Another issue which is particularly pertinent to this bill is water quality and river health. Regrettably, a recent EPA report found that the quality of water in the northern New South Wales rivers was not up to scratch. Following this, unfortunately an outbreak of food poisoning sparked the closure of the Tweed River to shellfish collection. This attracted great media attention and seriously impacted on the area's reputation as a prime holiday destination. It also affected and jeopardised the livelihood of many hardworking oyster farmers.

I have no doubt that the $85 million for the national rivercare initiative, as well as the $100 million for the coast and clean seas initiative, will go a long way to solving the degrading effects of stormwater run‐off, sewage overloads and sediment build‐up which are threatening the very life of these rivers.

I take this chance to congratulate the total catchment management groups in these three valleys for their combined work in addressing these problems. On this subject, I think there is a real need for a major change in attitudes to waste management on the part of the public and on the part of local councils, for it is all too easy to blame river degradation on the farmers who may live in the upper catchment areas or on developers. It is time we started thinking about what we do with our own body waste. The general public must take the lead in the Brunswick, Tweed and Richmond catchments. We must recognise that our own body waste is one of the major sources of river pollution.

Finally, I would like to mention the efforts of over 45 dunecare, landcare and rivercare groups in the Richmond electorate. The local knowledge of these volunteers is one of the greatest assets we have in attempting to conserve our environment. The Natural Heritage Trust will ensure that these landcare groups will become our front‐line force in tackling dune degradation, pollution control, soil conservation and monitoring natural flora and fauna. All these groups deserve praise, particularly my local group, Fingal Dune Care.

Another particular interest I have is that the Natural Heritage Trust be used to fund the construction of the Caldera Trail. This perhaps could rival the Milford Track. Members of this House who have climbed Mount Warning, such as the member for Farrer, Tim Fischer, would be familiar with the stunning volcanic rim which surrounds the Richmond electorate.

This area takes in four world heritage parks. In order to fully appreciate this Caldera region, I would like to see a walking trail encompass the whole line, linking up with existing trails and giving bushwalkers the chance to experience the unique biodiversity we have in that special part of Australia. There are a number of complex issues in this, such as track degradation and the construction of access points, but I am sure this trust could play a part in getting the project started, along with the rainforest centre which is being built in Murwillumbah.

Another group which deserves praise for its outstanding work is the community based Byron Bay Whale Watch Centre. This is Australia's premier viewing platform for watching whales. It is rather ironic that these magnificent mammals are still a source of income for the local economy, despite the fact that this income is now raised by observing and learning from whales instead of slaughtering them.

In conclusion, I would like to bring the House's attention to a very relevant expression: you can't be green if you are in the red. I think this expression sums up this legislation. By creating a trust fund, this government is supplying the means by which we will be able to preserve the best environmental practices to ensure that our natural heritage is preserved for the long term.

I believe that governments and individuals, when talking about the environment, need to stretch the definition of `long term' from a few generations to forever. Preserving the environment is about ensuring that our grandchildren can enjoy no less than we have today. If we fail to take into account all the facets of the environment, without a long‐term view, we will soon find that we are degrading our environment faster than we are attempting to preserve it. It is long‐term environmental policies that we need, not short‐term political gains.

I believe certain sectors of the Green movement are guilty of short‐sightedness by spending their energies on specific, isolated, populist issues at the expense of critical issues of the 1990s—clean air, clean water, sustainable forestry and soil conservation. Irrespective of our politics, we all have a responsibility to pass on our environment in a better state than we inherited it. This bill sets in perpetuity these goals. As the final backbench speaker on this important piece of legislation, I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some concluding remarks. I thank all those who have participated in this debate. I found it very interesting to listen, for example, to the two previous speakers and learn something of their obvious commitment to the real problems of environmental degradation and decay that need such urgent addressing in various individual places around the country. There is no doubt that this opportunity before us now is a historically significant one, a very important one, and one that we ought not miss—for the sake of this generation and future generations in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Governments, for generations now, have been hearing about the serious deterioration of Australia's natural resources. They have responded bit by bit, a little bit more here, a little bit more there, to the point where in recent years there has been a considerable amount of money and resources dedicated to grappling with the problems of natural resource degradation. But the reality is that we now have to face the fact that is abundantly clear: despite the efforts, the deterioration has continued; it is reaching alarming proportions and even accelerating at alarming proportions in many parts of the country, particularly in some of our most productive agricultural producing areas. That leaves us with the simple conclusion that a great deal more needs to be done. Governments have been prepared to go part of the way, but I think the community is now insisting that we go the whole way, and that we really do put in an effective, far reaching, visionary and—let's face it—expensive effort in this regard.

The Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill provides for just those objectives; that is, it constitutes a massive financial commitment to support the efforts of the community to address the problems we so clearly face. The National Farmers Federation, just for one, obviously acknowledges the extent and the seriousness of the problem, but also the need for very large funding resources. It recognises that the options for finding that degree of funding are very limited and that we have indeed isolated the only obvious and entirely appropriate source of funding.

The extent of the challenges which need to be addressed are really quite daunting. The visual effects of land and water degradation, salinity and vegetation decline are all too apparent across this country. The statistics which have been presented time and again—we heard some more of them tonight in some excellent presentations—reflect the deterioration in almost every aspect of our natural resource base.

The Natural Heritage Trust contains five key capital projects, all eligible for very substantial funding under the approach that the government has adopted. For example, there is $163 million for the Murray-Darling 2001 project, $32 million for a comprehensive national land and water resources audit, $80 million for a national reserve system, $100 million for the coasts and clean seas initiative, and $318 million for the national vegetation initiative. That is a total going on for $700 million in expenditure proposals. In addition to the five key capital projects, the Natural Heritage Trust provides the mechanism for a further commitment of over $450 million towards the implementation of other extremely important environmental and sustainable agriculture initiatives.

In total, the trust will be the springboard for a commitment of $1.5 billion over the next five years to directly engage the most pressing environmental challenges faced by this nation. At the conclusion of the five-year period an amount of around $300 million will still remain in the trust as a foundation for future programs of worth. I think we all know in our heart of hearts that an ongoing commitment by governments, as well as communities and land managers, land custodians—farmers perhaps chief amongst them—will be needed probably indefinitely. So I think it is important that we recognise at the outset that the commitment that will be required is a permanent one. It is a commitment until death us do part, so to speak.

The debate in this House over the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill has been a very interesting one. I believe that in some ways it serves a very useful purpose. It has, if you like, invigorated the national debate and helped build an overwhelming recognition by all members that Australia faces a challenge to its natural resources which simply cannot be overlooked. There are social and economic reasons and, in the end, there are trade and employment implications for the future of our nation that simply cannot be overlooked or ignored.

So it seems to me that I can really say that there is an opportunity here for the members of this House to engage in being part of what will one day be recalled as a defining moment in Australia's approach to natural resource management. It is the moment when the government, the opposition and the independents have an opportunity to put any political differences aside to provide a valuable legacy for future generations.

In this regard we as parliamentarians here in this parliament now at this time are in a very privileged position. We are privileged in that we have the opportunity to represent the views of our constituents, the policies of our respective parties and our personal views and beliefs in a forum which charts a positive course for the future of this nation. Here now we have this special opportunity before us; we have the opportunity to put any constraints aside and to make a decision which will benefit Australia's natural heritage and thereby enhance the lives and fortunes of future generations. I am a fifth generation farmer and I do have a real awareness of the importance of protecting and sustaining our natural resources for the benefit of those who come after us. We know so much more know than we knew in days gone by. Experience, bought sometimes at great expense over 200 short years of European style farming in this land, coupled with increased scientific knowledge and increased awareness of the fragile nature of the lands that we produce from so abundantly in this country, combine to give us a much stronger platform for future understanding and use of our natural resources. We need to make sure that we don't waste it, that we don't throw it away, that we now take the opportunity to act on the basis of what we know.

I believe that as parliamentary representatives we should all strive to make a positive difference to the welfare of this nation during our terms of office. This Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill will allow us to make a very real difference. Every day, every week—as one of the immediate past speakers commented—that the passage of this and the associated Telstra bill is delayed, our natural resources are declining forever, some unfortunately to an irretrievable level. That is a horrifying truth, but truth it is.

Now is the time to act; not tomorrow, not next month, not in the next parliament, but now. This nation requires a unified commitment to environmental management. The Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill provides a forum for each elected member to demonstrate their personal willingness to stand up and be counted on an issue that really does matter.

PARA.BREAK: One of the privileges in my life has been to have been personally part of the development of the government's environmental and sustainable agricultural policy since its inception. It is also a great privilege to have been able to introduce this bill to the parliament for the full scrutiny of members. It is a privilege now to recommend to this House its unified support for an instrument of legislation which will provide the opportunity for the government as a whole to be able to finally address the serious natural resource challenges that it faces—challenges that I believe we as com munity representatives have nothing short of an outright moral obligation to embrace.

SPEECH.PARA: When this bill passes to the Senate, there will undoubtedly be further debate on the merits of addressing the serious environmental challenges of this country. Indeed, I make the observation in my closing remarks that there are individuals and groups in the Senate who espouse environmental principles as their very reason for being. In some ways, this bill will be a public test of their conscience, a test of their true resolve in relation to these matters about which they protest such earnest concern.

In commending this bill, I call upon each and every representative of both houses to put any political differences aside and support the passage of this long overdue piece of legislation, one which will bring about significant and long lasting benefits for this nation, one which, in its entirety, in terms of the broader implications of its implementation and so forth, in my view, constitutes sound communications policy, sound economic policy and undoubtedly sound environmental policy. On that note, I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, omit the second dot point of the simplified outline.
Page 3, line 11, omit "Australia's natural capital infrastructure", substitute "Australia's natural environment".

I wanted to speak briefly to this amendment because, in many respects, it captures not only our second reading amendment but also the other amendments we have sought to make to this legislation. We support the general objectives outlined in this bill. We made that clear in our speeches during the second reading debate. But we do object very strongly to the linking of these very worthy objectives to the sale of Telstra.

The clause that we object to in this case has, as one of its objectives, that the main source of money for the reserve will be $1 billion from the partial privatisation of Telstra. I do not need to repeat to this House the very considerable concern that we have on this side about that link. The environment is sufficiently important to stand on its own merits. There is no other area of government policy that has been held hostage in the way that the environment has to the sale of a public asset. That is why we object to this provision.

It is quite clear from the material that has been provided to us not only in the budget papers but also through the Senate estimates committee hearings that the amount of additional funding, when you look at the cuts in the budget of some 13 per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would the member for Fremantle resume her seat for a moment. The level of conversation in the chamber is far too loud. I invite members to either take their seats or leave quietly.

—What I was outlining was the fact that this $1 billion from the partial privatisation of Telstra is much diminished when you look at the very considerable reductions that have already taken place in the budget that is before this House and that is being debated in the other place at the moment. There is overall a 13 per cent reduction in existing levels of expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: That is clearly in breach of the commitments that were given by the government before the election when it was said that the Labor Party's then level of funding would be maintained. There were no quibbles, no qualifications. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) repeated that commitment after the election when he said that our funding would be maintained. Instead, when the budget came down, we found some 13 per cent overall reduction. In some areas of policy there were very substantial cuts in addition to that, ranging up to 21 per cent in the case of the Environment Protection Authority.

The community have been asked to take the government at its word on the use of these funds in the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia reserve. I think at this stage the government's word would have to be seen to be considerably lacking. In addition, if you add together the previous levels of funding by the Labor government and the commitments we made during the election campaign to the funds that the government was committed to, minus their budget commitments plus the Telstra amounts, you are talking generously at around $50 million extra a year. That is for the sale of one-third of Telstra, with the very considerable disadvantages that confers throughout the community. It is the loss of a public asset of great magnitude. The government is going to deliver to the environment in excess of what Labor promised to the tune of $50 million a year. Members opposite ask why we object to this legislation. We object to it because it is very clear indeed that this is of no advantage to the environment.

The other element of this amendment that I have proposed is that the whole idea that the bill is simply dealing with matters of capital infrastructure is basically designed to hoodwink people. When the government were in opposition they were in the difficult position of saying, `Well, anything that we privatise, anything that we sell off, we will make sure that it only goes to repaying debt or capital expenditure.' So they are put in the position of having to define a lot of these programs that they list in the bill as if they were capital structure when clearly they are recurrent expenditure. That is, they would normally be funded from the recurrent revenues of the nation. We are asked to believe that they have this new quality conferred upon them.

It was made clear in the deliberations and questions in the Senate estimates committees that a lot more things might be added to the Natural Heritage Trust over time, many of which clearly do not have the character of capital infrastructure. We object on both those points to this clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask every member of the House to read Denis McCormack's research paper, which was presented under Victorian police protection to the 20th anniversary conference of the prestigious Asian Studies Association of Australia at the Latrobe University, Melbourne, on 10 July 1996. His paper was entitled `The grand plan: Asianisation of Australia—race, place and power'. It was incidentally the same day that Mr Ted Drane, the sporting shooter, was firing blanks at Denis and AAFI during his nationally televised Press Club address. The Press Club would learn a lot more from Denis than they did from Ted, which is why the media so fear his research, the obvious influence and political activism of Denis.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said before that Australia needs Denis McCormack in federal parliament. In this paper, which I intend to seek to table tonight, he has arrived. I will now read into Hansard the abstract of his paper and then seek your good judgment in allowing me to table the paper in the national interest. I hope this documentation will at once enable, inform, empower and inspire you to buck your respective parties and factions, and start representing more accurately in this place what members well know to be the majority of Australian views on immigration and Asianisation. Unless this problem is sorted out soon, the Australia that the majority of Australians have loved is doomed, and other problems become more insoluble. Here is the most concrete of abstracts:
Quoting only mainstream press/academic sources, this paper makes the case that a long‐range `grand plan' was nurtured by elites for the Asianisation of Australia.

Analysis of the process, together with some of its prominent players, has never before been drawn together for chronological exposition. The diggers, the founders of the Labor Movement, the Fathers of Federation, Furphy, Lawson and Patterson, along with countless other true‐blue Australians, from their day to ours, warned about the future swamping, dispossession and eventual disappearance of all things traditionally Australian should mass Asian immigration ever be sanctioned. Those warnings of yesteryear are today not only officially ignored and suppressed, but are being systematically erased from our common national memory through manipulation of Immigration Policy, Multicultural Policy, Education, Trade, Foreign Affairs, Defence, and Industrial Relations as well as Finance and Economic Management Policy in relation to globalisation, privatisatio
n, deregulation, foreign ownership and foreign investment. Australia is being demographically and economically recolonised through gradualist bipartisanship against often demonstrated public opinion.

Although this paper was written in early November `95, before the change to a Liberal/National Coalition Government after the March `96 Federal Election, the author has resisted the temptation to tinker with the text since the incoming Government has made it clear that whilst the faces have changed, the song remains the same. Apart from some useful but minor administrative changes, overall direction in vital policy areas outlined above will remain consistent with the directional changes initiated over the last 30 years—changes that simply became more obvious under the recent 13 years of Labor Government. Hence the paper's central thesis of the existence of an anti‐democratic Immigration/Asianisation bipartisan continuum remains intact, even bolstered.

The Australian public is largely uninformed about the scale of the scam or depth of deception documented in this paper, let alone the irreversible long term ramifications implied therein for their collective future. They are encouraged instead to believe that `The Price is Right' for `The Sale of The Century'. `It won't happen overnight, but it will happen'. . . `oh what a feeling'. . . `please consider'.
If there is no objection, I table that speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Moreton Bay is one of Australia's foremost environmentally sensitive areas on the doorstep to south‐east Queensland. Moreton Bay has some of Australia's most impressive island habitats—not that I am biased, because they are the centrepiece of my electorate—but because these islands provide a recreational playground second to none in the world. The bay supports an important fishing and boating community and is enjoyed not only by my constituents along the foreshores of Redland and Wynnum‐Manly, but also by many more who travel great distances for the pleasures of a bayside lifestyle.

SPEECH.PARA: To fully appreciate the future viability of this area as a recreational and prosperous business community, the relevant jurisdictions need to manage carefully the interchange between population, flora and fauna, and the resources within the boundaries of the bay. To closely monitor and add to the collective knowledge that needs to be documented, ongoing, active, hands‐on research needs to be continued.

A marine laboratory was established at Dunwich in 1949 by the state Department of Harbours and Marine. It was shared by the CSIRO's Fisheries Division and the University of Queensland. The UQ took over the site in 1961 from Harbours and Marine and put in a caretaker. Since then, this facility has been used by many departments and schools, as well as by international groups who pursue active field research in this prime marine habitat. The station has increased its usage to almost continuous usage by students and researchers from many and varied fields of study.

Of other significance, this field station helped develop the study of marine science in Queensland. Many of its graduates have gone on to further study and research, and the North Queensland field station of marine studies could be said to have its roots and origins in the activities of students from the Dunwich field station.

Over time, the facility has deteriorated to the point that major repairs are no longer possible. Restructuring and redesigning of the facility is required to upgrade it to world‐class standards. The work carried out from the station into Moreton Bay is vital, and all jurisdictions—local, state and federal interests—would be better served with the upgrade.

Professor Jack Greenwood, and the Director of Marine Science at UQ, Dr Ian Tibbits, have stressed that research into Moreton Bay has to continue, particularly with the ever increasing growth in urban development along the foreshores. Currently, the station is in need of an upgrade to the tune of $250,000. That would improve the shell of the building to start with. DEET funding has been approved to upgrade the interior. A later stage would see the dormitory and canteen facilities improved.

This project is an investment in future generations' use of the bay and its environs. The challenge is overcoming environmental limitations due to so many unknown factors. Federal funding has been forthcoming for aquiculture projects through the CSIRO and landcare projects to monitor waterways in the Redland area. The whole bay—flora and fauna, fishing and built communities—benefit from a commitment to research right in the middle of the bay.

The assistance to Moreton Bay of the application of the clean seas initiative from the partial sale of Telstra will see these things carried out. Without those proceeds, these initiatives to oversight the long‐term future of Moreton Bay will not happen. The hope of local councils, for university programs, research and development and forward thinking environmental solutions to challenges facing our coastal area will not be lost without the injection of major capital funding for vital environmental monitoring.

For the future of Moreton Bay, and all those other bays around coastal areas where ocean outfall and the pressure of increasing population are problems, the partial sale of Telstra has to go ahead. I put it to the House that, for the future of our bay environment, the clean seas program must see the light of day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the matter that I wish to raise tonight goes to the very heart of the notion of propriety and good government. I wish to draw attention to the striking similarity between some of the conflicts affecting the awarding of the advertising and PR contracts for the national gun control campaign, and the irregularities involved in the awarding of the casino licence by the Kennett government in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: Both the casino licence tender and the gun control contracts have been contaminated on a number of occasions. Premier Kennett said of the process for the casino tender:

We have always said during the tendering process that we would not be involved in discussions with them (Crown) simply because the only appropriate place for the discussion is with the casino authority.
He also said that he instructed his ministers not to meet or discuss casino issues with Crown. Later he admitted that he had met with Lloyd Williams of Crown to discuss casino matters.

BREAK.PARA: Similarly, the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) needs to clarify whether DDB Needham Adelaide visited his office the day after they were placed on the short list and whether they discussed the advertising contract. Any discussions would have compromised the integrity of the tendering process. His responses today provided no answers about the role played by his office.

The Prime Minister's senior political adviser, Mr Grahame Morris, intervened to have DDB Needham Adelaide included in the pitch list of five firms. He further intervened to have DDB Needham included on the short list, and we know this as fact. How can he claim impartiality and an open mind on the ministerial committee when he has already taken these extraordinary measures on DDB Needham's behalf?

Conflicts of interest undermine the fairness of tendering processes. They also undermine the appearance of impartiality. The process for the awarding of the casino licence to Crown was dogged with a number of examples of conflicts of it. Ron Walker, as chairman of Melbourne Major Events Corporation, and Lloyd Williams knew that Melbourne had won the right to stage the Australian Grand Prix when they were bidding for the casino licence. None of the other tenderers were privy to this information, which placed them at a severe disadvantage in terms of forecasting future revenue and hence formulating the value of their bids.

In April 1994, Lloyd Williams purchased land from Dinner Plain Pty Ltd for $150,000. Professor McIntyre, Chair of the Planning Panel for the Casino Authority, is a director and shareholder in Dinner Plain Pty Ltd, and also designed Mr Williams' ski lodge. Michael Barlow, another member of the planning panel, was a director of an architectural firm, A.T. Cox, and acted for Hudson Conway in the redevelopment of Tooronga Village.

The government has stated that Crown won the licence on the basis of design, rather than for financial reasons. The planning committee was crucial to Crown's success. The public should have been aware of Professor McIntyre's and Michael Barlow's conflicts of interest. The national gun control advertising process also suffered from conflicts of interest.

Members of the ministerial committee on government communication have longstanding connections with those who have benefited from these contracts. Senator Minchin and Grahame Morris have both worked closely with DDB Needham Adelaide on Liberal Party campaigns. Toby Ralph, Ted Horton and John King, all of DDB Needham Adelaide, are well known to members of the ministerial committee. The member for Kooyong, Mr Georgiou—the only backbench member ever of the ministerial committee—has also worked with the DDB Needham family on Liberal Party campaigns.

The Kennett government approved the expansion of the Crown Casino from 360 hotel rooms to 1,000 and from 200 gaming tables to 350. These changes occurred after the tender was awarded to Crown. DDB Needham Adelaide, since being awarded their contract, have substantially rewritten their advertising strategy and the budget for the campaign has been expanded from $1 million to $2.88 million. The whole campaign is running behind schedule.

The conduct of the Kennett government in awarding the casino licence shattered the faith of investors in the fairness of the Victorian government's tendering process. Jim Gallagher, of ITT Sheraton, declared that they would not bid for any state government contracts as a consequence of their treatment during the Victorian casino process. Similarly, John Bevins Advertising and Foote Cone and Belding Sydney, two of the unsuccessful bidders, have both said that the experience had convinced them not to pitch for government business again. Sham tendering processes that reward government mates hurt the interests of the Victorian and federal governments because reputable firms will refuse to tender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise here tonight to condemn what I see as one of the most insidious factors holding our economy back from its rightful course to recovery—the seeming price grab in diesel fuel prices by the multinational oil companies that hold our nation to ransom because of deregulation.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, fuel prices in Cairns rose another 1c per litre—the third price hike in as many weeks—hitting an all‐time high of 76.9c, more than 9c dearer than this time last year, or an increase of over 13 per cent in a 12‐month period, and 3c dearer than unleaded petrol. This is absolutely shameless opportunism by these multinationals and it is well past the time that this government stepped in and brought these international price pirates into line.

In a feeble attempt to explain what can only be seen as price manipulation, the last reason the oil companies gave to fuel distributors as to why diesel prices were rising in Far North Queensland and across Australia generally was the lame excuse that an excessively cold Northern Hemisphere winter was forcing prices up. That was nearly 12 months ago. Well, the Northern Hemisphere has come out of that winter, gone through spring and summer, and is now into autumn again, and yet diesel prices not only have not come down but have continued to increase.

These fuel companies are holding Australian small business to ransom at a time when the rest of the community is looking towards an improvement in the nation's financial state, by ripping off not only our small business people but every Australian, particularly those in regional areas like my seat of Leichhardt, through excessive prices.

The massive excessive profits that oil companies have been making since deregulation first raised its ugly head under the Hawke government in 1983 have been pointed out to the recent petrol pricing inquiry, and since the dismantling of regulating price controls following that the only winners have been the oil companies, and the massive losers have been Australian consumers, motorists and especially those in businesses whose activities have a major fuel component.

The average price of crude oil purchased by Australia in 1982‐83 was $35.21 per barrel. At this time last year, Gippsland crude could be bought for $16.50 per barrel, but where were the discounts to the consumer that should have been passed on?

We now have the crazy situation where, on the international spot oil market, for some reason or another you can buy a barrel of petrol—yes, I mean refined petrol—cheaper than you can buy a barrel of crude. If you call that rational economics, then I am glad I do not run my own business that way.

Instead of the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission looking at letting supermarkets sell petrol, this country should be looking at introducing the strongest possible anti‐competition sanctions against the oil companies, as these people have now proven that they cannot be trusted with deregulation and should be shunned by the rest of those of us in the Australian business community who are trying to make a `fair go' of a very unlevel playing field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I take the opportunity to talk about the sort of commitment that parents and volunteers make within many an electorate around this country but particularly in my electorate of Namadgi. When I say that, I am talking especially about the participation rate in winter sports within my community of Namadgi.

SPEECH.PARA: I am fortunate to be involved in a number of clubs, particularly junior ones in the area. Without the volunteer work of the parents and other people who attach themselves to these clubs, I am sure we would not see the success rate that we do. My electorate has one of the highest participation rates in sporting activity that you would see in the country for the age group that I am talking about.

Tonight I want to particularly refer to my association—although I have many associations with many clubs—with the Tuggeranong Junior Bulldogs Club, of which I happen to be patron. This club represents a very large number of junior Aussie rules footballers in the electorate and has a participation rate that demands of the organisers, all of whom are volunteers, a huge commitment. The result of the commitment from those people can be seen in the success of the club and in the delight that the young people have in their participation in their sport.

There is one particular young man in that club that I would like to give a special mention to tonight. His name is Steve Hall. He has been in the Tuggeranong Junior Bulldogs junior sides since the under‐8s. His early years with the club included selection in a number of ACT development squads and the captaincy of his own club side.

Back in March of 1995, Steve was unfortunately diagnosed with lymphatic cancer. This in fact happened just four days before he was to enjoy his first experience with the ACT in the under‐15s squad. Throughout 1995 he underwent intensive chemotherapy and radiotherapy. He was too sick to play at all last season, undergoing several long periods in hospital with serious infection as a result of that treatment. Steve worked very hard on his fitness over last summer and set his sights this year on playing for the Bulldogs under-17s and training with the ACT under‐16 national schoolboys squad, both of which goals he achieved.

The two things that are noteworthy here are that, first of all, he could not have done this without his own determination, his own love of the game and his own commitment to the other young people with whom he plays the game. Secondly, his father especially and his family really supported Steve to the hilt and gave him every encouragement to continue through that difficult time.

I was fortunate enough as patron of the club to be invited last month to the annual presentation night. One of the most joyous things that I could have done that evening was present Steve with a Youth Football Achievement Award, which was given to him at the club by the club for his example of commitment, let alone skill, displayed in the sport. It is obvious that Steve has a great affection for the game, but it is also obvious that he is very good at it. He receives a lot of admiration from his fellow young people, and it is a delight to see the reaction of the under‐8s, the under‐9s and the under‐10s who pay attention to the kids who are senior to them who have come through similar ranks.

BREAK.PARA: I have no doubt, having met Steve and having met his family briefly and having talked to people within that club, that this young man can probably achieve anything he wishes to in his lifetime. His achievement, along with the performances of the former Tuggeranong ACTAFL players Aaron Hamill and Justin Blumfield, who have now got to AFL level, provides tremendous encouragement for the other young sporting people, but particularly sporting footballers, in the Tuggeranong valley. At that presentation night, when a trophy and a shield went out to a couple of under‐8s, they saw the name of Aaron Hamill, who had done his junior football through the same club and is now playing first‐grade AFL. The look on their faces when they saw what they could achieve from their Tuggeranong urban area and the sort of reaction that those young players have to someone like Steve Hall, I can only say, augurs very well for the future of sport development in our electorate. In conclusion, I congratulate Steve and his family on the hardship that they have come through with flying colours. With the club, I very joyously wish them all the success for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a particularly moving story delivered by a very warm and caring member. I appreciated having the opportunity to listen to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about agricultural shows and what flows from them. In my electorate of Dickson there are two agricultural shows and, bordering on my electorate, there is a further agricultural show. In my opinion, these are part of a great culture in this country. What they foster is a number of particular things that bring the community together: they bring the country together and they bring the city together. As far as Brisbane is concerned, the ultimate show, the Royal National Association Show in August, brings again that marriage of the country and the city.

More particularly, as I have noticed in the Pine Rivers show and in the Samford show, it brings out the great Australian sport of woodchopping. I am someone who has followed the woodchops for a long time and I really appreciate the woodchops. I see at the table the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles), who lives in Tasmania, the state of the greatest woodchopper in the world, David Foster, whom he would know. We see David Foster at the royal national show every year and, believe you me, when Foster swings an axe, everyone stands and watches very closely and the wood does not last too long.

What I am leading to is this. We have the Olympics coming up in the year 2000. What better way to show the world one of the best demonstration sports than to bring to the world and to the kaleidoscope of atmosphere of the Olympics the great Australian sport of woodchopping?

As members will know and as most of the Australian people will know, there are many aspects of woodchopping. You can have the underhand woodchop, the standing block and of course the tree. One of the greatest spectacles I used to find at the show in Brisbane—at the Ekka, as they call it—was the tree event, where the axeman has to cut notches in the tree, climb the tree, chop one side, come back down again, go to the other side of the tree and do the same thing until the block is knocked over. With that event you can also have team relays. The various states line up at the national shows for the relay competition.

I urge the organisers of the Olympics to look very seriously at having woodchopping as a demonstration sport to show the world that this is an exciting and uniquely Australian sport. This would also illustrate that you can enjoy sport in an exciting atmosphere and in a real Australian way—that is, with the noise, colour and movement involved with the chopping of wood.

Agricultural shows are a nursery for these people. It is wonderful to see how the axemen go through the competitions at the shows in the capital cities and exhibit the sport. I beg the Olympic organising committee to look seriously at incorporating woodchopping as an Olympic demonstration sport. I know that a number of sports are being considered. I do not think a decision has been made on which sports to include. I ask them to seriously consider woodchopping because it is one of the finest spectator sports that you can imagine and nobody could doubt that it, more than most other sports, is uniquely Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I had the privilege of receiving an invitation to attend a function in the grounds of Parliament House. I have to confess that it was certainly one of the more pleasant events that I have attended since coming to this great House. The event was the Praise Corroboree and it was celebrated by the coming together of hundreds of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as well as non‐ATSI people in fellowship, with a focus on prayer and healing our land. It was a particularly uplifting experience to see culturally diverse groups come together for a common good. I commend Pastor Peter Walker, President of the Praise Corroboree Association, and the other fine Australians who made this wonderful experience a reality.

SPEECH.PARA: It was particularly exciting for me to see Tim Edwards and the group of kids from Emmanuel College in Cairns not only attend but also give the lead performance in the evening's concert. They performed magnificently and were a credit to their families and teachers. I must say that I was very proud of these wonderful kids and I have no doubt that each and every one of them has a very bright future.

But what was very disappointing about the whole event was the lack of interest by the media. Here we have a large group of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people standing up and spreading goodwill and good news, with one of their prime objectives being greater unity between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and fellow Australians. The media obviously did not consider it a significant enough event to report.

I find it amazing that the media will fall over itself to report any negatives within Aboriginal society, be they past treatment, Third World living conditions, corruption and financial abuses, land rights disputes, black deaths in custody and, at present, the relocated children inquiry and the Hanson debate. Yet when we have an event whereby Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people stand above all the negativity and show the rest of the world that they are responsible, caring, proud Australian citizens, they are virtually ignored. It is a sad indictment of our times when it would appear that only conflict, anger, condemnation, hate and greed sell newspapers or achieve good TV or radio ratings.

I, and I am sure many others in this place, would dearly love to see more of the good news stories and the other side of the Aboriginal debate more actively promoted in the media. I call on the media, in the interests of fairness, to give a little bit more time to covering events such as the Praise Corroboree and give recognition to the many fine Australians—Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and non‐ATSI people—who are actively working towards a noble and unified Australia of which all of its people can be justly proud.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr MILES (Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (10.57 p.m.)—I wish to add my comments to those made by the member for Leichhardt (Mr Entsch). The issue he raised is very important. About 1,000 Aboriginal people were in Canberra for the Praise Corroboree and they came from virtually all over Australia. They travelled thousands of kilometres to get here. If we had two or three Aboriginal people belting on the front doors of Parliament House the media would have been swarming all over them. On this occasion, these people came down as an act of reconciliation and to talk to members of parliament.

Many people within Security in Parliament House were concerned about how things would go. While the event was on many people involved with security in Parliament House did not even know these people were here. Their behaviour was exemplary. The organisers took a lot of trouble to ensure that, due to recent events, these people from all over Australia behaved themselves.

The member for Leichhardt has raised a real concern that when Aboriginal people and other Australians get together, share in a common cause and a common purpose, very little recognition is given and no mention is made of it in the newspapers. This is a great tragedy. It is one of the reasons there is division in Australia.

Peter Walker, an ATSIC commissioner, and others were part of the Praise Corroboree and I want to congratulate them on a marvellous job. It was an excellent idea. I understand that in future they want to repeat this. I hope it becomes bigger and better. The Praise Corroboree here a couple of weeks ago was fabulous. Everybody involved in it should be congratulated. It is a basis for deep, lasting and genuine reconciliation in this country. I add my comments to those of the member for Leichhardt.
