ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sydney Olympic Games: Increased Air Traffic

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 9 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did his Department or AirServices Australia conduct any survey regarding the increased volume of air traffic at Atlanta in the period immediately preceding, during and immediately after the Olympic Games; if so, what were the results of the survey.

(2) Based on the experience of Atlanta, have any predictions been made as to the likely increased volume of air traffic at Sydney in the period immediately preceding, during and immediately after the Sydney Olympic Games; if so, what are the predictions.
(3) What plans are being made to handle this additional volume of air traffic at Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport.
(4) Will other airports be used to ease the burden on Sydney; if so, (a) which airports and (b) what is the anticipated volume of additional traffic at those airports.
(5) Has any consideration been given to small aircraft and charter aircraft using the RAAF Base Richmond runway during the Olympic Games period.
(6) Will the 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew at Sydney airport be maintained in the period immediately preceding, during and immediately after the Olympic Games.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Representatives of the Federal Airports Corporation and Australia's major airlines visited Atlanta during and after the Games and had discussions with the operator of Hartsfield Airport and the main carrier, Delta Airlines. Detailed statistics on actual aircraft and passenger movements before, during and after the Games are not yet available but are expected to be received later this year.

(2) and (3) A comprehensive review is currently being undertaken of Sydney Airport's capacity to cater for all traffic in the year 2000. The review is taking account of the under‐utilised capacity of Sydney Airport during off‐peak hours; the experience of other Olympics and the capacity of other airports to cater for any need for overflow traffic such as charters and aircraft parking, should they be needed for the Games. The aim is to complete the review by the end of 1996 with the various issues being kept under review in the lead up to the Games.

(4) and (5) The Federal Government expects that Sydney Airport will be able to cope with the traffic expected at the time of the Olympics. However, as part of the contingency planning for the Games, all options are being examined should they be needed, for example, contingency use of other airports if particularly bad weather conditions affected Sydney Airport's capacity for a sustained period of time. No estimates have been made of any additional traffic which might use other airports but the numbers, if any, are likely to be small based on the experience of other Olympics.
(6) The 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew will be maintained immediately preceding, during and immediately after the Games.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 10 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Australia relatively free of known pests and diseases of rice.
(2) Does this help to give Australia a well deserved reputation as a producer of clean and low pesticide level foods.
(3) Is the Golden Apple snail, Pomacaea canaliculata sub species ampullariidae now present in Australia: if so, where did this pest come from and how did it enter Australia.
(4) Are attempts being made to prevent the snail's entry into the Murray River basin and rice growing areas: if not, why not.
(5) What methods of eradication of the snail are available to growers.
(6) Are these methods understood and readily available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, Australia is free of many serious virus and mycoplasma (phytoplasma) diseases of rice and also free of the leafhopper vectors which transmit these diseases to rice. These diseases are Orange leaf MLO, Yellow dwarf MLO, Dwarf, Tungro and its similar diseases Waika and Bunchy stunt; Transitory yellowing, Stripe and Black‐streaked dwarf, and Rice Gall dwarf phytoreovirus. The South east Asian vectors (Zigzag leafhopper (Recilia dorsalis) and Green leafhoppers (Nephotettix spp.)) and the vectors of these diseases in China and Japan (Laodelphax striatellus, Unkanodes sapporonus, Unkanodes albifascia and Terthron albovittatus) are absent from Australia. Australia is free of the South American disease, Hoja Blanca and its planthopper vector, Sogatodes oryzicola. Giallume is exotic to Australia but a few of its aphid vectors are present in Australia while others (Sitobion avenae) are not. Rice grassy stunt tenuivirus, Wilted stunt virus, and Rice ragged stunt oryzavirus, diseases exotic to Australia, are vectored by the Brown planthopper (Nilaparvata lugens) which is present in Australia.

Australia is also free of serious insect pests of rice namely White‐backed planthopper (Sogatella furcifera), Malayan black bug (Scotinophara coarctata), Yellow stem borer (Scirpophaga incertulas) and Pink borer (Sesamia inferans), Rice ear bug (Leptocorisa oratoria), Rice leaf folder (Cnaphalocrocis medinalis), other rice stem borers (Rupela albinella and Maliarpha separatella), Gold fringed borer (Chilo auricilia), Spotted stalk borer (Chilo partellus) and Early shoot borer (Chilo infuscatellus), Stinkbug (Oebalus pugnax), and Asian rice gall midge (Orseolia oryzae).

The aquatic snails Pomacia dolioides, Pomacia glauca, Pila globosa and Pila polita which attack seedling rice plants overseas are not present in Australia. Aquatic snails may also act as intermediate hosts for fluke parasites which are absent from Australia. Australia is free of several terrestrial snails and slugs which can also contaminate rice.

The mite, Oligonychus oryzae is not known to be present in Australia but can reduce yields up to 25% in India. Rice rust mite (Abacarus oryzae), Cereal rust mite (Abacarus hystrix), Steneotarsonemus spinki and Steneotarsonemus madecassus act as minor virus vectors of rice and grasses overseas but are absent from Australia.
Khapra beetle, Trogoderma granarium, a serious pest of stored rice and other grains is absent from Australia.

(2) Yes. The pesticide use on rice in Australia is considerably less than that in Asia. This results from the fact that the main rice‐growing area in Australia (the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area) is in a temperate area of the country free of the tropical pests of rice (eg stem borers, planthoppers) and is isolated from other rice growing areas. New South Wales also has no recorded virus or phytoplasma diseases of rice. Insecticides (Chlorpyrifos, replacing Maldison) is used only as a preventative for bloodworm control (Chironomus tepperi, a midge) during the 4 weeks when plants are small. No insecticide is used after this stage except for control of armyworm but this practice is rarely used and is actively discouraged by the rice industry to avoid spraying close to harvest. The rice industry has also replaced its reliance on insecticide use on stored grain with physical control methods. Herbicides are still required for weed control in rice but their use is less than that used overseas.

(3) AQIS was first advised in November 1991 by the Australian Museum, Sydney of the presence of Pomacaea canaliculatain Australia following the identification of specimens received over two years previously from Western Australia. The identity of the snail had posed some difficulty (it was known as `mystery snail' in the aquarium industry) and may be the same species as that recorded in Thailand as Pila ampullacea. This snail was said to have been traded for some (probably as long as ten) years in the Australian aquarium trade and to be actively bred at least two localities for shipment Australia‐wide. It was on sale in aquarium shops in Brisbane in 1993. As AQIS has no record of imports of this snail it is assumed to have been brought to Australia illegally or accidentally with fish. It is a native of Argentina and was introduced to Taiwan as food in 1980 from whence it has been carried to Japan (1981), the Philippines (1982) and is now widespread in Asia (Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia), Hawaii and Papua New Guinea. AQIS's view is that there is presently no evidence that the snail is established in the wild in Australia.

(4) AQIS understands that following the location of suspect snails on sale in a pet shop in Griffith in March 1994, which were subsequently identified as Golden apple snail by overseas experts, the NSW Department of Agriculture in Griffith, with the cooperation of the pet industry and the Australian Museum, suspended sales of this snail in NSW and began testing the snail as to its tendency to eat rice plants. The pet industry had maintained it only feeds on algae on the aquarium walls but subsequent testing by the NSW Department of Agriculture confirmed that it ate rice plants. Proclamation No 70727 under the Plant Diseases Act was passed by NSW on 10 November 1995, declaring Golden apple snail and snails of the family Ampullariidae pests in New South Wales. The second part of this legislation, which is not yet in place, will ban the snail from the rice quarantine areas. Coincidentally, the rice quarantine area is being extended and this legislation is due to go before the NSW Parliament shortly. It will require owners and occupiers of land within the quarantine area to destroy snail and snail eggs of the family Ampullariidae.

(5) There are no snail control chemicals registered for use against the Golden apple snail in NSW. There are no molluscicides registered for use in NSW apart from copper sulfate which is also used for algal control. About 1% of farms may be affected by 1 cm‐sized local aquatic snails whose populations build up in response to rainfall. If the snail numbers pose a risk to crop establishment, fields are aerially treated with granular copper sulfate as needed following the aerial sowing of the pregerminated rice into the flooded fields. Because Golden apple snail is a much larger snail, copper sulfate's effectiveness against it is unproven. Although copper tends to drop out of solution quickly into the mud, the Environmental Protection Authority (EPA) and the Australian and New Zealand Environmental Council (ANZEC) have established guidelines on drainage water management which must be met by growers using this treatment.

(6) The NSW Department of Agriculture is aware of controls that are being applied in the Philippines against Golden apple snail. These chemicals (eg niclosamide) are not registered for use in NSW against aquatic snails. Growers are aware of the use of copper sulfate in NSW against snails but would be unaware of the control problems that Golden apple snail would cause if it were to become established in the wild. The methods used to control Golden apple snail in other States (both in the aquarium trade or release into the wild) differ from activities occurring in NSW. Victorian authorities have not found Golden Apple Snail in that State and Victoria has no specific quarantine measures for this pest. Following the passage of the NSW legislation extending the quarantine area, a publicity campaign aimed at alerting rice growers to recognise Golden apple snail would most likely follow.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 18 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard ,9 September 1996, page 3686), has his attention been drawn to disquiet in the Customs Service about recent amendments to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations.
(2) Do the definitions of firearms and associated requirements in the regulations leave room for interpretation.
(3) Will the regulations conflict with provisions in the Firearms Act of Western Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The overwhelming response from Customs Officers involved with this issue is that the recent amendments to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations have achieved the goals of implementing the Australasian Police Ministers' Council resolutions and of providing a legislative framework which is much simpler to interpret.

(2) Any regulation which covers as wide a range of goods and involves as complex a series of tests and requirements as the import controls on firearms will almost inevitably provide some scope for interpretation. Administrative guidelines have been issued to ensure that Customs interpret the new regulation in a consistent and uniform manner.

(3) There may well be differences between the regulations and the provisions of the Western Australia Firearms Act. The purpose of the amendments was to implement the resolutions of the special Australasian Police Ministers' Council meeting by implementing more stringent controls on the importation of automatic and semi automatic firearms in the existing controls. The resolutions requires all States and Territories to introduce minimum standards regarding licensing and possession of firearms. However, there was never any intention that the Commonwealth legislation should mirror that of Western Australia or any other State or Territory.
